markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1875 (ETQ) STATION IS NEAR MONROE, ON LAND OWNED BY OLDEN TURNER, ON TOP OF HILL.  HILL IS MOSTLY WOODED, THOUGH CLEAR NEAR STATION, SOIL, LEDGE AND BUSHES.  SIGNAL SET NEAR TOWN LINE BETWEEN LYMAN AND MONROE.  TO REACH GO BY THE RIVER ROAD FROM MONROE HILL 4-1/2 MILES N TO CHURCH, THEN RIGHT 1/2 MILE TO HOUSE OF O.A. KENNEY. SIGNAL IS IN HIS CHARGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) IN SEARCHING FOR THE STATION A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP WHICH HAD A GROUP OF NAILS WEDGED INTO THE DRILL HOLE WAS FOUND NEAR THE SUMMIT OF HILL, BUT IT WAS NOT POSITIVELY CERTAIN OF THIS BEING THE OLD STATION MARK.  A DISTANCE WAS MEASURED TO THE GROUP OF NAILS IN DRILL HOLE. DISTANCE BEING 0.230 METERS (0.75 FEET) EAST FROM TRIANGULATION STATION BALD LEDGE 2.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS ABOUT 10 MILES WEST OF LITTLETON, 6 MILES NORTH OF LISBON, ON THE HIGHEST PART OF GARNER MOUNTAIN, AND IS ON LAND OWNED BY MR. DON HALL AND MR. RALPH VARNEY.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN LITTLETON, GO WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 18 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 18 AND 135.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAYS 18 AND 135 FOR 6.0 MILES TO WHERE STATE HIGHWAY 135 TURNS LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW STATE HIGHWAY 135 FOR 4.6 MILES TO MONROE TOWN LINE.  CONTINUE ON HIGHWAY 135 FOR 2.3 MILES TO A GRAVELED SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW THE GRAVELED ROAD FOR 1.6 MILES TO A SMALL GRASSY AREA AND TRACK ROAD ON THE LEFT.  THIS IS END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR A 2-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK.  (A 4-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK CAN BE DRIVEN ABOUT 1/2 MILE FARTHER).  PACK EASTERLY ON A TRACK ROAD FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO A FORK OF THE TRACK ROAD.  TAKE RIGHT FORK FOR ABOUT 30 YARDS TO A ROAD FORK, THENCE LEFT FORK FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO WHERE THE TRACK ROAD TURNS RIGHT AND A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON TREE ABOUT 30 YARDS TO THE LEFT.  FROM THE TRIANGLE BLAZE FOLLOW A BLAZED TRAIL NORTHEASTERLY TO SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  ABOUT A 1-1/2 HOUR PACK.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BALD LEDGE 2 1958, IS SET IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  THE OUTCROP OF ROCK IS ABOUT 10 FEET BY 12 FEET.  THE MARK IS 14 FEET NORTH OF A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON A 4-INCH PINE TREE AND 6 FEET SOUTH OF THE RIM OF ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BALD LEDGE 2 NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 3 FEET BY 3 FEET.  IT IS ON THE SOUTH SLOPE OF PEAK ABOUT 4 FEET LOWER THAN STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BALD LEDGE 2 NO 2 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 2 FEET BY 3 FEET.  IT IS 8 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH END OF ROCK LEDGE AND 10 FEET EAST OF THE WEST END OF ROCK LEDGE.  A DISTANCE WAS MEASURED TO A GROUP OF NAILS DRIVEN INTO A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK OUTCROP.  DISTANCE BEING 0.230 METERS (0.75 FEET) EAST OF THE STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (JBJ) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DUE TO ROAD CHANGES AND NATURAL OBJECTS A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 11 MILES WEST OF LITTLETON, NEW HAMPSHIRE, 9 MILES SOUTH OF ST. JOHNSBURY, VERMONT, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF GARNER MOUNTAIN AND ON LAND OWNED BY RALPH VARNEY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN LITTLETON, NEW HAMPSHIRE, GO WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 18 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 18 AND 135.  CONTINUE WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAYS 18 AND 135 FOR 6.0 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 135, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 135 FOR 4.5 MILES TO THE MONROE-LITTLETON TOWN LINE.  CONTINUE SOUTHWEST ON HIGHWAY 135 FOR 2.3 MILES TO A PAVED SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT, JUST AFTER PASSING A FIRE STATION ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.95 MILE TO THE END OF THE PAVEMENT AND A HOUSE ON THE LEFT, CONTINUE EASTERLY ON DIRT ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO AN ABANDON HOUSE AND BARN ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE EASTERLY ON DIRT ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK, TAKE THE RIGHT FORK, NORTHERLY, FOR 0.05 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO WEST THEN NORTH ON OLD LOGGING ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO AN OLD LOGGING ROAD ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE NORTH THEN WEST ON LOGGING ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE. IT IS POSSIBLE THAT IN DRY WEATHER A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLE COULD BE DRIVEN FARTHER BY FOLLOWING OLD LOGGING ROAD SOUTHERLY FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE END OF THE LOGGING ROAD.  FROM THIS POINT, PACK SOUTHERLY UP STEEP HILL FOR ABOUT 30 MINUTES TO THE TOP OF MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BALD LEDGE 2 1958, CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A MASS OF ROCK OUTCROP, THAT PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  IT IS 11.0 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF A ROCK LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BALD LEDGE 2 NO 1 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A 3 BY 3 FOOT ROCK OUTCROP, THAT PROJECTS 2.0 FEET ON THE EAST SIDE. IT IS ABOUT 4.0 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED BALD LEDGE 2 NO 2 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A 3 BY 3 FOOT ROCK OUTCROP, THAT PROJECTS 12 INCHES.  IT IS 12.0 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF A ROCK LEDGE, 7.0 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE ROCK LEDGE AND ABOUT THE SAME IN ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  NOTE--THE DISTANCE BETWEEN THE REFERENCE MARKS COULD NOT BE MEASURED DUE TO OBSTRUCTION.  MAIN SCHEME LINES WERE NOT OBSERVED FROM THIS STATION DUE TO SNOW IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--9 MILES SOUTH OF ST. JOHNSBURY, VERMONT                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (WMJ) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARKS NO. 1 AND NO. 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED BY J.B. JONES IN 1968.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1878 STATION SOMETIMES CALLED BOY MT. IS 2200 FEET HIGH, THE SW END OF THE RANDOLPH RANGE, PATH IS ABOUT 1/2 MILE LONG ASCENDS FROM THE MT. ADAMS HOUSE, 5-1/2 MILES SE OF JEFFERSON HILL.  IN 1876 A VISTA WAS CUT THROUGH THE GROWTH LEAVING 1 SPRUCE TREE, WITH LOWER LIMBS LOPPED OFF, STANDING IN THE GAP, AND VISIBLE FROM STARR KING, AND PROBABLY FROM WASHINGTON.  UPPER BRANCHES WERE NOT TRIMMED.  TREE IS ABOUT 5 METERS N OF PATH AND 10 OR 15 METERS FROM HIGHEST POINT OF THE LEDGE IN A GENERAL DIRECTION AWAY FROM MT. ADAMS.  IN THE PATH AND 17.25 METERS (ERROR OF PERHAPS 2 CENTIMETERS) FROM THE TREE IS A POINT CUT IN THE LEDGE AND USED BY THE TOPOGRAPHICAL DEPARTMENT OF THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN CLUB.  LAND OWNED BY JEREMIAH RICKER, JEFFERSON, NEW HAMPSHIRE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12 MILES NORTHWEST OF ERROL AND ABOUT 8 MILES EAST OF COLEBROOK ON THE BALSAMS GOLF COURSE.  STATION IS 84 FEET NORTH OF FLAGPOLE AND 4.5 FEET SOUTH OF EDGE OF GRADED BANK.  STATION MARK IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED BALSAMS 1959.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 3 AND STATE HIGHWAY 26 IN THE SOUTH PART OF COLEBROOK GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 26 FOR 10.9 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO 0.5 MILE TO THE BALSAMS HOTEL ON LEFT.  CONTINUE ON BLACKTOP ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO FORKS.  KEEP RIGHT FORK FOR 1.65 MILES TO FORKS.  TAKE LEFT FORK FOR 0.1 MILE TO CONCRETE WALL AND AZIMUTH MARK ON RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  CONTINUE FOR 0.15 MILE TO FORKS.  TAKE RIGHT FORK FOR 0.05 MILE TO STATION ON THE RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 64 FEET EAST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF BLACKTOP ROAD AND 25 FEET WEST OF FLAGPOLE.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS STAMPED BALSAMS NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 79 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF STONE PORCH OF CLUBHOUSE AND 40 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF ROAD.  THE MARK IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED BALSAMS NO 2 1959.  AZIMUTH MARK IS 17 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF BLACKTOP ROAD AND 6 FEET WEST OF THE EAST END OF A CONCRETE WALL BETWEEN THE ROAD AND A SMALL LAKE.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF THE WALL WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET AND IS STAMPED BALSAMS 1959.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.

BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) THE STATION MARK IS A HOLE DRILLED IN THE LEDGE ON HIGHEST POINT.  JUST TO THE W, ABOUT 200 OR 300 FEET DISTANT, IS ANOTHER LEDGE, NEARLY, IF NOT QUITE AS HIGH.  AROUND THE STATION MARK, 3 OR 4 INCHES FROM IT, THERE ARE 3 SHALLOW HOLES FORMING A TRIANGLE.  THE SUMMIT IS A LONG RIDGE RUNNING NEARLY N AND S, HIGHEST POINT IS TOWARD THE S.  THE LAND IS UNDER THE CARE OF OTIS WHEELER OF NEW IPSWICH. SIGNAL LEFT IN CHARGE OF EZRA CARR, OF NEW IPSWICH.  STATION MAY BE REACHED BY GOING TO THE HOUSE OF MR. EZRA CARR, NW SIDE OF MOUNTAIN, ON MOUNTAIN ROAD FROM NEW IPSWICH TO RINDGE. SUMMIT ABOUT 1/2 MILE FROM HOUSE.  ASCENT NOT VERY HARD. THE WHOLE MOUNTAIN ON N, E AND S CLEARED.  IT IS SAID THAT THERE IS A ROAD ALMOST UP TO THE TOP, AND THE EASIEST ASCENT IS AS FOLLOWS--TURN FROM THE MAIN ROAD BETWEEN PETERBORO AND NEW IPSWICH ON A ROAD LEADING TO SMITH VILLAGE, ON E SIDE OF MOUNTAIN.  TURN FROM THIS ROAD ONTO THE FIRST ROAD TO THE RIGHT, AND GO TO HOUSE OF WM.D. LOCKE.  THENCE THERE IS A ROAD ALMOST TO THE TOP. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2.0 MILES SW OF BARRINGTON ON THE HIGHEST PART OF BEAUTY HILL AND ON LAND OWNED BY MISS EDNA LOCKE AND LLOYD SMITH.  IT IS 35 FEET S OF THE CENTER LINE OF A GRAVEL ROAD AND 33 FEET ESE OF A TRIANGULAR-BLAZED 18-INCH PINE TREE.  IT IS STAMPED BEAUTY HILL 1943 AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES.   SURFACE AND UNDERGROUND MARKS ARE BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE. REFERENCE AND AZIMUTH MARKS ARE BRONZE DISKS SET IN DRILL HOLES IN BOULDERS.   REFERENCE MARK 1 IS NE OF THE STATION AND 22 FEET N OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE GRAVEL ROAD.  IT IS STAMPED BEAUTY HILL NO 1 1943.   REFERENCE MARK 2 IS NW OF THE STATION AND 18 FEET N OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE GRAVEL ROAD.  IT IS STAMPED BEAUTY HILL NO 2 1943.   AZIMUTH MARK IS E OF THE STATION, 50 FEET SSW OF THE SW CORNER OF A HOUSE, 48 FEET NW OF POWER-TRANSMISSION LINE POLE 26, 15 FEET SE OF THE E GATEPOST THAT IS IN A ROCK FENCE, AND 12 FEET N OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE GRAVEL ROAD.  IT IS STAMPED BEAUTY HILL 1943.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 4, 9, AND 125 AT THE E EDGE OF THE TOWN OF BARRINGTON, GO S ON HIGHWAY 125 FOR 1.55 MILES TO A CROSSROADS AT WINKLEY POND.  THEN RIGHT ON A GRAVEL ROAD FOR 1.0 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE AHEAD (W) FOR 0.4 MILE TO A FORK, THEN LEFT FORK FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 27 METERS. BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1983 THE BASE LINE IS LOCATED AT THE BERLIN MUNICIPAL AIRPORT.  THE AIRPORT IS AT THE SMALL HAMLET OF MILAN, WHICH IS ABOUT 11.3 KM (7.0 MI) NORTH OF BERLIN.  THE BASE LINE IS ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE AIRPORT, EAST OF OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE NORTH-SOUTH RUNWAY, AND IN THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF A MOWED FIELD AREA.   TO REACH THE BASE LINE FROM THE POST OFFICE IN MILAN, GO SOUTH ALONG STATE ROUTE 16 FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A PAVED ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ALONG PAVED ROAD FOR 0.6 KM (0.4 MI) TO A PAVED T-ROAD JUNCTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ALONG PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) TO A PAVED PARKING LOT AND THE ENTRANCE TO THE AIRPORT ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ALONG PAVED ENTRANCE FOR 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO A HANGAR BUILDING ON THE LEFT AND THE AIRCRAFT RAMP AREA. CONTINUE EAST ACROSS RAMP AREA FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO THE POINT WHERE THE RAMP AREA LEADS INTO THE RUNWAY AND LANDING STRIP. TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ALONG THE WEST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY FOR 0.4 KM (0.25 MI) TO THE NORTH END OF RUNWAY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ACROSS RUNWAY AND MOWED FIELD AREA FOR 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO THE 0 METER POINT ON THE LEFT.   THE BASE LINE IS A NORTH-SOUTH LINE WITH THE 0 METER POINT ON THE NORTH END.  IT CONSISTS OF THE 0, 150, 400, AND 1400 METER POINT, WITH A POINT FOR THE CALIBRATION OF 100 FOOT TAPES SET ON LINE SOUTH OF THE 0 METER POINT.  THE BASE LINE IS IN A MOWED FIELD AREA AND IS EAST OF AND APPROXIMATELY PARALLEL TO THE RUNWAY.  ALL THE MARKS EXCLUDING THE 1400 METER POINT ARE SET ABOUT 110 FEET EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY AND ABOUT 60 FEET WEST OF A WOODS LINE. THE 1400 METER POINT IS SET ABOUT 110 FEET EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE RUNWAY AND IS ABOUT 30 FEET EAST INTO THE WOODS AREA FROM THE EAST EDGE OF THE MOWED FIELD AREA.   THE 0 METER POINT IS A STANDARD NGS DISK NOT STAMPED SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 30 CM (12 IN) IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH THE GROUND LOCATED ABOUT 33.5 M (110.0 FT) E FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE AIRPORT RUNWAY, 28.5 M (93.5 FT) ESE FROM THE CENTER OF A RUNWAY LIGHT CONTROL BOX, 18.3 M (60.0 FT) W FROM A WOODS LINE, AND 1.3 M (4.4 FT) S FROM A WITNESS POST.   THIS BASE LINE WAS ESTABLISHED IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE NEW HAMPSHIRE LAND SURVEYORS ASSOCIATION.  FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT NEW HAMPSHIRE LAND SURVEYORS ASSOCIATION, PUTNAM HALL, THOMPSON SCHOOL UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE, DURHAM, NH 03824. markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY GEOCACHING 2009 (RG) THIS STATION MARKS THE BOUNDARY LINE BETWEEN TOWNS OF NEWTON AND PLAISTOW NEW HAMPSHIRE AND THE TOWNS OF HAVERHILL AND MERRIMAC MASSACHUSETTS.  THIS BOUNDARY POINT WAS ORIGINALLY MARKED IN 1827 AND SURVEYED BY SIMEON BORDEN IN 1834 AS PART OF HIS TRIANGULATION OF MASSACHUSETTS (1830-1838).  THIS POINT IS ONE OF 8 SUCH POINTS SURVEYED BY BORDEN ON THE MASSACHUSETTS - NEW HAMPSHIRE LINE AND WAS ORIGINALLY KNOWN AS 'BRANDY BROW HILL'.  THE BORDEN POINTS ARE DOCUMENTED IN THE BULLETIN OF THE USGS NO. 13 (1885) 'BOUNDARIES OF THE UNITED STATES AND OF THE SEVERAL STATES AND TERRITORIES' BY HENRY GANNETT, CHIEF GEOGRAPHER.  IN THE SECTION ON THE BOUNDARIES OF MASSACHUSETTS, A TABLE LISTS THESE 8 BORDEN POINTS WITH GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS ALONG WITH POINTS ON THE BOUNDARIES WITH OTHER STATES.  THE CURRENT MONUMENT WAS SET IN 1890 AND CONSISTS OF A GRANITE POST ABOUT 4 FEET HIGH AND ABOUT 15 INCHES SQUARE.  ON THE NH SIDE IT IS INSCRIBED 'N + P, NH, 1890' AND ON THE MASSACHUSETTS SIDE 'H + M, MASS, 1890, BRANDY BROW'.  THE 'H' ON THE TOP LINE AND THE LAST LETTER 'W' OF 'BRANDY BROW' HAVE BEEN LOST TO EROSION.  A GROOVE CUT ON THE TOP SURFACE WITH A DRILL HOLE IN THE CENTER MARK THE BOUNDARY LINE AND THE CORNER POINT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM INTERSTATE 495, EXIT 52 IN AMESBURY, MA, GO SOUTHWEST ON ROUTE 110 1.0 MILES TO ROUTE 108 ON THE RIGHT.  GO NORTH ON ROUTE 108, CONTINUING INTO NH AT TOTAL OF 2.9 MILES TO THE NEWTON - PLAISTOW TOWN LINE (JUST PAST A CITGO STATION ON THE LEFT). PARK VEHICLE  AND PROCEED EAST UP THE HILL ABOUT 200 YARDS TO THE STATION.  REPORT SUBMITTED BY R. GARLAND.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 (OBF) STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL KNOWN AS BUNKER HILL SOME 3 MILES N OF THE TOWN OF EXETER AND NEAR THE TOWN OF STRATHAM.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A HALF-INCH DRILL HOLE (SHALLOW) IN A TRIANGLE IN A LARGE ROCK JUST ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE TOP OF THE GROUND AND ABOUT ON THE W SIDE OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  A LARGE SPLIT BOULDER IS ABOUT 60 FEET NE OF THE STATION AND A VERY TALL ONE ABOUT SE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1930 BUNKER HILL (NOT THE HISTORIC HILL OF THAT NAME, HOWEVER) IS NOT FAR FROM WHERE I AM NOW LIVING AND I HAVE BEEN THERE FREQUENTLY.  FOR SOME TIME, I WAS UNABLE TO FIND THE TRIANGULATION STATION, HOWEVER, PARTLY AT LEAST BECAUSE OF THE MEAGER AND INACCURATE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  FINALLY I CUT OUT SOME OF THE SMALL BIRCHES SO THAT I COULD SEE STATIONS MARK AND STRATHAM TALL CHURCH SPIRE IN LINE AND THEN, ON NOV. 23, 1930, I FOUND THE STATION.  IT WAS IN A CLUMP OF BIRCHES AND COVERED WITH LEAVES.  THE MARK SEEMED TO HAVE BEEN CHIPPED IN SUCH A WAY THAT THE DRILL HOLE HAD DISAPPEARED AND ONLY A PART OF THE TRIANGLE REMAINED.  THE STONE DID NOT IMPRESS ME AS BEING A STABLE OR SATISFACTORY STATION MARK, AND WHAT WAS LEFT OF THE TRIANGLE WAS ON THE EXTREME EDGE, WHICH SUGGESTED THAT PERHAPS THE STONE HAD BEEN PARTLY ROTATED BY FROST ACTION OR OTHERWISE.  A SPLIT BOULDER, DOUBTLESS THE ONE REFERRED TO IN THE PRINTED DESCRIPTION HAS A 3-INCH TRIANGLE (NOT MENTIONED IN THE DESCRIPTION) CUT IN IT, THE TRIANGLE BEING ABOUT 86.4 FEET FROM THE STATION, ABOUT S 54 DEG W.  THIS BOULDER IS SUBSTANTIAL, BEING ABOUT 9 FEET LONG, NEARLY AS WIDE AND ABOUT 3 FEET HIGH.  THERE IS NO OTHER SPLIT BOULDER IN THE VICINITY, SO THIS MUST BE THE ONE DESCRIBED AS BEING ABOUT 60 FEET NE OF THE STATION, THE DISTANCE BEING APPARENTLY AN ERROR.  THE VERY TALL BOULDER MENTIONED IS ACTUALLY ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET HIGH, ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET IN DIAMETER AT THE BASE, AND MORE OR LESS CONICAL, WITH A 3 1/2-INCH TRIANGLE CUT IN THE TOP, BUT NOT MENTIONED IN THE DESCRIPTION.  THIS TRIANGLE IS ABOUT 84.5 FEET FROM THE STATION, ABOUT N 30 DEG 07 MIN W.  I AM REASONABLY SURE THAT THE MARK I HAVE DESCRIBED IS THE STATION, AND THE DIRECTIONS TO SUCH NEARBY OBJECTS (STRATHAM, MARK, STRATHAM TALL SPIRE, EXETER STANDPIPE) AS I COULD SEE, HAVE CHECKED TO THE NEAREST MINUTE, WHICH IS AS CLOSE AS I ATTEMPTED TO READ MY SMALL ENGINEERS TRANSIT.  I THINK THERE IS A DECIDED POSSIBILITY THAT THE STONE MAY NOT BE IN EXACTLY ITS ORIGINAL POSITION, HOWEVER.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH SMALL BIRCHES AND THE VIEW IS VERY LIMITED.  THE PRESENT OWNER OF THE PROPERTY, R.E. HOLMES, OF STRATHAM, TELLS ME, HOWEVER, THAT HE EXPECTS SOON TO CUT OFF THE TREES AND UNDERBRUSH, AND USE THE LAND IN HIS POULTRY BUSINESS, AS A RANGE FOR HENS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION NOT RECOVERED.  TWO HOURS WERE SPENT SEARCHING FOR THIS STATION WITHOUT SUCCESS.  IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT THIS STATION BE CLASSIFIED AS LOST.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTH NORTHEAST OF JEFFERSON, ABOUT 1/3 MILE SOUTHEAST OF THE SUMMIT OF MT. CABOT AND ON THE END OF A RIDGE JUST NORTH OF BUNNELL NOTCH.  THE STATION HAS FOUR STEEL LEGS AND A CABIN ON THE TOP.  TO REACH STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN JEFFERSON GO WEST ON U.S. HIGHWAY 2 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 2.2 MILES TO FORK.  TAKE RIGHT FORK ON GORE ROAD AND GO 1.2 MILE TO POINT WHERE ROAD TURNS LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO 0.5 MILE TO A ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.7 MILE ON PLEASANT VALLEY ROAD TO FORK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.4 MILE TO HOME OF MR. WHITE ON RIGHT AND A RED BARN ON THE LEFT.  FROM HERE TRAIL BEGINS UP ABANDONED RAILROAD BED.  FOLLOW TRAIL, ALWAYS KEEPING TRAIL TO LEFT, FOR ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES TO STATION.  A 2-1/2 HOUR PACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JJC) THE LOOKOUT TOWER WAS RECOVERED IN FAIR CONDITION.  THE TOWER HAS BEEN ABANDONED.  THE REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 OF STATION CABOT (USGS) WERE NOT RECOVERED THIS DATE.  THE LOOKOUT TOWER WAS CUT IN AS AN INTERSECTION STATION BY MR. J. CHILDS TRIANGULATION PARTY DURING THE SUMMER OF 1959.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 11 MILES SOUTHWEST OF TWIN MOUNTAIN, ABOUT 9 MILES NORTH OF NORTH WOODSTOCK AND ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF FRANCONIA ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF PROFILE MOUNTAIN. THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 30 INCHES.  THE MARK IS 11.3 FEET SOUTH OF A VERY LARGE ROCK OUTCROP, 20.2 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH WALL OF THE OBSERVATION PLATFORM AND 2.6 FEET FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH WALL OF THE OBSERVATION PLATFORM. THE MARK IS UNDERNEATH THE PLATFORM AND THE DISK IS STAMPED CANNON 2 1958.  TO REACH STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAYS 3 AND 302 AND STATE HIGHWAYS 10 AND 115 IN TWIN MOUNTAIN, GO WEST AND SOUTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 3 FOR 12.0 MILES TO THE AERIAL TRAMWAY AT FRANCONIA NOTCH AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  RIDE THE TRAMWAY TO THE TOP AND THEN PACK ALONG FOOTPATH TO THE OBSERVATION PLATFORM AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  ABOUT A 5 MINUTE PACK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 8.7 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF FOREST SERVICE LOOKOUT TOWER, 3.6 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND 0.9 FOOT WEST OF THE WEST EDGE OF A 5 X 9 FOOT BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILLHOLE IN A 5 X 9 FOOT BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET AND THE DISK IS STAMPED CANNON 2 NO 1 1958.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 30.2 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE OBSERVATION PLATFORM, 10.8 FEET SOUTH OF A SIGN POST AND 42 FEET WEST SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 20 INCHES AND THE DISK IS STAMPED CANNON 2 NO 2 1958.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 6 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (WMJ) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1959. THERE WAS NO SUITABLE PLACE FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  A DIFFERENCE IN DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS NOTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1988 (CGS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1988 (JBD) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1989)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1989 (DKS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2010)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2010 (KH) FOUND TRIANGULATION STATION DISK AND ITS TWO REFERENCE MARKS IN GOOD CONDITION. THE MAIN STATION IS UNDER THE OBSERVATION TOWER AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS CAN BE SEEN FROM THE OBSERVATION TOWER. THE OLD FOREST SERVICE LOOKOUT TOWER, MENTIONED IN THE LOG FROM 1959, WAS REMOVED IN THE FALL OF 2007. PHOTOS OF ALL MARKS (CLOSEUP AND AREA) ARE AVAILABLE ON GEOCACHING.COM.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 11 MILES SOUTHWEST OF TWIN MOUNTAIN AND ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF FRANCONIA ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF PROFILE MOUNTAIN.  STATION IS ABOUT 35 FEET TALL, CONSTRUCTED OF WOOD AND IS SUPPORTED BY FOUR LEGS.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE WHITE LIGHT ON THE ROOF OF THE TOWER WHICH IS JUST TO THE EAST OF CENTER OF THE ROOF.  TO REACH STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAYS 3 AND 302 AND STATE HIGHWAYS 10 AND 115 IN TWIN MOUNTAIN GO WEST AND SOUTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 3 FOR 12.0 MILES TO THE AERIAL TRAMWAY AT FRANCONIA NOTCH AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  RIDE THE TRAMWAY TO THE TOP AND THEN FOLLOW THE FOOTPATH FOR ABOUT 5 MINUTES TO THE SUMMIT AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (WMJ) THE STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1988 (JBD) MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1989)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1989 (DKS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2010)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2010 (KH) IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE STATION WAS DESTROYED. IT WAS THE WHITE LIGHT ON THE ROOF OF THE OLD CANNON MOUNTAIN FIRE LOOKOUT TOWER. THE TOWER WAS REMOVED IN THE FALL OF 2007. ONLY THE CONCRETE BLOCKS OF THE FOUR TOWER LEGS ARE REMAINING.

BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1874 (ETQ) LAND OWNED BY TAFT AND GREENLEAF.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART, MARKED BY BOLT AND TRIANGLE. SIGNAL IN CHARGE OF TAFT AND GREENLEAF, PROFILE HOUSE, FRANCONIA.  TO REACH THE STATION GO 1-1/2 MILES W FROM PROFILE HOUSE VIA PATH TO POINT NEAR THE CANNON, THEN 1 MILE SW VIA BURNED TIMBER TO TOP OF MOUNTAIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (2010)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2010 (KH) FOUND THE STATION IN A GOOD CONDITION. IT IS AN IRON BOLT SURROUNDED BY A CHISELED TRIANGLE IN A ROCK OUTCROP. STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF CANNON MOUNTAIN FORMERLY KNOWN AS PROFILE MOUNTAIN. TO REACH THE STATION RIDE THE CANNON MOUNTAIN AERIAL TRAMWAY TO ITS UPPER STATION. FROM THERE WALK THE RIM TRAIL TO THE OBSERVATION TOWER.   STATION IS WEST OF THE OBSERVATION TOWER AND 15 FEET WEST OF STATION PF0987. PHOTOS OF THE STATION (CLOSEUP AND AREA) ARE AVAILABLE ON GEOCACHING.COM.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW SURFACE STATION MARK AND TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS ABOUT 6-1/2 MILES WEST OF NEWFOUND LAKE, 5 MILES EAST OF CANAAN, AND IS ON THE SUMMIT OF MOUNT CARDIGAN. THE STATION MARK IS UNDER THE STATE FOREST SERVICE LOOKOUT TOWER AT THE APPROXIMATE CENTER AT BASE OF TOWER.  THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN IS FORMED BY SOLID ROCK.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 4 AND STATE HIGHWAY 118 IN CANAAN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 118 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AS PER SIGN MOUNT CARDIGAN-STATE FOREST, AND GO EASTERLY ON THE MAIN ROAD FOR 0.95 MILE TO THE ORANGE TOWN LINE.  CONTINUE ON THE MAIN ROAD FOR 1.7 MILES TO A ROAD FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING BRIDGE. TAKE RIGHT FORK, GO 0.75 MILE TO A ROAD FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK, GO 0.65 MILE TO A PICNIC AREA AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK EASTERLY ON THE WEST RIDGE TRAIL, A WELL MARKED TRAIL, FOR 1.3 MILES TO SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  ABOUT A 1 HOUR PACK.  THE ORIGINAL STATION MARK IS AN IRON PIN LEADED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE BEDROCK AND IS ABOUT 2 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE ROCK.  THE MARK WAS HELD INTACT AND A NEW SURFACE MARK WAS SET WHICH IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CARDIGAN 1873 1958, CEMENTED IN THE OLD HOLE FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE ROCK.  IT IS 11.3 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 11.9 FEET WEST OF THE EAST LEG OF TOWER, 9.6 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH LEG, AND 9 FEET EAST OF THE WEST LEG OF TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CARDIGAN NO 1 1873 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  IT IS 46 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE MOST NORTHERLY LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER AND 21.6 FEET EAST OF THE GUY WIRE ANCHOR PIN FOR THE SOUTH LEG.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CARDIGAN NO 2 1873 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  IT IS 28 FEET WEST OF THE MOST WESTERLY LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, AND 17 FEET SOUTH OF THE GUY WIRE ANCHOR PIN FOR THE WEST LEG OF TOWER.  OBSERVATIONS MADE FROM A 6 FT. STAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1978 (GEL) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DIRECTIONS TO REFERENCE MARKS AND THE DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK 1 COMPARED FAVORABLY WITH THE 1958 DATA.  THE DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS OBSERVED TO BE 0.019 METER LESS THAN THE 1958 DATA.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 6-1/2 MILES WEST OF NEWFOUND LAKE, 5-1/2 MILES EAST OF CANAAN, AND IS ON THE SUMMIT OF MOUNT CARDIGAN.  THE STATION MARK IS DIRECTLY UNDER THE STATE FOREST SERVICE LOOKOUT TOWER AT THE APPROXIMATE CENTER AT THE BASE OF THE TOWER.  THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN IS FORMED BY SOLID ROCK.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 4 AND STATE HIGHWAY 118 IN CANAAN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 118 FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AS PER SIGN (CARDIGAN STATE PARK 5 MILES) AND FOLLOW MAIN ROAD EASTERLY FOR 2.6 MILES TO TWO ROADS LEFT JUST AFTER CROSSING SMALL BRIDGE.  KEEP RIGHT AHEAD FOR 1.35 MILES TO A PARKING AREA.  CONTINUE EASTERLY ON TRACK ROAD WITH FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE JEEP (OR 1-1/2 HOUR PACK) FOR 1.7 MILES TO THE SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CARDIGAN 1873 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK IN THE CENTER OF AN EIGHT-INCH TRIANGLE ETCHED IN THE ROCK.  THE DISK IS AT THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE TOWER OVERHEAD, 11.3 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 11.9 FEET WEST OF THE EAST LEG OF TOWER, 9.6 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH LEG, AND 9.2 FEET EAST OF THE WEST LEG OF TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CARDIGAN NO 1 1873 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  IT IS 46 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE MOST NORTHEAST LEG OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND 21.6 FEET EAST OF THE GUY WIRE ANCHOR PIN FOR THE SOUTH LEG.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED CARDIGAN NO 2 1873 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  IT IS 28 FEET WEST OF THE MOST WESTERLY LEG OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND 17 FEET SOUTH OF THE GUY WIRE ANCHOR PIN FOR THE WEST LEG OF THE TOWER.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5-1/2 MILES EAST OF CANAAN.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 3.3 FEET.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1959 (JCC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 21 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LITTLETON, 9 MILES WEST OF BARTLETT AND AT THE MOUNT CARRIGAIN LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD USGS DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES AT THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF BASE OF LOOKOUT TOWER AND IS STAMPED CARRIGAIN 2 1943.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE BASE OF STEPS OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD USGS DISK THAT IS ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK AND IS STAMPED NO 1 1943.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS 27.5 FEET NORTH NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 23.8 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 10.8 FEET WEST OF A TELEPHONE POLE AND IS ABOUT 2 FEET HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD USGS DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET AND IS STAMPED NO 2 1943.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE RAILROAD CROSSING IN BARTLETT, GO WEST ON US HIGHWAY 302 FOR 3.45 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  (THIS IS JUST AFTER CROSSING BRIDGE WITH A LOW STEEL QUARD RAILING.) TURN LEFT ON GRAVEL ROAD AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY FOR 2.05 MILES TO A DIM TRACK ROAD ON RIGHT AND SIGN SIGNAL RIDGE TRAIL MT. CARRIGAIN 4.5 MILES AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  (THIS IS JUST BEFORE REACHING WHITEFACE BROOK BRIDGE.) FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOLLOW DIM TRACK ROAD NORTHWESTERLY FOR ABOUT 2.0 MILES TO FORK AND SIGN CARRIGAIN NOTCH TRAIL LEADING TO THE RIGHT AND SIGN SIGNAL RIDGE TRAIL LEADING TO THE LEFT.  TAKE LEFT TRAIL AND GO ABOUT 0.3 MILE TO AN OLD ABANDONED CCC CAMP, AFTER PASSING CAMP THE TRAIL BEARS LEFT UP HILL, FOLLOW MAIN TRAIL FOR ABOUT 2.0 MILES TO TOP OF RIDGE, FOLLOW TOP OF RIDGE FOR ABOUT 0.3 MILE TO AN OLD CABIN AT THE FOOT OF MOUNTAIN JUST BEFORE REACHING LOOKOUT TOWER, BEAR LEFT AT CABIN FOLLOWING MOUNTAIN TRAIL UP RIDGE FOR ABOUT 0.15 MILE TO LOOKOUT TOWER AND STATION.  THIS IS ABOUT A 4 HOUR PACK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (RG) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.   REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS NOT FOUND, PRESUMED DESTROYED.  THE TOWER WAS REBUILT IN THE EARLY 1980S AND THE OLD CONCRETE BASE OF THE STEPS IS GONE.   REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS NOT FOUND, PRESUMED DESTROYED.  THE BOULDER ON WHICH IS WAS MOUNTED WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED AND AN OLD CEMENT SMEAR WITH A HOLE IN ITS CENTER WAS FOUND ON THE BOULDER. PRESUMABLY THIS WAS THE LOCATION OF THE MISSING REFERENCE MARK.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) GO FROM PITTSFIELD VILLAGE TO HOUSE OF WM. T. BATCHELDER ON SE SIDE OF MOUNTAIN, THENCE THE WAY IS DIRECT AND PLAIN TO THE TOP. THE TOP IS BARE AND A SOMEWHAT LONG RIDGE.  STATION IS ON HIGHEST PART AND MARKED BY BOLT AND TRIANGLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1933)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1933 (HSS) STATION IS ON THE SOUTHWESTERN SUMMIT OF CATAMOUNT MOUNTAIN, WHICH IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES SE OF THE TOWN OF PITTSFIELD.  THE LOCALITY IS WELL SHOWN ON THE U.S.G.S. GILMANTON SHEET.  THE BEST APPROACH IS FROM THE S SIDE, WHERE A FAIRLY GOOD TRAIL LEADS NEARLY TO THE SUMMIT, THROUGH AN OPEN PASTURE AND SOME WOODLAND.  THERE ARE SEVERAL BARE LEDGES ON THE SUMMIT AND THE STATION IS ON ONE OF THESE. ABOUT 124 FEET SSW OF THE STATION IS A PROMINENT CAIRN, BUILT OF FLAT STONES AND MORE OR LESS SQUARE IN CROSS-SECTION, AND A SIMILAR CAIRN IS ABOUT 192 FEET NNE OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY AN 8-INCH TRIANGLE, IN THE CENTER OF WHICH IS A DRILL HOLE WITH A METAL BOLT ADJACENT TO IT.  THE HEAD OF THE BOLT IS ROUGH AND IRREGULAR, AND IT IS ABOUT 1/2 INCH W OF THE DRILL HOLE.  I FOUND NEAR THE STATION SEVERAL DRILL HOLES (SOME OF THEM SHALLOW), LOCATED ABOUT AS FOLLOWS, THE DISTANCES BEING IN FEET FROM THE DRILL HOLE--13.13, S 30 DEG W.  13.30, S 31 DEG W.  3.50, S 55 DEG W.  4.90, S 62 DEG W.  5.77, S 62 DEG W.  4.89, S 83 DEG W. 0.60, N 75 DEG W.  1.22, N 75 DEG W.  7.07, N 3 DEG E.  1.02, N 75 DEG E.  IN THE ABSENCE OF AN INSTRUMENT THESE AZIMUTHS (0 DEG S) WERE DETERMINED ONLY VERY ROUGHLY, BY SKETCHING ON A SMALL PIECE OF CARDBOARD, AND THEY MAY BE MUCH IN ERROR.  THE HOLES MIGHT SERVE AS REFERENCE MARKS IN FINDING THE STATION OR IN REPLACING IT, IF IT SHOULD BE DESTROYED, SO I HAVE GIVEN THEIR POSITIONS AS WELL AS POSSIBLE UNDER THE CIRCUMSTANCES.  THE VIEW IS OPEN FROM ABOUT NE THROUGH S TO SW AND IS OBSTRUCTED BY TREES IN OTHER DIRECTIONS, ALTHOUGH LINES COULD EASILY BE OPENED.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1955 1.6 MI SE FROM PLYMOUTH. ABOUT 1.55 MILES SOUTHEAST ALONG THE BOSTON AND MAINE RAILROAD FROM THE STATION AT PLYMOUTH, IN THE TOP OF BRIDGE SEAT OF NORTH ABUTMENT OF RAILROAD BRIDGE NO. 49/75, ABOUT 0.25 MILE SOUTH OF MILE POST G 97 - C 50, 5 FEET WEST OF WEST RAIL, 5 FEET EAST OF WEST END OF BRIDGE SEAT AND ABOUT 3 1/2 FEET BELOW LEVEL OF TRACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1990)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1990 (MG) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES NORTH OF TWIN MOUNTAIN. ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF WHITEFIELD.  ON PROPERTY OF MR. LEE MERRILL.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE OF A LARGE BOULDER.  PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES.  STAMPED CHERRY 1959.  IT IS 26.9 FEET EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF STATE ROUTE 115.  9.0 FEET SOUTH OF A METAL WITNESS POST. 7.6 FEET EAST-SOUTHEAST OF A FENCE LINE.  ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE ELEVATION OF THE HIGHWAY.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 6 FT X 3 FT BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET. THE DISK IS STAMPED CHERRY R.M. 1 1959.  IT IS ABOUT 6 FEET ABOVE STATION ELEVATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 5 FT X 3 FT BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET.  THE DISK IS STAMPED CHERRY R.M. 2 1959.  IT IS 35.6 FEET EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF STATE ROUTE 115. 56.4 FEET NORTHEAST OF TOWNSHIP LINE.  15.0 FEET EAST-SOUTHEAST OF FENCE LINE.  ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE STATION ELEVATION.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAYS 3 AND 302 IN TWIN MOUNTAIN.  GO NORTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 3 FOR 1.9 MILES TO STATE ROUTE 115.  TURN RIGHT ON STATE ROUTE 115 FOR 3.5 MILES TO STATION ON RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1875 (ETQ) TO REACH THE MOUNTAIN GO TO HOUSE OF CHAS. CARTER 4 MILES NW OF TWIN MOUNTAIN HOUSE ON ROAD TO WAMBACH.  THENCE TAKE PATH AND GO NE TO TOP.  LAND OWNED BY NO MAN.  TOP IS WOODED.  SIGNAL IS A SPRUCE TREE.
PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.
BY DBA SYSTEMS INCORPORATED 1974 (WEH) DESTROYED.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (GWL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1/2 MILE EAST OF BRATTLEBORO, VERMONT, ON THE WEST EDGE OF AND NEAR THE CENTRAL PORTION OF MANTASTIQUET MOUNTAIN AND OVERLOOKING THE CONNECTICUT RIVER WHICH IS THE NEW HAMPSHIRE BOUNDARY LINE.  IT IS ON LAND OWNED BY THE STATE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE, ON A BARE ROCK AND 15.68 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE MEMORIAL MONUMENT BUILT TO THE MEMORY OF WALTER H. CHILDS.  THE DISK IS STAMPED CHILDS 1942.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS IN THE SOLID ROCK OF THE HILL TOP NORTHEAST OF THE STATION.  IT IS STAMPED CHILDS NO 1 1942.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS IN SOLID ROCK EAST OF THE STATION. IT IS STAMPED CHILDS NO 2 1942.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE TO THE WALTER H. CHILDS MEMORIAL MONUMENT.  IT IS A GRANITE PILLAR ABOUT 1-1/2 FEET SQUARE AT THE BASE AND ABOUT 4 FEET HIGH.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS AN OLD MARK OF THE COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY, PROBABLY A MAGNETIC STATION, AND IS LOCATED IN THE DEDE STOLTE MEMORIAL ATHLETIC FIELD AT THE SOUTH EDGE OF BRATTLEBORO.  IT IS MARKED BY A SHALLOW BRONZE CUP WITH THE LETTERS U.S.C. AND G.S. AND IS SET AT THE TOP OF A 10 INCH CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE. IT IS LOCATED AT THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE FOOTBALL GRIDIRON, ABOUT 15 FEET EAST OF THE EAST END OF THE SOUTH BLEACHERS AND 2 FEET NORTH OF THE FENCE ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE FOOTBALL FIELD.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE RAILROAD DEPOT IN BRATTLEBORO GO EAST ACROSS THE CONNECTICUT RIVER BRIDGE.  AFTER CROSSING THE BRIDGE TAKE THE FIRST ROAD LEFT AND GO 0.15 MILE TO A GRANITE GATE POST ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. FROM HERE FOLLOW TRAIL (OLD ROAD) THAT ZIG ZAGS UP THE HILL TO THE MONUMENT AND THE STATION AS DESCRIBED.  ABOUT A 1 HOUR PACK.  A 4 FOOT STAND WILL SEE A 4 FOOT LIGHT AT HALIFAX 1878.  A 4 FOOT STAND WILL SEE A 4 FOOT LIGHT AT TT 7FI (USGS).  A 4 FOOT STAND WILL SEE A 4 FOOT LIGHT AT PUTNEY (USGS).  A 4 FOOT STAND WILL SEE A 4 FOOT LIGHT AT PUTNEY SCHOOL.  A 4 FOOT STAND WILL SEE A 74 FOOT LIGHT AT HANNUM.  A 4 FOOT STAND WILL SEE A 87 FOOT LIGHT AT NORTH POND.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 2 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1954 STATION MARK IS MISSING, HOLE REMAINS IN LEDGE WHERE IT WAS SET. REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 ARE STILL IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY VT DEPT OF HIGHWAYS 1961 (LMC) STATION WAS FOUND DESTROYED.  DRILL HOLE FOUND AND TWO REFERENCE MARKERS.  THESE ARE STILL GOOD ALTHOUGH SIGNS OF TAMPERING ARE EVIDENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (WFD) REFERENCE MARKS NUMBERS 1 AND 2 AND THE AZIMUTH MARK WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION, ESSENTIALLY AS DESCRIBED.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS SET IN A GRANITE RATHER THAN A CONCRETE MONUMENT. THE COUNTERSUNK HOLE WHERE THE STATION MARK HAD BEEN SET IN BEDROCK WAS RECOVERED, BUT THE MARK HAD BEEN LIFTED OR PRIED OUT.  THE HOLE WAS SLIGHTLY DEEPENED AND MORE DEEPLY COUNTERSUNK AND A NEW DISK SET IN THE SAME SPOT, STAMPED CHILDS 1942, THE SAME AS THE ORIGINAL.  HORIZONTAL DISTANCE TO R.M. 1 DID NOT CHECK, IT WAS REMEASURED TWICE.  CHILDS MEMORIAL MONUMENT IS DRESSED GRANITE, 1.5 X 1.5 3.0 FEET WITH A PYRAMIDAL TOP, BONDED TO THE ROCK OUTCROP.  A BRONZE PLAQUE IS SET IN THE SOUTHWEST FACE, IN MEMORY OF WALTER H. CHILDS, ERECTED 1906.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (WD) THE STATION WAS FOUND IN VERY POOR CONDITION.  THE DISK HAS BEEN REMOVED AND ONLY THE STEM REMAINS PROJECTING FROM THE ROCK OUTCROPPING.  FOUND REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IN GOOD CONDITION.  FOUND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IN VERY POOR CONDITION.  ALL BUT THE CENTER-MOST ONE INCH OF THE DISK HAS BEEN REMOVED.  FOUND THE CHILDS MEMORIAL MONUMENT, MZ1891, IN GOOD CONDITION.  DID NO SEARCH FOR THE AZIMUTH MARK.  TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF US HIGHWAY 5 AND STATE HIGHWAY 119 IN DOWNTOWN BRATTLEBORO, NH, GO EAST ON STATE HIGHWAY ACROSS TWO BRIDGES OVER THE CONNECTICUT RIVER FOR 0.4 MILES TO MOUNTAIN ROAD LEADING NORTH.  MOUNTAIN ROAD IS ABOUT 100 YARDS SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST END OF THE MORE EASTERLY OF THE TWO BRIDGES.  GO NORTH ON MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR ABOUT 0.20 MILES TO A PARKING AREA FOR THE WANTASTIQUET STATE NATURAL AREA ON THE RIGHT.  FROM THE PARKING AREA, PACK UPHILL ON THE MORE EASTERLY OF TWO TRAILS LEADING NORTH.  THE TRAIL IS VERY ROUGH AND STEEP IN PLACES, AND IS NOT PASSABLE BY FOUR WHEEL DRIVE OVER MUCH OF ITS LENGTH.  FOLLOW THE TRAIL FOR 1.90 MILES AND 1,000 FEET ELEVATION GAIN TO THE STATION AND THE MONUMENT ON THE RIGHT IN A ROCK OUTCROPPING OVERLOOKING BRATTLEBORO.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 SEE STATION CHILDS                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (WD) THE MONUMENT IS AN 18-INCH BY 18-INCH GRANITE SHAFT WITH A PYRAMIDAL TOP THAT PROJECTS 40 INCHES.  IT HAS BEEN SPRAY PAINTED IN A BLACK AND WHITE CHECKERBOARD PATTERN AND HAS BEEN VANDALIZED WITH NUMEROUS SPRAY PAINTED GRAFFITI, BUT OTHERWISE IS IN GOOD AND STABLE CONDITION.  SEE STATION CHILDS (MZ1890) FOR TO REACH INSTRUCTIONS.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (GBB) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, IN GOOD CONDITION.  THIS STATION IS LISTED AS CHOCORUA MOUNTAIN IN THE DESCRIPTIONS AND AS CHOCORUA IN THE POSITION LIST.  THE STATION WAS AN IRON BOLT WITHIN A CHISELED TRIANGLE ON MIDDLE OF HIGHEST ROCK ON SUMMIT.  IT WAS RE-MARKED JUNE 29, 1943 WITH A STANDARD TABLET STAMPED MOUNT CHOCORUA 1876 1943, CENTERED EXACTLY OVER THE OLD HOLE.  A 2-INCH STEEL PIPE ABOUT 4 FEET HIGH SUPPORTS A 1-1/2-FOOT SQUARE SHEET STEEL TABLE 10 INCHES W OF STATION.  THIS TABLE INTERFERES WITH CENTERING INSTRUMENT OVER STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS TWO IRON BOLTS SET TOGETHER AT E EDGE OF SUMMIT AND 21.80 FEET FROM STATION N 72 DEG 17 MIN E.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A 1-INCH DRILL HOLE BESIDE AN OLD METAL BOLT IN ROCK LEDGE SW OF STATION, AND ABOUT 9 FEET BELOW SUMMIT. IT IS 27.15 FEET DISTANT FROM STATION S 38 DEG 37 MIN W.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A PAIR OF OLD IRON BOLTS NEAR TOP IN VERTICAL FACE OF ROCK LEDGE, ABOUT 10 FEET FROM W ESCARPMENT OF MAIN TOP, ABOUT 3 FEET BELOW SUMMIT, AND 15.30 FEET FROM STATION N 86 DEG 01 MIN W.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FOREST SERVICE 1959 (FSB) RECOVERED STATION AS DESCRIBED.  THE MOST WELL-KNOWN ROUTE IS VIA THE PIPER TRAIL ALTHOUGH THE CHAMNEY FALLS TRAIL, WHICH TAKES OFF FROM THE KANGAMACUS HIGHWAY, IS SHORTER AND EASIER. THE STATION MARK WAS REPLACED IN 1943 BY A STANDARD USGS BRONZE TABLET.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (DKA) THE DISK HAS BEEN MUTILATED AS TO BE UNREADABLE. YOU CAN SEE A FEW OF THE LETTERS BUT NOT ENOUGH TO READ THE PID.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1986 (REP) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 14.5 KM (9.0 MI) WEST OF NEWPORT, 3.2 KM (2.0 MI) EAST OF THE CONNECTICUT RIVER, WHICH IS THE STATE LINE, 2.4 KM (1.5 MI) SOUTHWEST OF CLAREMONT AND AT THE CLAREMONT MUNICIPAL AIRPORT.  OWNERSHIP--TOWN OF CLAREMONT, C/O ROD FRYMAN, RFD 2 BOX 666, CLAREMONT NH 03743, PHONE 603-543-0039 OR 542-9796.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 91 AND STATE HIGHWAY 131 IN ASCUTNEY, VERMONT.  GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 131 FOR 0.7 KM (0.45 MI) TO THE INTERSECTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 131, 12 AND U.S. HIGHWAY 5, CONTINUE EAST ON HIGHWAY 12 INTO NEW HAMPSHIRE FOR 2.3 KM (1.4 MI) TO A HIGH RAILROAD BRIDGE, CONTINUE AHEAD ON THE HIGHWAY FOR 0.9 KM (0.55 MI) TO A CROSS STREET, PLAINS ROAD, ON THE RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ON PLAINS ROAD FOR 0.3 KM (0.2 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND A FORK LEFT, OLD CHURCH ROAD, CONTINUE AHEAD, SOUTH ON PLAINS ROAD FOR 1.8 KM (1.1 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, AIRPORT ROAD. TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 0.4 KM (0.25 MI) TO A ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHEAST ONTO THE AIRPORT FOR 60 METERS (200 FT) TO THE AIRPORT OFFICE ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD ONTO THE TARMAC, THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ACROSS THE TARMAC RAMP AND ACROSS THE RUNWAY FOR 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) TO THE STATION AT THE WINDSOCK.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---CLARE 1986---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 30 CM IN DIAMETER PROJECTING 4 CM ABOVE GROUND.  LOCATED 85.0 METERS (279 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF RUNWAY 11-29, 84.7 METERS (278 FT) NORTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF RUNWAY 5-23, 13.20 METERS (43.3 FT) NORTHEAST FROM THE WINDSOCK POLE, 10.90 METERS (35.8 FT) SOUTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF A 1 METER SQUARE DRAIN GRATE AND 0.71 METERS (2.3 FT) NORTH OF A WOODEN WITNESS POST.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---CLARE 1986---, SET INTO AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 1.2 METERS BELOW THE SURFACE.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD NGS REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED ---CLARE AZI 1986---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 30 CM IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH GROUND.  LOCATED 61.3 METERS (201 FT) WEST-SOUTHWEST FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF RUNWAY, 23.5 METERS (77 FT) SOUTH FROM THE CENTER OF THE RUNWAY, 6.51 METERS (21.4 FT) NORTH FROM THE NORTHEAST LEG OF A VASI LIGHT AND 0.70 METERS (2.3 FT) EAST FROM A WOODEN WITNESS POST.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH FROM THE STATION, GO EAST FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF RUNWAY 11-29 AND CROSSING RUNWAY 5-23 TO THE MARK.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS A STANDARD NGS REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED ---CLARE AZI 1986---, SET INTO AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 1.2 METERS BELOW THE SURFACE.  FAA AIRPORT SURVEYS, NEW ENGLAND, SEPTEMBER-OCTOBER 1986.  THIS STATION IS SUITABLE FOR GPS SURVEYS.  DESCRIBED BY R.T. WOODRUFF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1986)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1986 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1992)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1992 STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 14.5 KM (9.00 MI) WEST OF NEWPORT, 3.2 KM (2.00 MI) EAST OF THE CONNECTICUT RIVER WHICH IS THE STATE LINE, 2.4 KM (1.50 MI) SOUTHWEST OF CLAREMONT AND AT THE CLAREMONT MUNICIPAL AIRPORT.  OWNERSHIP--TOWN OF CLAREMONT, CITY HALL, CLAREMONT NH 03743, MANAGER FRANK LOEFFLER, PHONE-603-542-8530.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 91 AND STATE ROUTE 131 IN ASCUTNEY VT, GO EAST FOR 0.8 KM (0.50 MI) ALONG STATE ROUTE 131 TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE ROUTES 131, 12 AND U.S. HIGHWAY 5.  CONTINUE EAST ALONG HIGHWAY 12 INTO NEW HAMPSHIRE FOR 2.4 KM (1.50 MI) TO A RAILROAD BRIDGE OVERHEAD.  CONTINUE AHEAD ON HIGHWAY 12 (ALSO 103 EAST) FOR 1 KM (0.60 MI) TO A CROSS STREET RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.16 KM (0.10 MI) TO BRIDGE OVER WASTE WATER FACILITY. CONTINUE SOUTH ON PLAINS ROAD FOR 0.16 KM (0.10 MI) TO FORK IN ROAD. TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTH ON PLAINS ROAD FOR 1.9 KM (1.20 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK.  CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 0.32 KM (0.20 MI) TO A ROAD LEFT. TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 0.5 KM (0.30 MI) ON SULLIVAN ROAD TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT ONTO AIRPORT GROUNDS AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 60 M (196.8 FT) TO AIRPORT OFFICE ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD AND GO EAST ON TARMAC, THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH ACROSS RUNWAY FOR 0.32 KM (0.20 MI) TO THE STATION AT THE WINDSOCK.  THE STATION IS 85 M (278.9 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE RUNWAY, 84.7 M (277.9 FT) NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF RUNWAY 5-23, 13.2 M (43.3 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE WINDSOCK POLE, 10.9 M (35.8 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF A 1 M (3.3 FT) SQUARE DRAIN GRATE AND 0.71 M (2.33 FT) NORTH OF A WOODEN WITNESS POST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1994)  RECOVERY NOTE BY VERMONT AGENCY OF TRANSPORTATION 1994 (MC) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1994)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1994 (JMR) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1998)  RECOVERY NOTE BY WOOLPERT CONSULTANTS 1998 (BBS) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, WOOLPERT LLP 1998 (ARL).  NOTE THAT A GATE WITH AN ELECTRONIC KEYPAD SYSTEM HAS BEEN INSTALLED.  CONTACT THE AIRPORT MANAGER FOR ENTRY.  THIS STATION IS DESIGNATED AS THE PRIMARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2000)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2000 (CSM) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 91 AND STATE HIGHWAY 131 IN ASCUTNEY, VERMONT.  GO EAST ON HIGHWAY 131 FOR 0.7 KM (0.45 MI) TO THE INTERSECTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 131,12 AND U.S. HIGHWAY 5, CONTINUE EAST ON HIGHWAY 12 INTO NEW HAMPSHIRE FOR 2.3 KM 1.4 MI TO A HIGH RAILROAD BRIDGE, CONTINUE AHEAD ON THE HIGHWAY FOR 0.9 KM (0.55 MI) TO A CROSS STREET, PLAINS ROAD ON THE RIGHT. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE STATE ROUTE 1-B BRIDGE OVER LITTLE HARBOR AT THE NEW CASTLE-RYE TOWN LINE, AND ABOUT 1.77 KM (1.10 MI) NORTHEAST OF THE ROUTE 1-A AND 1-B JUNCTION, GO NORTHEAST ALONG ROUTE 1-B FOR 1.9 KM (1.20 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF A ROAD TO THE RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST ALONG ROAD FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO ENTRANCE ROAD TO FORT CONSTITUTION AND THE NEW CASTLE COAST GUARD STATION ON THE RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 0.24 KM (0.15 MI) TO THE COAST GUARD ADMINISTRATION BUILDING AND A PAVED PARKING AREA, HELIPORT AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT NEAR THE EDGE OF THE OCEAN. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS ABOUT 5 MILES NORTH OF CONWAY AND ABOUT 2 MILES SOUTH OF NORTH CONWAY ALONG U.S. HIGHWAY 302 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16, AT THE WHITE MOUNTAIN AIRPORT, AND IS ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. WILEY APT, OWNER AND MANAGER OF AIRPORT.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN NORTH CONWAY, GO SOUTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 302 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16 FOR 2.2 MILES TO THE WHITE MOUNTAIN AIRPORT ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW A TRACK ROAD ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE OF AIRFIELD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A WIND-T AND THE STATION. TO REACH CONWAY AZIMUTH CONTINUE EASTERLY ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO THE EAST END OF FIELD AND THE STATION.  STATION MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS STAMPED CONWAY 1958.  THE SURFACE DISK IS SET IN A SQUARE CONCRETE POST FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 36 FEET SOUTHWEST OF WIND-T, 11.6 FEET SOUTHWEST OF WIND SOCK AND 15 FEET NORTH OF THE TRACK ROAD.  THE UNDERGROUND DISK IS SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 48 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CONWAY NO 1 1958, IS SET IN A ROUND CONCRETE POST FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND. IT IS 55 FEET NORTH OF THE TRACK ROAD AND 36 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE WIND-T.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CONWAY NO 2 1958, IS SET IN A ROUND CONCRETE POST FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND. IT IS 31.5 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE WIND-T AND 12 FEET NORTH OF THE TRACK ROAD.  CONWAY AZIMUTH IS THE AZIMUTH MARK FOR THIS STATION.  AZIMUTH MARK IS A STANDARD STATION DISK STAMPED CONWAY AZIMUTH 1958, SET IN A SQUARE CONCRETE POST FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 51 FEET WEST OF A TRIANGULAR BLAZE ON A BIRCH TREE.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE TO TRIANGULATION STATION CONWAY AZIMUTH, DISTANCE BEING 632.178 METERS (2,074.07 FEET) EAST OF STATION CONWAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1980 (KA) NO MARK, MARK MUST HAVE BEEN MOVED OR BURIED DURING MODERNIZING OF AIR PORT.  TALKED WITH AIRPORT MANAGER.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5 MILES NORTH OF CONWAY, 2 MILES SOUTH OF N. CONWAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1981)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1981 (CLN) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1, 2 AND CONWAY AZIMUTH 1958 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS BADLY CHIPPED BUT IS STILL SOLID.  THE DIRECTION TO THE MARK CHECKED BUT A LONGER DISTANCE OF 0.03 FOOT (0.91 CM) WAS NOTED TO THE MARK.  A SHORTER DISTANCE OF 0.05 FOOT (1.52 CM) AND A HIGHER DIRECTION OF 3 MINUTES WAS NOTED TO REFERENCE MARK 1.  THE MARKS MAY HAVE BEEN HIT BY EQUIPMENT DURING CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW ROAD.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8.0 KM (4.95 MI) NORTH OF CONWAY, 3.2 KM (2.00 MI) SOUTH OF NORTH CONWAY AND IN A CLEARED LOT BEHIND THE MT WASHINGTON VALLEY MOTOR COURT.  IT IS JUST SOUTH OF THE WHITE MOUNTAIN AIRPORT. OWNERSHIP--WHITE MOUNTAIN AIRPORT, NORTH CONWAY, NEW HAMPSHIRE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN NORTH CONWAY, GO SOUTH ON U.S.  HIGHWAY 302 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16 FOR 3.5 KM (2.15 MI) TO A PAVED ROAD ON THE LEFT, JUST PAST THE AIRPORT AND BEFORE REACHING THE MOTOR COURT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.10 MI) TO A FIRE HYDRANT AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  SET INTO THE TOP OF A SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT, 12 INCHES, 30 CM IN DIAMETER, RECESSED 2 INCHES, 5 CM ABOVE THE GROUND. LOCATED 17.7 METERS (58.1 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHEAST FROM A FIRE HYDRANT, 17.7 METERS (58.1 FT) SOUTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF PAVED ROAD AND 0.5 METER (1.6 FT) WEST FROM A METAL WITNESS POST.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (JKS) THE MAIN MARK WAS RECOVERED DUE TO THE WITNESS POST AND GOOD CO-ORDINATES. THE MAIN MARK IS IN GOOD CONDITION. THE RM'S WERE NOT FOUND ON A RANDOM SEARCH. THE REFERENCED ITEMS TO THE RM'S SUCH AS THE WIND-SOCK, FIRE HYDRANT AND ACCESS ROAD NO LONGER EXIST. THIS AIRPORT NO LONGER EXISTS AND THE AREA IS A LARGE MALL. THE RM'S MAY STILL EXIST BUT WERE NOT RECOVERED.

IT IS 30 FEET NORTHWEST OF A TRIANGULAR BLAZED BIRCH TREE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED CONWAY AZIMUTH NO 2 1958, IS SET IN A SQUARE CONCRETE POST WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND. BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF HENNIKER.  THE TOP OF HILL IS STONY.  STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT, WHERE THE LEDGE IS FULL OF SEAMS AND EASILY BROKEN.  STATION IS MARKED BY A HOLE IN ROCK.  AROUND THE HOLE IS DRILLED A TRIANGLE, THE W SIDE OF WHICH POINTS N AND S.  TO THE N, 12-1/2 FEET DISTANT, IS A DRILLED ARROWHEAD POINTING TO THE STATION.  LAND IS OWNED BY MR. HARVEY C. CHASE, OF HENNIKER.  TO REACH THE TOP, GO TO MR. H.C. CHASES, ON E SIDE, 1/4 OF A MILE FROM SUMMIT, AND IT IS POSSIBLE TO DRIVE ALMOST ALL THE WAY UP.

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) ASCENT BEST FROM HOUSE OF MR. ELIAS WILSON, ON N SIDE OF MR. WILSONS HOUSE, ABOUT 3/4 MILE FROM SUMMIT.  A ROUGH ROAD LEADS THROUGH THE WOODS PART OF THE WAY.  REST OF ASCENT THROUGH PASTURES.  THE TOP IS LEDGE.  THE MOUNTAIN MAY BE REACHED VIA HILLSBORO BRIDGE ON THE CONCORD AND CLAREMONT RAILROAD.  OR VIA PARKERS STATION ON THE MANCHESTER AND NORTH WEARE RAILROAD, TAKING THE ROAD THROUGH FRANCESTOWN.  DISTANCE OF MR. WILSONS FROM HILLSBORO BRIDGE ABOUT 8-1/2 MILES, AND FROM FRANCESTOWN ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES.  THE TOP FORMATION IS 3 RIDGES OF ROCK RUNNING ABOUT N AND S, SEPARATED BY 50 OR 60 FEET.  THE STATION IS ON THE E ONE.  IT IS MARKED BY A HOLE DRILLED AT HIGHEST POINT.  THREE OTHER HOLES FOR THE TRIPOD FEET OF AN INSTRUMENT ARE DRILLED ABOUT THE STATION MARK.  LAND OWNED BY MR. ELIAS WILSON, IN WHOSE CARE THE SIGNAL IS LEFT.  ADRESS--FRANCESTOWN, NEW HAMPSHIRE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JHW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS NOW MARKED WITH U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND STATE SURVEY BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN THE ORIGINAL DRILLHOLE, AND IS ABOUT 75 FEET SOUTH, SOUTHEAST OF A STATE FOREST LOOKOUT TOWER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 136 AND A PAVED ROAD NORTHWEST IN FRANCESTOWN, GO NORTHWEST ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 2.6 MILES TO A GRAVEL ROAD LEFT AND SIGN HOB-NOB FARIS.  TURN LEFT ON GRAVEL ROAD AND GO WEST FOR 1.0 MILE TO A DRIVEWAY LEFT OPPOSITE A GROUP OF FARM BUILDINGS.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW DRIVEWAY SOUTH FOR 0.5 MILE TO THE EDGE OF WOODS AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE FOLLOW WELL MARKED TRAIL NORTHWEST TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 20 MILES WEST OF MANCHESTER, 22 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CONCORD, 3 MILES WEST OF FRANCESTOWN AND ON THE EAST EDGE OF CROTCHET MOUNTAIN.  IT IS 101 FEET EAST SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTH LEG OF CROTCHET MOUNTAIN LOOKOUT TOWER AND 74 FEET EAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF CABIN.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD USGS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 5 FEET WITH NO STAMPING ON DISK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN FRANCESTOWN, GO NORTHWEST ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.65 MILE TO FORK, KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 1.7 MILES TO FORK, TAKE LEFT FORK ON GRAVEL ROAD AND GO WESTERLY FOR 0.6 TO FORK, KEEP LEFT FORK AND CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON GRAVEL ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT ON TRACK ROAD AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.1 MILE TO GATE, PASS THROUGH GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTHERLY THROUGH FIELD ON TRACK ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOLLOW FOOT TRAIL UP MOUNTAIN FOR ABOUT 1 HOUR OF WALKING TO TOP OF MOUNTAIN AND STATION AT LOOKOUT TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 82 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF CABIN AND 8 FEET NORTH OF TRAIL LEADING TO CABIN. THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET AND IS STAMPED CROTCHET NO 1 1871 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 57.8 FEET EAST SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTH LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 31 FEET EAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF CABIN AND 6.2 FEET WEST SOUTHWEST OF A GUY WIRE EYE BOLT THAT IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET AND IS STAMPED CROTCHET NO 2 1871 1959.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) THIS PEAK IS THE SOUTHERN AND HIGHEST PART OF A RANGE RUNNING IN THE GENERAL N AND S DIRECTION AND CALLED THE GRANTHAM RANGE AS MOST OF IT LIES IN THE TOWN OF GRANTHAM.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A BOLT IN THE ROCK ON THE HIGHEST POINT.  TO REACH, TO GO UP ON THE E SIDE, GO TO THE HOUSE OF JOHN BARTON. THE ASCENT FROM HERE IS VERY STEEP.  IT IS NO DOUBT EASIER OF ASCENT ON THE W SIDE.

markers.description: BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1925 LOCATED IN SE. PART OF TOWN OF CLARKSVILLE, ABOUT 4.0 MI NE. OF BIG DIAMOND POND, ON HIGHEST PART OF W. END OF CRYSTAL MOUNTAINS, ON NW. PART OF RATHER FLAT SUMMIT WHICH IS COVERED WITH LARGE TIMBER.  ABOUT 1.5 MI W. OF S. FROM POINT WHERE TOTE RD. OUT OF LITTLE DIAMOND (DEAD DIAMOND) RIVER CROSSES THE -RED LINE- AT HAY SHED, FROM THIS POINT THE -RED LINE- FOLLOWS S. UP THE RIDGE ALMOST UP TO STATION AND THEN TURNS W. DOWN SIDE OF RIDGE.  STATION IS ABOUT 500 FT W. OF S. FROM THIS BEND OF THE -RED LINE-.  STATION MARK,  STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN SOLID LEDGE.  REFERENCE MARK,  SPRUCE SIGNAL TREE 28 FT DISTANT, N 73 DEG 15 MIN E.

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) FROM OXFORD VILLAGE TAKE ROAD TO WENTWORTH, STOP AT MOUNT CUBE HOUSE AT N END OF MOUNTAIN.  THENCE A PATH LEADS TO TOP. TWO POINTS, SIGNAL IS ON S AND HIGHEST ONE.  STATION IS MARKED BY BOLT AND TRIANGLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) STATION MARK, AN IRON BOLT WHICH IS SURROUNDED BY A TRIANGLE CHISLED IN THE OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE ESTABLISHED BY THIS PARTY.  FOLLOWING IS A NEW AND COMPLETE DESCRIPTION.  STATION IS APPROXIMATELY 4 MILES SOUTH OF ORFORDVILLE AND 6.5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PIERMONT AND ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. CUBE.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN ORFORDVILLE, GO EAST ON STATE HIGHWAY 25A FOR 5.7 MILES TO THE MT. CUBE FARM AND LARGE BRICK HOUSE ON THE LEFT, TURN RIGHT THROUGH GATE AND FOLLOW MARKED TRAIL THROUGH FIELD FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JBW) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A PROMINENT WOODED HILL KNOWN AS DAVIS HILL ABOUT 11-1/2 MI. SW OF KEENE, AND ABOUT 7-1/2 MI. NW OF WINCHESTER.  IT IS ON A LARGE ROCK OUTCROP ON THE NE SHOULDER OF THE HILL, ABOUT 200 YD. NE OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL, 30 FT. N OF A 12-IN. OAK TREE, 15 FT. SW OF THE NE EDGE OF THE OUTCROP, AND 10 FT. SE OF THE NW EDGE OF THE OUTCROP. THE DISK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK AND IS STAMPED DAVIS 1957.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 9 AND 63 (ABOUT 9 MI. W OF KEENE), GO S ON STATE HIGHWAY 63 FOR 3.3 MI. TO A DRIVEWAY LEFT.  TURN LEFT ON THE DRIVEWAY ABOUT 100 YD. TO A HOUSE AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM THE HOUSE PACK E, ANGLING UPHILL FOR ABOUT 15 MINUTES TO THE OUTCROP OF A ROCK AT THE NE END OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS IN A SECTION OF ROCK ABOUT 30- BY 5-FT., SEPARATED FROM THE MAIN ROCK OUTCROP BY A LARGE CREVICE, AND ABOUT 2 FT. NE OF THE CREVICE.  THE MARK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK AND IS STAMPED DAVIS NO 1 1957.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS IN A LEDGE ABOUT 4 FT. HIGH AND IS 15 FT. E OF THE 12-IN. OAK TREE.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK AND IS STAMPED DAVIS NO 2 1957.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION COULD BE FOUND FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 1 METER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY DBA SYSTEMS INCORPORATED 1974 (WEH) DAVIS 1957 FOUND STATION AND REFERENCE IS IN GOOD ORDER.  HEAVILY WOODED AREA.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--11.5 MILES SW FROM KEENE, N. H.

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S.  HIGHWAY 202 AND STATE HIGHWAYS 11 AND 108 IN ROCHESTER, PROCEED SOUTHEAST 2.49 KM (1.55 MI) ON STATE HIGHWAY 108 TO A PAVED ROAD AND HANGAR ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND PROCEED NORTHEAST ON THE PAVED ROAD AND TAXI RAMP FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO THE TAXIWAY.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED SOUTHEAST 0.5 KM (0.30 MI) ALONG THE TAXIWAY TO RUNWAY 15-33.  PROCEED NORTHEAST 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) ACROSS THE RUNWAY TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED--DAW A 1998-- SET IN A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 0.3 M (1.0 FT) IN DIAMETER, WITH A STEEL ROD IMBEDDED IN THE CONCRETE, RECESSED 0.05 M.  (0.16 FT) THE STATION IS LOCATED 50.77 M (166.57 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF NORTH 87 DEGREES EAST FROM A PK NAIL SET AT THE CENTERLINE END OF RUNWAY 15-33, 37.65 M (123.52 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF SOUTH 84 DEGREES EAST FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE RUNWAY, 15.21 M (49.90 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF SOUTH 53 DEGREES EAST FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A CONCRETE PAD WITH A GLIDESLOPE LIGHT, AND 6.98 M (22.90 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF SOUTH 69 DEGREES FROM A CONCRETE LIGHT ALIGNMENT POST.  THIS STATION IS DESIGNATED AS A SECONDARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10 MILES SOUTHEAST OF COLEBROOK AND ABOUT 10 MILES NORTHWEST OF ERROL ON THE SUMMIT OF DIXVILLE PEAK AT THE SITE OF THE REMAINS OF AN OLD LOOKOUT TOWER.  STATION IS AT THE WEST EDGE OF A SMALL CLEARING.  THE STATION MARK IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK WITH NO STAMPING CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET.  TO REACH STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 3 AND STATE HIGHWAY 26 NEAR THE SOUTH EDGE OF COLEBROOK GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 26 FOR 9.45 MILES TO A DIM WOODS ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.05 MILE TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  THIS IS AN OLD ABANDONED LOGGING ROAD THAT HAS GROWN UP WITH SMALL TREES, LARGER TREES HAVE FALLEN ACROSS ROAD AND THE BRIDGE HAVE FALLEN IN. PACK SOUTHERLY ALONG BLAZED ROAD TO FORKS.  TAKE RIGHT FORK TO STREAM.  CROSS STREAM AND CONTINUE TO ANOTHER STREAM.  CROSS STREAM AND CONTINUE ON OLD LOGGING ROAD MARKED BY BLAZED TREES ALONG THE EASTERLY SIDE OF THE MAIN BROOK TO WHERE BLAZED TRAIL BEARS LEFT AWAY FROM THE BROOK.  DISTANCE FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL TO THIS POINT IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES AND ABOUT 1 HOUR PACK.  FOLLOW BLAZED TRAIL FOR ABOUT 1 MILE UP STEEP CLIMB THROUGH HEAVY TIMBER AND UNDERGROWTH TO SUMMIT AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  THIS IS ALSO ABOUT 1 HOUR PACK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS SET FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK THAT ALSO WAS USED FOR ONE OF THE GUY CABLES FOR THE OLD LOOKOUT TOWER. THE DISK IS STAMPED DIXVILLE NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2-1/2 FEET AND THE DISK IS STAMPED DIXVILLE NO 2 1959.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 7 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2007 (RG) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT SEARCHED FOR.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BALSAM HOTEL IN DIXVILLE NOTCH, DRIVE WEST ON ROUTE 26 ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE SKI AREA (LABELED WILDERNESS ROAD) ON THE LEFT.  DRIVE UP THIS DIRT ROAD ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO THE SKI AREA PARKING LOT.  PACK UP SNOWMOBILE TRAILS ABOUT 2.5 MILES TO THE SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  A MAP OF THE TRAILS TO THE SUMMIT CAN BE OBTAINED AT THE FRONT DESK OF THE HOTEL.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 (OBF) STATION IS ON A VERY PROMINENT BARE HILL, ABOUT A MILE S OF THE CENTER OF THE TOWN OF DOVER, AND JUST W OF THE MAIN ROAD FROM DOVER TO DOVER POINT.  THERE IS ANOTHER ROAD, ALMOST AS WELL USED, ON THE W SIDE OF THE HILL, BUT THE TWO JOIN JUST S OF THE HILL ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED. THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL, AND IS MARKED BY A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN SOLID ROCK WHICH IS JUST ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE TOP OF THE GROUND.  THERE IS A LARGE PINE TREE ABOUT 100 FEET SE, AND A GROVE OF PINES ABOUT 100 YARDS W OF THE STATION.  SEVERAL LARGE BOULDERS ARE JUST S OF THE STATION.  A LARGE FARMHOUSE WITH BARN IS JUST ACROSS THE ROAD E OF THE STATION.  SEVERAL HOUSES ARE ON THE OTHER ROAD ABOUT SW OF THE STATION AND BEYOND THE PINE GROVE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1908 DESCRIPTION.  DESCRIPTION FOUND COMPLETE, CORRECT, AND ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  THE DESCRIPTION IS INADEQUATE AND A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS ABOUT 1 MI. SE OF DOWNTOWN DOVER, ON THE SW SIDE OF THE OLD DOVER-DOVER POINT ROAD, ON THE TOP OF A HILL, AND ABOUT 500 FT. S OF THE HOME OF JOHN ROUSSEAU.  THREE SMALL BOULDERS LIE TO THE E AND S OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS 1.8 FT. W OF THE W END OF THE BOULDER TO THE E, AND 5 FT. N OF THE N END OF THE BOULDER TO THE S.  THE ROCK IN WHICH THE STATION IS DRILLED IS SLIGHTLY LOWER THAN THE SURROUNDING GROUND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF WASHINGTON STREET AND HENRY LOW AVENUE IN DOVER, GO 1 MI. SE ALONG HENRY LOW AVENUE (OLD DOVER-DOVER POINT ROAD) TO THE FARM OF JOHN ROUSEEAU AND THE STATION ON TOP OF THE HILL TO THE S.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12.0 MILES NORTHWEST OF BERLIN, ABOUT 10.0 MILES EAST OF GROVETON, ABOUT 1.5 MILES NORTHWEST OF WEST MILAN AND IN THE YARD OF THE DUMMER PLAIN SCHOOL.  IT IS 76.1 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE SCHOOL HOUSE AND 47.0 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PLAIN ROAD.  THE SURFACE DISK IS SET IN THE TOP OF A 10-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE UNDERGROUND DISK IS SET 36 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE. THE DISKS ARE STAMPED DUMMER 1959.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE HOTEL COSTELLO IN BERLIN, GO NORTHWEST ON STATE HIGHWAY 110 FOR 11.0 MILES TO THE RAILROAD CROSSING IN WEST MILAN, CONTINUE AHEAD ON STATE HIGHWAY 110 FOR 1.0 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON PLAIN ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO DUMMER PLAIN SCHOOL AND STATION ON THE RIGHT.  REFERENCE MARK NO 1 IS 68.4 FEET SOUTHEAST OF UTILITY POLE NO 7, 52.0 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE SCHOOL HOUSE AND 48.1 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PLAIN ROAD.  IT IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE MARK IS SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED DUMMER NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO 2 IS 74.4 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE SCHOOL HOUSE AND 74.0 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PLAIN ROAD.  IT IS ABOUT 2 FEET HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE MARK IS SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED DUMMER NO 2 1959.  AZIMUTH MARK IS 20.0 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF PLAIN ROAD, 18.0 FEET EAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE WEST FORK OF HOLT ROAD, 14.2 FEET WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE EAST FORK OF HOLT ROAD AND 2.3 FEET SOUTH OF UTILITY POLE NO 153.  THE MARK IS SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED DUMMER 1959.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION, GO NORTHWEST ON PLAIN ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, HOLT ROAD AND THE AZIMUTH MARK SET IN THE Y FORK OF HOLT ROAD.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.

TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 123 AND 137 IN THE TOWN OF HANCOCK, GO SOUTHEAST 2.4 MILES ALONG HIGHWAY 137 TO A ROAD THAT GOES WEST-NORTHWEST, THEN 1.3 MILES ALONG SAID ROAD TO THE INTERSECTION OF ROADS, THEN NORTHEAST ALONG ROAD 0.8 MILE TO A TRAIL OR OLD ROAD, THEN ALONG SAID TRAIL OR OLD ROAD WEST, THEN NORTH 1.2 MILES TO THE STATION.  SAID STATION IS IN THE LEDGE CROPPING ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN.  THE STATION MARK BEING A 7/8 INCH DIAMETER DRILL HOLE FOUND IN THE CENTER OF A TRIANGLE OF DRILL HOLES. REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A DRILL HOLE SET IN THE LEDGE ON THE LINE BETWEEN SAID STATION AND CROTCHED MOUNTAIN LOOOKOUT TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A DRILL HOLE SET ON THE TOP OF A 7 FOOT ROUND 4 FOOT HIGH BOULDER.  NOTE--ALL ANGLES WERE TURNED WITH A DKM2AE THEODOLITE. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE CAMPUS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE, AT THE SITE OF THE UNIVERSITY WATER TANK NEAR THE NW EDGE OF THE TOWN OF DURHAM.  IT IS 50 PACES S OF NESMITH HALL, 55 FEET S OF A GRAVEL ROAD, AND 32.12 FEET SE OF THE CENTER OF THE FEED PIPE OF THE WATER TANK.  IT IS STAMPED DURHAM 1943 AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  SURFACE, UNDERGROUND, AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE.  AZIMUTH MARK IS A BRONZE DISK SET IN DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS N OF THE STATION, 5 FEET S OF THE NESMITH HALL, 1 FOOT E OF A POWER-TRANSMISSION LINE POLE, AND 1 FOOT S OF THE SE CORNER OF A LARGE TRANSFORMER.  IT IS STAMPED DURHAM NO 1 1943 AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SE OF THE STATION, 2.5 FEET N OF THE NW CORNER OF A SMALL WHITE BARN, AND 1 FOOT W OF A BOARD FENCE. IT IS STAMPED DURHAM NO 2 1943 AND PROJECTS 5 INCHES.  AZIMUTH MARK IS W BY S OF THE STATION NEAR THE SW EDGE OF THE FOOTBALL FIELD IN A LARGE OUTCROPPING OF BEDROCK.  IT IS 68 PACES W OF THE CONCRETE CURB OF A RACE TRACK, 41 PACES E OF THE SE CORNER OF A SMALL FRAME HOUSE, 14 FEET W OF POWER-TRANSMISSION LINE POLE 2, AND 120 PACES NW OF A FLAGPOLE.  IT IS STAMPED DURHAM 1943.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN DURHAM, GO W ON THE MAIN STREET FOR 0.6 MILE TO THE ENTRANCE TO NESMITH HALL ON THE LEFT.  THEN FOLLOW A DRIVE AROUND THE W END OF THE BUILDING TO THE TOP OF A SMALL HILL AND THE STATION.  THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE WATER TANK IS NW OF THE STATION. THE TANK IS SUPPORTED BY FOUR STEEL LEGS AND IS ABOUT 125 FEET HIGH.  THE STRUCTURE IS PAINTED WHITE AND THE TANK PROPER HAS THE LETTERS UNH PAINTED IN BLACK ON THE N AND S SIDES.  IT IS LOCATED BY DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM TRIANGULATION STATION DURHAM.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 30 METERS. markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1851 (TJC) STATION IS ON THE W OF THE GREAT BAY IN THE TOWN OF DURHAM, N.H.  THE STATION IS A HIGH ROCK UP IN THE PASTURE BELONGING TO A MAN NAMED LIGHTFOOT.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT IN THE ROCK.  THE BEST WAY TO REACH THE STATION IS TO GO FROM GREENLAND THROUGH STRATHAM STATION AND NEWMARKET STATION.  GO ON TO LAMPREY RIVER VILLAGE, CROSS THE RIVER, AND TAKE THE FIRST RIGHT-HAND ROAD THAT LEADS DOWN TOWARD THE BAY.  KEEP THAT ROAD WHICH WILL BEAR AROUND TO THE LEFT AND WOULD CARRY YOU ON TO DURHAM MEETING HOUSE.  IT IS ON THE LEFT-HAND SIDE, BACK IN THE PASTURE, HIGH UP, AND DIFFICULT OF ACCESS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) TWO HOURS WAS SPENT IN THIS VICINITY LOOKING AND ASKING FOR INFORMATION CONCERNING STATION.  ALL REFERENCE POINTS DESTROYED.  IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT THIS STATION BE CLASSIFIED AS LOST.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1992 (DRM) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT THE DILLANT-HOPKINS AIRPORT ON THE SOUTH END OF THE AIRPORT NORTHWEST OF RUNWAY END 2.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 235.7 FT (71.8 M) NORTHWEST OF RUNWAY END 2, 86.8 FT (26.5 M) WEST OF AND ON-LINE WITH THE FIRST SET OF RUNWAY LIGHTS NORTH OF END 2, 43 FT (13.1 M) SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTH END OF A SMALL ROCK LINED RUNOFF DITCH, AND 1.8 FT (0.5 M) EAST OF A 1/2 INCH PVC WITNESS POST.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED EEN B 1992 AND SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS 0.3 FT (9.1 CM) BELOW THE SURFACE.  A 12 X 12 INCH CONCRETE SLAB WAS PLACED OVER THE MARK FOR PROTECTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1998)  RECOVERY NOTE BY WOOLPERT CONSULTANTS 1998 (BBS) DESCRIBED BY WOOLPERT LLP 1998 (ARL) .  THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 23.8 KM (14.80 MI) EAST OF BRATTLEBORO VERMONT AND THE VERMONT AND NEW HAMPSHIRE STATE LINE, 5.1 KM (3.15 MI) WEST OF MARLBOROUGH, 2.7 KM (1.65 MI) SOUTH OF KEENE AND IS AT THE DILLANT-HOPKINS / KEENE AIRPORT.  OWNERSHIP--CITY OF KEENE, C/O ED MATTERN AIRPORT DIRECTOR, 80 AIRPORT ROAD, KEENE NH 03431-4455, PHONE NUMBER 603-357-9835, FAX NUMBER 603-357-9853.  CONTACT THE AIRPORT DIRECTOR A MINIMUM OF 24 HOURS PRIOR TO ENTRY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 101, 12 AND 12A IN KEENE, PROCEED SOUTH 1.37 KM (0.85 MI) ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 12 TO STATE HIGHWAY 32 (RICHMOND ROAD) ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED SOUTH 0.24 KM (0.15 MI) ALONG RICHMOND ROAD TO AIRPORT ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED WEST ALONG AIRPORT ROAD 0.8 KM (0.50 MI) TO THE AIRPORT ON THE LEFT AND A GATE TO THE RIGHT OF THE TERMINAL. CONTINUE THROUGH THE GATE AND PROCEED SOUTHWEST 0.24 KM (0.15 MI) ACROSS THE APRON AND ALONG TAXIWAY S TO THE JUNCTION OF RUNWAY 32-14.  TURN LEFT AND PROCEED SOUTHEAST 0.40 KM (0.25 MI) ALONG RUNWAY 32-14 TO THE JUNCTION OF RUNWAYS 32-14 AND 2-20.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED SOUTH 1.4 KM (0.85 MI) ALONG RUNWAY 2-20 TO THE START OF RUNWAY 2 AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED--EEN B 1992-- SET IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE RECESSED 0.15 M (0.49 FT) BELOW THE GROUND AND COVERED BY 2 PATIO BLOCKS. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES NORTH OF MILFORD, 4 MILES NORTH OF MONT VERNON 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF NEW BOSTON AND ON A PROMINENT WOODED HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS JOE ENGLISH HILL.  IT IS 6 FEET EAST OF A 6 INCH TRIANGULAR BLAZED OAK TREE WITH A WITNESS POST SIGN NAILED TO THE TREE AND IS ON THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF HILL.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES AND IS STAMPED ENGLISH 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 18 INCHES AND IS STAMPED ENGLISH NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET AND IS STAMPED ENGLISH NO 2 1959.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN NEW BOSTON, GO SOUTHERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 13 FOR 2.45 MILES TO CROSSROADS AT BOTTOM OF HILL, TURN LEFT AT CROSSROADS AND GO EASTERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK ON GRAVEL ROAD AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.5 MILE TO A TRACK ROAD ON RIGHT BETWEEN 2 FENCE LINE.  (THIS IS JUST BEFORE REACHING A WHITE HOUSE ON THE LEFT.) TURN RIGHT ON TRACK ROAD AND GO EASTERLY THROUGH ORCHARD AND THEN FIELD FOR 0.25 MILE TO WOODS, CONTINUE THROUGH WOODS ON TRACK ROAD FOR ABOUT 0.15 MILE TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOLLOW DIM FOOT TRAIL SOUTHEASTERLY UP HILL FOR ABOUT 0.2 MILE TO THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF SUMMIT AND STATION.  THIS IS ABOUT 50 YARD EAST OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF HILL.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 5.33 METERS.
