BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) GO TO MOUNTAIN HOUSE ON W SIDE, ON ROAD FROM GREENFIELD TO SOUTH LYNDEBOROUGH.  NO PRACTICABLE ROAD UP THE HILL.  LEAVE MOUNTAIN HOUSE WALK UP GREENFIELD ROAD ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO A DESERTED HOUSE ON RIGHT-HAND SIDE.  TURN IN AT A PAIR OF BARS ON THE RIGHT, JUST BEFORE REACHING THE HOUSE, AND PUSH UP THROUGH WOODS AND PASTURES.  THE MOST DIRECT COURSE WILL BE APPARENT ON ADVANCING.  MOST OF THE WOODS MAY BE AVOIDED BY BEARING TO THE LEFT AFTER ENTERING THROUGH THE BARS, AND THEN TURNING TO THE RIGHT AFTER CROSSING THE FIRST FENCE OR WALL.  DISTANCE FROM ROAD TO SUMMIT PROBABLY ALMOST A MILE, AND FROM MOUNTAIN HOUSE ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES.  THE TOP IS LEDGE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A HOLE DRILLED IN ROCK.  AT 8 INCHES FROM THIS ARE 3 SHALLOW HOLES FORMING A TRIANGLE ONE OF WHOSE SIDES POINTS N AND S.  AN ARROWHEAD DRILLED IN ROCK ON W SIDE, 22 FEET DISTANT, POINTS TOWARD THE STATION. LAND ON THE TOP IS OWNED IN PART BY GEORGE WINN, OF WOBURN, MASSACHUSETTS.  THE N PEAK OR HILL IS PROBABLY BETTER FOR A TERTIARY SIGNAL. IT IS SAID THAT MUCH MORE CAN BE SEEN FROM ITS SUMMIT.  THERE ARE 2 PEAKS TO THE N OR NE, BOTH OF WHICH ARE HIGHER THAN THE ONE USED.  ONE OF THESE WE CALL N HILL, E PEAK.  THE OTHER N HILL W PEAK.  INFORMATION OBTAINED THAT TO REACH THE N HILL, GO TO JOE BLANCHARDS ON N SIDE, ON THE DIRECT ROAD FROM FRANCESTOWN TO THE MOUNTAIN HOUSE OR SOUTH LYNDEBOROUGH.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

AND S., THE MOUNTAIN IS BEST REACHED FROM CONNECTICUT LAKE BY TRAIL FROM THE DAM ABOUT 8.0 MI TO SUMMIT OR BY BOAT TO SOUTH BAY, THENCE BY TOTE RD. REFERENCE MARK, CHISELED TRIANGLE IN DRILL HOLE 358.7 FT DISTANT, S 68 DEG 44 MIN E. THE ORIGINAL FIRE TOWER WAS REPLACED IN THE 1920S BY ONE ABOUT 250 FEET FURTHER EAST.  NO REMNANTS OF THE ORIGINAL TOWER WERE FOUND, NOR ANY EXPOSED ROCK IN THE GENERAL AREA.  THE AREA WAS SEARCHED FOR 30 MINUTES BY ONE MAN.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 (OBF) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE HIGHEST HILL ABOUT A HALF MILE S OF THE TOWN OF NEW MARKET AND ON THE W SIDE OF THE MAIN ROAD BETWEEN NEW MARKET AND NEWFIELDS AND EXETER.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH A DENSE GROWTH OF BRUSH, MOSTLY OAK.  A LARGE IRON WATER TANK IS ON THE SPUR OF THE HILL ABOUT 50 METERS E OF THE STATION AND 40 FEET BELOW IT.  THERE ARE TRAILS UP THE HILL FROM VARIOUS DIRECTIONS, BUT FROM THE SE IS A WAGON TRACK WINDING TO THE WATER TANK.  IT IS GROWN UP WITH BRUSH, BUT IS THE EASIEST WAY TO WALK UP.  THE STATION IS ON THE TOP OF A LARGE FLAT ROCK FACE, PRACTICALLY A PART OF THE TOP OF THE HILL, AND THE HIGHEST PART LARGE ENOUGH TO MOUNT AN INSTRUMENT ON, AND NOT MORE THAN 4 METERS W OF A ROCKY LEDGE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN A TRIANGLE WITH 4-INCH SIDES.  THE REFERENCE MARKS, 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLES, TWO IN POINTED ROCKS A LITTLE HIGHER THAN THE STATION, THE OTHER (EASTERN ONE) IN THE ROCK OF THE LEDGE OVER WHICH ONE MUST CLIMB IN GOING DIRECTLY TO THE STATION, ARE RESPECTIVELY, 3.825 METERS FROM THE STATION N 24 DEG 39 MIN E.  5.785 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 28 DEG 11 MIN E.  3.255 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 85 DEG 49 MIN W. THERE IS A STONE FENCE 15 OR 20 METERS W OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1930 I HAVE BEEN AT THIS STATION SEVERAL TIMES DURING THIS YEAR (1930) AND HAVE FOUND THE STATION MARK AND 3 REFERENCE HOLES TO BE IN GOOD ORDER.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION APPEARS TO BE CORRECT AND ADEQUATE.  THE VIEW IS PARTIALLY OBSTRUCTED BY SMALL TREES, BUT LINES COULD READILY BE OPENED.  THE IRON WATER TANK, NEARBY, IS PAINTED RED AND SERVES AS A CONSPICUOUS GUIDE FOR REACHING THE LOCALITY OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS CORRECT AND ADEQUATE EXCEPT FOR THE FOLLOWING DISCREPANCY--  STONE FENCE IS 12 METERS W OF STATION, NOT 15 OR 20 METERS.  THE FOLLOWING SHOULD BE ADDED--  THE STATION IS WITNESSED BY THREE BLAZED TREES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (EHK) THE STATION AND THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED. THE DISTANCES TO THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE MEASURED WITH A STEEL TAPE AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  THE STATION WAS REMARKED AND STAMPED MARK 1908 1953.  REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS REMARKED WITH A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED MARK 1908 1953 NO 1, SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS REMARKED WITH A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK STAMPED MARK 1908 1953 NO 2, SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A BOULDER.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) THE NAME OF THE TOWN OF MASON HILL HAS BEEN CHANGED TO GREENVILLE. FROM GREENVILLE GO ABOUT 1-1/4 TO 1-1/2 MILES TO MR. E.H. RUSSELLS ON E SIDE.  THE HILL IS S OF THE VILLAGE.  FROM MR. RUSSELLS A ROAD LEADS NEARLY TO THE TOP.  FROM THE TOP, MONADNOCK IS JUST VISIBLE, A LITTLE ABOVE KIDDER MOUNTAIN TOP.  THE SUMMIT OF CROTCHET MOUNTAIN CAN BE SEEN JUST OVER THE LONG E SPUR OF PETERBORO MOUNTAIN. THIS IS THE RIGHT SPOT TO FORM A SECONDARY QUADRILATERAL WITH MONADNOCK, CROTCHET AND UNKONOONUC.  THE SUMMIT IS RATHER LEVEL, MOSTLY LEDGE, COVERED HERE AND THERE WITH EARTH.  PASTURE LAND OWNED BY A MAN IN MASSACHUSETTS.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A DRILLED HOLE, AROUND WHICH IS DRILLED A TRIANGLE WHOSE W SIDE POINTS N AND S.  AT 30-1/2 FEET E OF STATION A DRILLED ARROWHEAD POINTS TO IT.  AT 122 FEET S IS A STONE WALL RUNNING N OF W.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 23 MILES SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF MANCHESTER, 17 MILES WEST OF NASHUA, 1 MILE SOUTH OF THE VILLAGE OF GREENVILLE AND ON THE SUMMIT OF A WOODED HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS BARRETT HILL.  IT IS 10 FEET EAST OF A 10 INCH TRIANGULAR BLAZED PINE TREE, 120 FEET NORTH OF AN OLD STONE FENCE AND 5 FEET EAST OF A METAL WITNESS POST. THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK INSIDE OF A TRIANGLE CHISELED IN BEDROCK AND IS STAMPED MASON 1871 1959.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN GREENVILLE, GO EAST OVER BRIDGE FOR 0.05 MILE TO STATE HIGHWAY 123, TURN LEFT ON STATE HIGHWAY 123 AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.85 MILE TO THE INTERSECTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 31.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON STATE HIGHWAYS 31 AND 123 FOR 0.6 MILE TO WHERE STATE HIGHWAY 31 TURNS LEFT AND GOES EAST AND A GRAVEL ROAD ON RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT ON GRAVEL ROAD AND FOLLOW MAIN TRAVELED ROAD WESTERLY FOR 0.75 MILE TO A TRIANGULAR BLAZED TREE ON RIGHT AND A DIM WOODS ROAD ON LEFT, TURN LEFT ON DIM WOODS ROAD PASSING THROUGH OPENING IN ROCK FENCE AND GO SOUTHERLY UP HILL FOR 0.25 MILE TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE THAT IS 42 FEET NORTHEAST OF A 10 INCH TRIANGULAR BLAZED PINE TREE, 45 FEET NORTHEAST OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET AND IS STAMPED MASON NO 1 1871 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 46 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A 10 INCH TRIANGULAR BLAZED PINE TREE AND 45 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK AND IS STAMPED MASON NO 2 1871 1959.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 14 METERS.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1915 (JEM) IN PITTSBURG TOWNSHIP, ABOUT 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF MALVINA, QUEBEC, RAILROAD STATION, ON THE CREST OF THE DIVIDE BETWEEN HALLS STREAM AND INDIAN STREAM.  STATION MARK--STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN CONCRETE.  THE REFERENCE MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK, DISTANT 11.50 FEET, N 61 DEG 28 MIN W, FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2008 (RG) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD IBC TRIANGULATION DISK SET IN A MASS OF CONCRETE SET IN A HOLLOW OF THE BEDROCK.  THE REFERENCE MARK IS A STANDARD IBC TRIANGULATION DISK SET IN A LARGE BOULDER STANDING ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE THE GROUND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF ROUTE 3 AND ROUTE 145 IN PITTSBURG, GO WEST ON ROUTE 3 ABOUT 2.7 MILES TO INDIAN STREAM ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  GO NORTH ON INDIAN STREAM ROAD ABOUT 3.1 MILES TO A LOGGING ROAD ON THE LEFT. GO NORTHWEST ABOUT .4 MILES ON THE LOGGING ROAD TO A BRIDGE AND A GATE SIGNED GATE 6. CROSS THE BRIDGE AND BEAR RIGHT ONTO ANOTHER LOGGING ROAD.  GO NORTHEAST ABOUT 1.7 MILES TO A FORK AND A GATE SIGNED GATE 7. TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHWEST ABOUT 1.8 ON THE LOGGING ROAD TO A TRIANGLE INTERSECTION WITH HALLS STREAM ROAD.  GO NORTH ON HALLS STREAM ROAD ABOUT 1.4 MILES TO A LOGGING ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  GO EAST AND SOUTHEAST ON THIS LOGGING ROAD ABOUT .4 MILES TO A CLEARING AND END OF VEHICULAR TRAVEL. FROM HERE, BUSHWHACK EAST ABOUT .75 MILES THROUGH OPEN WOODS TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY WOOLPERT CONSULTANTS 1998 (BBS) DESCRIBED BY WOOLPERT LLP 1998 (ARL) .  THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 10.8 KM (6.70 MI) NORTHWEST OF DERRY, 9.0 KM (5.60 MI) NORTHEAST OF MERRIMACK, 5.55 KM (3.45 MI) SOUTH OF MANCHESTER AND IS AT THE MANCHESTER AIRPORT.  OWNERSHIP--CITY OF MANCHESTER, C/O RICHARD FIXLER ASSISTANT AIRPORT DIRECTOR, MANCHESTER AIRPORT, ONE AIRPORT ROAD SUITE 300, MANCHESTER NH 03103-3395, PHONE NUMBER 603-624-6539, FAX NUMBER 603-666-4101.  CONTACT THE ASSISTANT AIRPORT DIRECTOR A MINIMUM OF 24 HOURS PRIOR TO ENTRY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 293 (EXIT 1) AND STATE HIGHWAY 28 SOUTH OF MANCHESTER, PROCEED SOUTH ALONG STATE ROUTE 28 (SOUTH WILLOW STREET) 1.17 KM (0.70 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF HARVEY ROAD ON THE RIGHT. STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1934 (RE) RECOVERY BY ROBERT EASTWICK AS FOLLOWS--TO REACH THE SUMMIT OF THIS MOUNTAIN GO TO THE ARTISTS FALLS HOUSE 1 MILE FROM N CONWAY, FROM THERE TAKE THE TRAIL THAT LEADS TO THE FALLS AND CONTINUES ON TO THE SUMMIT. STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (JKS) HOLE AND TRIANGLE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AT THE DESCRIBED LOCATION.   AS NOTED IN THE 1934 REPORT, THE BOLT IS NO LONGER HERE. THE HOLE AND THE CHISELED TRIANGLE STILL ARE AND SOMEONE HAS DRIVEN A 1/2 INCH DIAMETER IRON ROD INTO THE HOLE.   ELEVATION IS NOT LISTED ON THE DATA, BUT THE TOPO MAP OF THE AREA AND GPS READING AGREE THAT 1,875 FOOT IS THE ELEVATION.   SUBMITTED BY J.K. SNYDER

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES NORTH NORTHWEST OF BERLIN, 2 MILES WEST OF MILAN AND AT THE MILAN HILL LOOKOUT TOWER.  IT IS 13.1 FEET EAST SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTH WEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 8.7 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 13.0 FEET WEST NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 16.3 FEET NORTHEAST OF SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 5.6 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A CONCRETE BASE OF STEPS AND 3.83 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE BASE OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS ABOUT 10 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND IS STAMPED MILAN 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 80 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 61.6 FEET WEST SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF SHELTER AND IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES AND IS STAMPED MILAN NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 51.7 FEET WEST SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 8 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF A TRACK ROAD AND IS ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION MARK.  THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET AND IS STAMPED MILAN NO 2 1959.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN MILAN, GO WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 110 B FOR 1.95 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AND SIGN MILAN HILL STATE PARK.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.4 MILE TO CARE-TAKERS HOUSE ON RIGHT, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.15 MILES TO A TRACK ROAD ON LEFT, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW TRACK ROAD UP HILL FOR 0.05 MILE TO LOOKOUT TOWER AND STATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 13.67 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JJC) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED AS ORIGINALLY DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) (ALL OBJECTS OBSERVED FROM LOOKOUT TOWER OVER STATION, NO OBJECTS VISIBLE FROM THE GROUND.)  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12 MILES NORTHEAST OF LANCASTER, 10 MILES WEST NORTHWEST OF BERLIN AND AT THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF BASE OF THE MILL MTN. LOOKOUT TOWER.  IT IS 6.48 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 7.27 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 7.61 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER AND 6.84 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET ON THE EAST SIDE AND IS ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND ON THE WEST SIDE OF BOULDER AND IS STAMPED MILL 1959.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE COSTELLO HOTEL IN BERLIN, GO NORTHWEST ON STATE ROUTE 110 FOR 17.0 MILES TO A PICNIC AREA ON THE RIGHT AND SMALL SIGN ON LEFT MILL TRAIL AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOLLOW MILL TRAIL ON LEFT UP HILL FOR ABOUT 2.0 MILES TO LOOKOUT TOWER AND STATION.  (THIS IS ABOUT AN 1-1/2 HOUR PACK.)  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 15.25 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FOREST SERVICE 1965 (FSB) RECOVERED STATION AS DESCRIBED.  ALL MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE MILL TRAIL HAS BEEN OFFICIALLY ABANDONED AND THE LOOKOUT TOWER HAS BEEN DISMANTLED.  HOWEVER, ONE CAN STILL REACH THE STATION SITE FROM THE PICNIC AREA IF ONE IS CAREFUL AS THE TRAIL HAS NOT YET GROWN OVER.  NO OBSERVATION ARE OBTAINABLE FROM THE STATION SITE AT GROUND LEVEL.

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) TO REACH THE STATION GO TO THE HOUSE OF MR. AARON COLBURN, ON THE MOUNTAIN ROAD FROM SOUTH WEARE TO WEARE CENTER.  HE LIVES 2-1/2 MILES FROM SOUTH WEARE AND 2-3/4 MILES FROM WEARE CENTER.  CLINTON GROVE IS 3/4 MILE DISTANT TO THE N.  THE SIGNAL IS ON THE W KNOLL OR RIDGE OF THE HILL, SINCE THE E RIDGE IS COVERED WITH WOODS, ALTHOUGH HIGHER.  THE SIGNAL IS ON NEWLY CLEARED PASTURE, ON HIGHEST POINT OF W RIDGE.  BY KEEPING THE ROAD FOR 1/2 MILE S OF MR. COLBURNS AND TURNING IN AT BARS ON THE LEFT, IT IS POSSIBLE TO DRIVE TO THE TOP THROUGH PASTURE.  THE TOP IS NOW COVERED WITH STUMPS, OLD TRUNKS AND BRUSH. ITS CHARACTER IS SOIL, BROKEN LEDGE, AND LOOSE ROCK MIXED.  TO FIX THE STATION, A HOLE WAS DUG THROUGH EARTH AND LOOSE ROCK ABOUT 18 INCHES DEEP, TO WHAT SEEMS TO BE SOLID LEDGE. A HOLE IS DRILLED IN THIS LEDGE.  THERE IS SO MUCH IRON IN THE HILL, THAT THE INDICATIONS OF THE COMPASS ARE PROBABLY NOT RELIABLE.

REPAIRS CONSISTED OF CUTTING AWAY ALL THE FRIABLE CONCRETE, TO AN AVERAGE DEPTH OF 8 INCHES, AND PUTTING ON A NEW TOP IN WHICH THE USUAL INSCRIPTIONS WERE STAMPED, INCLUDING---RENEWED 1939---. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1896 STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF MONADNOCK MOUNTAIN, WHICH IS IN THE TOWNS OF JAFFREY, DUBLIN AND MARLBORO.  THE STATION IS ON A COMPARATIVELY LEVEL ROCK, WITH A HIGHER ROCK TO THE N.  IT IS MARKED BY A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK.  THERE IS A DRILL HOLE BESIDE THE ONE WHICH MARKS THE STATION OPENING INTO IT AND ANOTHER 7/8 INCH DISTANT, WITH AN IRON BOLT IN IT.  THERE ARE 5 LINES CUT IN THE ROCK RADIATING FROM THE CENTER HOLE.  FIVE REFERENCE MARKS, DRILL HOLES IN ROCKS WITH SQUARES AROUND THEM AND WITH ARROWS POINTING TO THE STATION, ARE LOCATED AS FOLLOWS--NO. 1 DISTANT 11.52 METERS (38.80 FEET), N 4 DEG 21 MIN E.  NO. 2 DISTANT 10.78 METERS (35.37 FEET), N 32 DEG 59 MIN E.  NO. 3 DISTANT 5.12 METERS (16.80 FEET), S 10 DEG 53 MIN W.  NO. 5 DISTANT 5.43 METERS (17.81 FEET), N 87 DEG 50 MIN W.  THE BORDEN STATION IS 10.31 METERS (33.83 FEET) DISTANT, N 8 DEG W.                            STATION RECOVERY (1932)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1932 (HSS) STATION MAY BE REACHED FROM THE HIGHWAY BETWEEN JAFFREY AND TROY.  AT A POINT ABOUT S OF THE MOUNTAIN A PRIVATE TOLL ROAD RUNS N ABOUT 1.3 MILES TO A SMALL HOTEL, CALLED THE HALF WAY HOUSE, AND FROM THERE A STEEP AND ROCKY, BUT MUCH USED TRAIL LEADS TO THE SUMMIT, THE ASCENT REQUIRING ABOUT 3/4 HOUR.  THERE ARE SEVERAL OTHER TRAILS ON THE MOUNTAIN.  THE UPPER PART OF THE MOUNTAIN CONSISTS OF BARE LEDGES AND THE SUMMIT IS RATHER SHARPLY POINTED.  THE STATION IS MARKED AS DESCRIBED AND I HAD NO DIFFICULTY IN IT WHEN I VISITED THE MOUNTAIN IN 1932.  THE TRIANGLE AND 5 RADIAL LINES ARE STILL DISTINCT, ALTHOUGH NOT DEEPLY CUT IN THE LEDGE.  THE TRIANGLE, WHICH IS LARGE, APPEARS TO BE CENTERED ON THE HOLE (ONE OF 3 WITHIN THE TRIANGLE) WHICH IS DESCRIBED AS BEING THE STATION POINT.  I FOUND MANY DRILL HOLES, OF VARIOUS SIZES, ON THE SUMMIT, SEVERAL OF THEM BEING WITHIN A FEW FEET OF THE STATION, BUT, I FAILED TO IDENTIFY ANY OF THEM, IN A HASTY SEARCH, AS BEING THE REFERENCE MARKS MENTIONED IN THE DESCRIPTION, ALTHOUGH SOME OF THEM MAY STILL EXIST.  A U.S.G.S. DISK, UNSTAMPED, IS CEMENTED IN THE LEDGE AT A DISTANCE OF 1.04 FEET IN A SOUTHWESTERLY DIRECTION FROM THE STATION.  IT WAS SET BY MR. C.B. KENDALL IN 1931.  NEAR THE STATION IS A FIRE LOOKOUT CABIN, CONSISTING OF A MASONRY WALL SURMOUNTED BY SEVERAL WINDOWS ON A LOW ROOF.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 5 FEET N OF THE NE CORNER OF THE CABIN.  THE VIEW FROM THE SUMMIT IS UNOBSTRUCTED IN ALL DIRECTIONS.  A LARGE PART OF THE MOUNTAIN IS IN PUBLIC OWNERSHIP, THE SUMMIT BEING OWNED BY EITHER THE TOWN OF JAFFREY, OR THE SOCIETY FOR THE PROTECTION OF NEW HAMPSHIRE FORESTS, THERE BEING SOME UNCERTAINTY AS TO THE POSITION OF THE BOUNDARY LINE.  I FOUND A DRILL HOLE WHICH I TOOK TO BE THE BORDEN STATION, MENTIONED IN THE DESCRIPTION, THE DISTANCE AND AZIMUTH AGREEING WITH THOSE GIVEN.  THE HOLE HAS A CONICAL OPENING, WHICH SUGGESTED THAT THE ROCK HAD BEEN CHIPPED AWAY BY SOMEONE WHO MAY HAVE REMOVED THE COPPER BOLT WHICH DOUBTLESS ORIGINALLY WAS IN THE HOLE.  NOTE--THIS STATION IS DATED 1860 BUT 1861 IS GIVEN IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION AND ON THE SKETCHES IN THE ANNUAL REPORTS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1937)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1937 DRILL HOLE, WITH LARGER DRILL HOLE OPENING INTO IT, ENCLOSED IN A LARGE TRIANGLE IN A FAIRLY LEVEL ROCK, S OF A HIGHER ROCK, AND 5.5 FEET N OF NE CORNER OF STONE FIRE LOOKOUT CABIN, ON THE HIGHEST PART OF MT. MONADNOCK, IN JAFFREY.  THE MOUNTAIN ALSO LIES PARTLY IN DUBLIN AND MARLBORO.  FIVE LINES CUT IN THE ROCK RADIATE FROM THE STATION DRILL HOLE, AND THERE IS A 1/2-INCH IRON PIN 0.1 FOOT NE FROM IT.  A U.S.G.S. STANDARD DISK, UNSTAMPED, SET IN LEDGE IS 1.04 FEET SW FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARKS--IN 1937, THE MASSACHUSETTS GEODETIC SURVEY RECOVERED THE 5 ORIGINAL REFERENCE DRILL HOLES, WITHIN SQUARES, WITH ARROWS, AND ESTABLISHED REFERENCE MARKS NOS. 6, 7 AND 8, MARKED BY U.S.C. AND G.S. STANDARD REFERENCE DISKS SET IN LEDGE.  MEASUREMENTS TO REFERENCE MARKS NOS. 2 AND 3 COULD NOT BE CHECKED BECAUSE OF OBSTRUCTION BY FIRE LOOKOUT CABIN, BUT THESE TWO MARKS WERE LOCATED FROM REFERENCE MARK NO. 7, AS GIVEN BELOW.  THE 6 OTHER REFERENCE MARKS ARE LOCATED FROM STATION, AS FOLLOWS--ALL DISTANCES AND AZIMUTHS ADJUSTED--  STATION TO SE CORNER FIRE LOOKOUT CABIN, 15.2 FEET.  TO NE CORNER, 5.5 FEET.  TO NW CORNER, 15.3 FEET.  FROM MONADNOCK R.M. NO. 7, 1937, REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS 23.54 FEET, IN GEODETIC AZIMUTH 327 DEG 24 MIN 39 SEC.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 48.55 FEET, IN GEODETIC AZIMUTH 348 DEG 45 MIN 04 SEC.  TO NE CORNER FIRE LOOKOUT CABIN, 35.5 FEET.  NW CORNER, 23.8 FEET.  SW CORNER, 31.0 FEET.  FIVE 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLES WERE FOUND IN THE LEDGE IN THE NW QUADRANT, AT FOLLOWING DISTANCES FROM THE STATION, PROCEEDING FROM W TOWARD N.  2.00 FEET, 1.77 FEET, 1.96 FEET, 1.98 FEET, 1.15 FEET.  A 10-FOOT TOWER WAS USED IN 1937 FOR THE NORTHERN ARC TRIANGULATION, AND AFFORDED A CLEAR VIEW IN ALL DIRECTIONS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM JAFFREY, FOLLOW ROAD TO MARLBORO WESTERLY FOR ABOUT 5 MILES TO ITS HIGHEST POINT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW PRIVATE TOLL ROAD NORTHERLY FOR 1.3 MILES TO HALF WAY HOUSE.  FROM THERE, THE WELL-MARKED WHITE ARROW TRAIL LEADS TO THE SUMMIT, ABOUT A 3/4 HOUR STEEP CLIMB.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JBW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND THE STATION MARK AND FIVE ORIGINAL REFERENCE MARKS, MARKED BY DRILL HOLES IN ROCK, WERE FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARKS 6 AND 7, MARKED BY STANDARD REFERENCE DISKS SET IN BEDROCK, WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISK HAD BEEN REMOVED FROM REFERENCE MARK 8.  A CHECK OF THE DISTANCES AND DIRECTIONS TO REFERENCE MARKS 6 AND 7 SHOWED THE DISTANCES TO BE CORRECT BUT A DIFFERENCE OF 3 FT WAS FOUND IN THE DIRECTIONS.  THE OLD DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 35 MILES WEST SOUTHWEST OF MANCHESTER, 33 MILES WEST NORTHWEST OF NASHUA, 3 MILES NORTH NORTHWEST OF JAFFREY AND ON THE HIGHEST PART OF MONADNOCK MOUNTAIN.  IT IS 5 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A SMALL LOW ROOF CABIN AND 10 FEET SOUTH OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF MOUNTAIN.  THE STATION MARK IS A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT HAS 5 LINES CHISELED IN BEDROCK THAT INTERSECT THE CENTER OF HOLE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 202 AND STATE HIGHWAY 124 IN JEFFREY, GO WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 124 FOR 5.1 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND SIGN TOLL ROAD, HALF WAY HOUSE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY ON TOLL ROAD FOR 1.3 MILES TO CABINS AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOLLOW FOOT TRAIL TO LEFT OF CABIN AND THEN NORTHERLY UP MOUNTAIN TO CABIN AT TOP OF MOUNTAIN AND STATION.  (THE TRAIL WAS MARKED WITH WHITE ARROWS ON ROCK AT THE TIME THE STATION WAS OCCUPIED.)  REFERENCE MARK NO. 6 IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK ON THE SOUTHWEST EDGE OF SUMMIT AND IS STAMPED MONADNOCK 6 1861.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 7 IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK AND IS STAMPED MONADNOCK 7 1861.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 8 IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK AND IS STAMPED MONADNOCK NO 8 1860 1959.  A STANDARD USGS DISK IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK SOUTHWEST OF THE STATION MARK 1.04 FEET 0.317 METERS WITH NO STAMPING ON DISK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 1 METER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1989)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NH DEPT OF TRANSP 1989 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN JAFFREY, 16.5 KM (10.25 MI) SOUTHEAST OF KEENE, 13.5 KM (8.40 MI) WEST OF PETERBOROUGH, 4.5 KM (2.80 MI) NORTHWEST OF JAFFREY CENTER, ON THE SUMMIT OF MONADNOCK MOUNTAIN. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE ROUTES 202 AND 124 IN JAFFREY, GO WEST FOR 3.4 KM (2.10 MI) ON ROUTE 124 TO A ROAD ON THE RIGHT TO MONADNOCK STATE PARK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 2.1 KM (1.30 MI) ON THE ROAD TO POOLE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST FOR 1.2 KM (0.75 MI) ON POOLE ROAD TO A PARKING AREA AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK ALONG THE WELL-MARKED TRAIL FOR 1 AND 3/4 HOURS TO THE TOP OF MONADNOCK MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION AT THE HIGHEST POINT. THE STATION IS A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK FROM WHICH 5 CHISELED LINES RADIATE, 0.317 M (1.040 FT) NORTHEAST FROM AN UNSTAMPED USGS BENCH MARK DISK. REFERENCE MARK 6 IS A STANDARD USGS DISK 26.60 FT (8.11 M) SOUTH FROM THE STATION. REFERENCE MARK 7 IS A STANDARD USGS DISK 33.76 FT (10.29 M) NORTHWEST FROM THE STATION. REFERENCE MARK 8 IS A STANDARD USGS DISK 19.11 FT (5.82 M) EAST FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1992)  RECOVERED 1992 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2008 (RG) THE STATION, THE 5 OLD  RM 1,2,3,4,5 DRILL HOLES, THE 3 DISKS RM 6,7,8 THE OLD BORDEN DRILL HOLE AND THE USGS DISK WERE ALL RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ALL DISTANCES WERE CHECK AND FOUND CORRECT WITHIN THE ACCURACY OF STEEL TAPE OVER UNEVEN GROUND (1 - 2 INCHES).  TO REACH DESCRIPTION IS CORRECT AS GIVEN IN 1989.  THE STATION IS A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK WITHIN A TRIANGLE WITH 5 LINES RADIATING FROM THE MARK.  A HOLE WITH AN IRON BOLT AND ANOTHER DRILL HOLE ARE ON EITHER SIDE OF THE STATION.  STATION MZ1474, AN UNSTAMPED USGS DISK IS ABOUT 1 FOOT SW OF THE STATION.  RM 1, 3, 3, 4, AND 5 ARE DRILL HOLES INSIDE CHISELED SQUARES WITH CHISELED ARROWS POINTING TO THE STATION.  THE SQUARE AROUND RM 4 IS WORN AWAY.  RM 6 IS A STANDARD USCGS DISK STAMPED MONADNOCK 1861 6.  THE SURFACE IS HIGHLY ERODED AND THE STAMPING IS HARD TO READ.  RM 7 IS A STANDARD USCGS DISK STAMPED MONADNOCK 1861 7.  THE FINAL '1' IN 1861 HAS A '0' CROSSED OUT AND A '1' OVERSTAMPED, AND THE RM NUMBER HAS AN '8' CROSSED OUT AND A '7' OVERSTAMPED.  RM 8 IS A STANDARD USCGS DISK STAMPED MONADNOCK NO 8 1860 1959.  THE BORDEN HOLE IS ABOUT 1 1/2 IN DIAMETER AND HAS A ROUNDED BOTTOM.  THERE ARE ERRORS IN THE ORIGINAL REPORT OF THE STATION WITH RESPECT TO THE LOCATIONS OF THE FIVE ORIGINAL REFERENCE MARKS (DRILL HOLES). THE 'FEET' FOR RM 1 IS INCORRECTLY CALCULATED FROM THE 'METERS', AND ONE LINE OF TEXT WAS DROPPED CAUSING THE AZIMUTH FOR  RM  3 AND THE DISTANCE FOR RM 4 TO BE MISSING. THE CORRECT LOCATIONS, TAKEN FROM CGS SPECIAL PUBLICATION NO. 76 'TRIANGULATION IN MASSACHUSETTS' (1922) ARE AS FOLLOWS - NO. 1, DISTANT 11.52 METERS (37.80 FEET), IN AZIMUTH 4 DEG 21 MIN, NO. 2, DISTANT 10.78 METERS (35.37 FEET), IN AZIMUTH 32 DEG 59 MIN, NO. 3, DISTANT 5.12 METERS (16.80 FEET), IN AZIMUTH 83 DEG 26 MIN, NO. 4, DISTANT 2.71 METERS (8.89 FEET), IN AZIMUTH 190 DEG 53 MIN, NO. 5, DISTANT 5.43 METERS (17.81 FEET), IN AZIMUTH 272 DEG 10 MIN.  RANGE HOLES - COMPARISON OF THE AZIMUTHS FOR THE REFERENCE MARKS WITH THAT OF OTHER PRIMARY STATIONS SURVEYED AT THE TIME, SHOWS RM 1 IS ON RANGE TO STATION BALD HILL (LX4700), AND RM 2 IS ON RANGE TO STATION MOUNT TOM (MZ1808).  RM  3, 4 AND 5 WERE NOT FOUND TO BE ON RANGE TO ANY IDENTIFIABLE STATIONS.  RANGE LINES - COMPARISON OF THE AZIMUTHS OF THE FIVE RANGE LINES RADIATING FROM THE STATION DRILL HOLE, MEASURED FROM PHOTOGRAPHS, SHOW THE FIVE LINES TO BE ON RANGE TO THE FIVE PRIMARY STATIONS OBSERVED FROM THIS STATION IN THE ORIGINAL SURVEY. STARTING FROM THE MOST NORTHERLY POINTING RANGE LINE, GOING CLOCKWISE, THESE ARE - STATION GUNSTOCK (OC1335), STATION UNKONOONUC (MY3800), STATION WACHUSETT (MY3791), STATION BALD HILL (LX4700) AND STATION MOUNT TOM (MZ1808).
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JBW) SEE STATION MONADNOCK                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 STATION HAS GOUGES AND NICKS ON IT                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2008 (RG) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE TO REACH DESCRIPTION IS CORRECT AS GIVEN IN 1989 FOR STATION MZ1473.  THE STATION IS AN UNSTAMPED USGS DISK IS ABOUT 1 FOOT SW OF THE STATION MZ1473.  SEE THAT STATION LOG FOR DETAILS.  THE MONUMENTATION DATE FOR THIS STATION IS GIVEN AS 1957.  HOWEVER THE 1932 LOG FOR THE CGS STATION MONADNOCK (MZ1473) SPECIFIES THAT THIS STATION WAS MONUMENTED IN 1931.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF HANOVER.  LAND IS OWNED BY SAMUEL WARD.  SIGNAL IS ON HIGHEST POINT ON LEDGE, SET WITH BOLT AND GUYS, ABOUT 3/4 MILE W FROM HOUSE OF WM. L. HARRIS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (CWM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS A DRILL HOLE IN A LEDGE OUTCROP ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A 1560 FT KNOLL ON THE SOUTHERN END OF MOOSE MOUNTAIN. THE STATION IS 5 PACES NORTH OF A CHISELED INSCRIPTION, C.F. CROSS, 1920, AND IS IN THE CENTER OF 3 GUY ANCHOR HOLES, TWO OF WHICH CONTAIN STEEL GUY PEGS.  TO REACH THE STATION, FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. ROUTE 4 AND 4A, PROCEED EASTERLY ALONG U.S. ROUTE 4, 1.1 MILES TO AN ASPHALT ROAD IN MASCOMA, N.H. GO NORTH ON THIS ROAD FOR 1.25 MILES TO A WHITE HOUSE ON A HILL.  TURN RIGHT INTO THE DRIVEWAY AND FOLLOW TO A FIELD ROAD LEADING FROM THE HOUSE.  GO 0.55 MILES IN A SOUTHERLY DIRECTION ALONG THE FIELD ROAD TO A BREAK IN A STONE WALL.  THEN PACK IN AN EASTERLY DIRECTION FOR APPROXIMATELY 1/2 MILE TO A LEDGE OUTCROP.  PROCEED EASTERLY DOWN A DIP, THEN CLIMB TO A MORE ELEVATED LEDGE OUTCROP AND THE STATION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1878 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF BROOKFIELD.  TO REACH FROM MIDDLETON VILLAGE, BY ROAD TO WOLFBORO, TO THE HOUSE OF B.C. PERKINS.  THENCE TO SUMMIT WHICH IS LEDGY.  STATION IS MARKED BY BOLT AND TRIANGLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1980 (KG) NOT RECOVERABLE.  SUMMIT SEARCHED THROUGHLY.  POSSIBLE EVIDENCE MARK WAS DESTROYED. ROCK CHIPPED AND BROKEN AWAY.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--3 MILES WEST OF SANBORNVILLE, N.H.
markers.setting: SET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) THIS MOUNTAIN IS IN THE NE PART OF HANOVER AND IS REACHED FROM EAST HANOVER BY THE ROAD LEADING TO THE NORTH NEIGHBORHOOD SO CALLED, THENCE TURNING TO THE RIGHT TO THE HOUSE OF CARLETON CAMP, WHO LIVES ABOUT 3/4 MILE FROM THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN. LAND IS OWNED BY RUFUS CAMP OF HANOVER.  A CART ROAD LEADS NEARLY TO THE TOP FROM CARLETON CAMPS HOUSE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY AN IRON BOLT SET IN THE LEDGE.  N OF THE STATION 17 FEET AN ARROWHEAD POINTING TO THE STATION IS CUT IN THE ROCK.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF BENTON.  LAND WAS LEASED BY JAMES CLEMENT FOR 99 YEARS.  TO REACH MOUNTAIN LEAVE B.C. AND M. RAILROAD AT WARREN, THENCE TO TOP BY CARRIAGE ROAD.  HOUSE ON TOP.  SIGNAL IS 18-3/4 FEET FROM SE CORNER OF HOUSE.  THE ABOVE SIGNAL WAS OBSERVED UPON FROM CARDIGAN AND PROSPECT AND WHEN THE STATION WAS OCCUPIED IT WAS MOVED TO A POINT S OF HOUSE AND THE POINTINGS FROM CARDIGAN AND PROSPECT REDUCED TO NEW STATION.  THE NEW STATION IS ON LARGE FLAT ROCK, BURIED IN GROUND AND RESTING ON LEDGE, MARKED BY TRIANGLE, SIDES ABOUT A FOOT, WITH A BOLT IN CENTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FOREST SERVICE 1959 (FSB) THE BOLT MARKING THIS STATION HAS BEEN BROKEN OFF FLUSH WITH THE GROUND LEVEL AND SETS IN A CHISELED TRIANGLE 1.1 FOOT ON A SIDE.  IT LIES S 83 DEG 02 MIN W, 18.77 FEET (HOR. DIST.) FROM MOOSILAUKE 2 USC AND GS 1958.  POINT IS FURTHER IDENTIFIED BY TWO ADDITIONAL BOLTS, ONE INTACT AND ONE BROKEN OFF FLUSH WITH GROUND LEVEL AT DISTANCES OF 12.40 FEET AND 11.33 FEET RESPECTFULLY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 (DKA) MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2016 (CDH) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SUMMIT OF MOOSILAUK MOUNTAIN APPROXIMATELY 7.5 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF WARREN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 23 AND 118 ABOUT 1.0 MILE NORTH OF WARREN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 118 FOR 2.5 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AND SIGN MOOSILAUKE INN.  TURN LEFT, CROSS BRIDGE, AND FOLLOW BLACKTOP ROAD FOR 1.5 MILES TO THE END OF BLACKTOP AND THE ENTRANCE TO THE MOOSILAUKE INN.  THIS IS THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR 2-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCKS.  WITH 4-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ALONG OLD CARRIAGE ROAD FOR APPROXIMATELY 5.0 MILES TO THE SUMMIT OF MOOSILAUK MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION. THE ROAD IS VERY ROCKY IN PLACES AND CHAINS MAY BE NEEDED TO DRIVE TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN.  THERE IS WATER AND A CABIN AT THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOOSILAUK 2 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET.  IT IS 33.5 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF OLD ROCK FOUNDATION AND 30.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A TRAIL MARKER SIGN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOOSILAUK 2 NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES.  IT IS 16 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF OLD ROCK FOUNDATION AND 18.5 FEET NORTH OF TRAIL MARKER SIGN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOOSILAUK 2 NO 2 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 1 FOOT.  IT IS 73 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF OLD ROCK FOUNDATION.  AZIMUTH MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MOOSILAUK 2 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  IT IS 10 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE OLD CARRIAGE ROAD AND 4 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A ROCK CAIRN WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION, FOLLOW OLD CARRIAGE ROAD SOUTHWEST FOR ABOUT 0.6 MILES TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT NEAR A ROCK CAIRN.  THERE ARE SEVERAL CAIRNS ALONG THIS ROAD AND IT MAY BE HARD TO FIND THE RIGHT ONE.  THE CAIRN NEAR THE AZIMUTH MARK DOES NOT HAVE PAINT ON IT AS DO SOME OF THE OTHERS.  THE OLD STATION, MOOSILAUK 1873, WAS NOT FOUND ON THE FIRST VISIT BY THE OBSERVING PARTY AND DUE TO BAD WEATHER ALL OBSERVING WAS DISCONTINUED AT THIS STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1971 (LBN) DISTANCES TO REFERENCE MARKS ARE INCORRECT. DISTANCE FROM MOOSILAUK 2 TO RM 1 IS 48.26 FEET. DISTANCE FROM MOOSILAUK 2 TO RM 2 IS 50.23 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 (DKA) FOUND STATION AND RM1                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2016 (CDH) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1878 (ETQ) TO REACH THE STATION GO FROM EAGLE HOTEL, GORHAM, ACROSS THE PEABODY RIVER ON THE KING AND QUEEN POST HIGHWAY BRIDGE.  CROSS THE GRAND TRUNK RAILROAD.  TURN TO THE RIGHT THROUGH A GATE INTO HITCHCOCKS PASTURE.  FOLLOW THE LOGGING ROAD TO A SMALL BROOK.  THEN TURN TO THE LEFT ALMOST AT A RIGHT ANGLE.  AFTER ENTERING THE WOODS KEEP THE ROAD THAT GRADUALLY BEARS TO THE RIGHT, PASS A SMALL SPRING TO THE LEFT, FOLLOW THE SPOTTED TREES OVER 2 OR 3 BARE LEDGES, PASS A SPRING OF COLD WATER ABOUT 2/3 OF THE WAY UP.  A SMALL STREAM OF WATER RUNS DOWN THE PATH ABOUT 20 RODS FROM THE SUMMIT.  THE VALLEY SE OF SUMMIT HAS A COLD SPRING REACHED BY A PATH.  STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT, WHICH IS QUITE SMOOTH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1921 STATION IS ON A SMOOTH GRANITE TOP BUT LITTLE HIGHER THAN A SPRUCE COVERED SUMMIT 100 FEET FARTHER W.  THE STATION WAS DISTINGUISHED BY A COLLECTION OF BOULDERS COLLECTED ON THE TOP AND A CANISTER CONTAINING AN APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN CLUB REGISTER. BENEATH THE BOULDERS AND APPROXIMATELY ON THE TRUE SUMMIT WAS A DRILL HOLE ABOUT 1 INCH IN DIAMETER.  ENLARGED CREVICES IN THE ROCK INDICATED WHERE THE LEGS OF THE ORIGINAL SIGNAL HAD BEEN PLACED, WHILE NUMEROUS IRON PINS WEDGED INTO DRILL HOLES WITH CUT NAILS INDICATED WHERE THE ORIGINAL GUY LINES HAD BEEN FASTENED.  A TRIPOD 3.02 METERS IN HEIGHT WAS ERECTED OVER THE STATION.  THE ASCENT CAN BE MADE BY TRAIL FROM GORHAM, VIA MT. SURPRISE OR USE CAN BE MADE OF AN OLD LOGGING ROAD THAT LEAVES THE GORHAM GLEN HOUSE ROAD ABOUT 2 MILES FROM GORHAM.  THIS ROAD LEADS TO THE SADDLE BETWEEN IMP MOUNTAIN AND MT. MORIAH.  THE TRAIL TO THE STATION LEADS TO THE LEFT FROM THE SADDLE AND IS MARKED BY SIGNS PLACED BY THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN CLUB.  NOTE--COPIED FROM A LETTER T.P. PENDLETON, U.S.G.S. DATED AUGUST 25, 1921.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE LETTER FROM T.P. PENDLETON, U.S.G.S., DATED AUGUST 25, 1921.  A STANDARD TRIANGULATION STATION DISK WAS CEMENTED IN THE DRILL HOLE OF STATION MORIAH 1878.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE ESTABLISHED BY THIS PARTY.  DUE TO THE CHANGES IN THE LOCALITY A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF GORHAM, ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. MORIAH AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE U.S. FORESTRY DEPT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 2 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16 ON THE EAST EDGE OF GORHAM, GO SOUTH ON STATE HIGHWAY 16 FOR 1.8 MILES TO THE BRIDGE OVER THE PEABODY RIVER, CONTINUE SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 16 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT AT SIGN MORIAH BRK. TRAIL.  TURN LEFT ON DIRT ROAD AND GO 0.1 MILE TO A FORK, TAKE RIGHT FORK FOR ABOUT 100 YARDS TO AN OLD ROTTEN BRIDGE AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  (IF YOU COULD GET A 4-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK OVER THIS BRIDGE YOU COULD DRIVE FOR ABOUT 1.5 MILES ALONG OLD TRACK ROAD.) FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL, CROSS BRIDGE AND FOLLOW DIM TRACK ROAD FOR ABOUT 0.5 MILE TO A DIM FORK, TAKE RIGHT FORK STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR ABOUT 2.0 MILES TO A FORK IN THE TRAILS AT SIGN ON LEFT MORIAH BROOK TRAIL - 2.6 PINKHAM NOTCH HWY., CARTER MORIAH TRAIL 0.9.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW TRAIL FOR 0.9 MILE TO THE SADDLE BETWEEN IMP MOUNTAIN AND MT. MORIAH, TURN LEFT ON CARTER MORIAH TRAIL AND GO ABOUT 1.0 MILE TO A TRAIL LEFT WHICH IS ABOUT 50 YARDS NORTH OF THE SUMMIT OF MT. MORIAH AND WHERE THE MAIN TRAIL TURNS RIGHT DOWN HILL, TURN LEFT AND GO ABOUT 50 YARDS TO THE SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  (3-1/2 HOUR PACK).  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MORIAH 1878 1958.  IT IS CEMENTED IN THE DRILL HOLE OF STATION MORIAH 1878, ON TOP OF A LARGE MASS OF OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH IS THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MORIAH NO 1 1878 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK ABOUT 8 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MORIAH NO 2 1878 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  NOTE--THIS STATION WILL BE KNOWN AS MORIAH 1878 1958 HEREAFTER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (CBP) STATION MARK FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS NO. 1 AND NO. 2 ALSO FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK FOUND. UNRESTRICTED 360 DEG VIEW, AS TREES HAVE BEEN CUT AWAY.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) CHURCH IS WHITE WITH 2-STORY BELFRY.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1878 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THOMPSONS AND MESERVES PURCHASE.  A HIGH, SHARP, BARE SUMMIT OF THE PRESIDENTIAL RANGE.  A PATH, A LITTLE LESS THAN 4 MILES LONG, STARTS FROM C.E. LOWES ON ROAD FROM GORHAM TO JEFFERSON HILL, HALF-WAY.  STATION CUT IN THE ROCK BY MEMBERS OF THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN CLUB BUT HAS NOT BEEN INSPECTED.  THIS IS THE POINT HELIOTROPED FROM.  NEARBY IS A STOUT SIGNAL POLE ERECTED BY MEMBERS OF THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN CLUB IN 1877, BUT WITH NO PERMANENT MARK UNDER IT.  THERE IS ALSO A VERY SMALL POLE WHICH HAS STOOD NEARBY FOR YEARS.  DISTANCE FROM MT. WASHINGTON CHIMNEY IS ABOUT 5,620 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (DKA) I FOUND A DRILLHOLE IN A BOULDER WITH A BOLT WITH A HOLE DRILLED IN THE CENTER OF IT ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN. THERE IS NO RECORD OF SUCH A BOLT ON THE DATA SHEET SO I DO NOT KNOW IF IT IS IN THE ORIGINAL BM LOCATION.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) TOP OF HILL IS LEDGE ON HIGHEST POINT OF WHICH SIGNAL IS SET. MOUNTAIN IS ON DIRECT ROAD FROM HENNIKER TO BRADFORD 2-1/2 MILES FROM THE FORMER.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1874 (ETQ) STATION IS ON UNGRANTED LANDS.  THE STATION IS 5 RODS FROM HIGHEST PART AND 8 FEET FROM DEEP GULF, MARKED WITH BOLT AND TRIANGLE.  TO REACH GO 11 MILES E FROM CAMPTON VILLAGE TO GREELYS MOUNTAIN HOTEL (TOWN OF WATERVILLE).  THEN 5 MILES NE VIA BRIDLE PATH TO TOP.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1943 (GBG) THIS STATION WAS NOT FOUND AFTER A THOROUGH SEARCH, ALTHOUGH THREE OF A PROBABLE FOUR ANCHOR BOLTS FOR GUY WIRES FOR SIGNAL WERE FOUND.  ROCK IS SEVERELY WEATHERED HERE AND IT IS PROBABLE THAT THE MARK HAS DISINTEGRATED.  THE PROBABLE POINT OF THE OLD MARK IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 FEET FROM THE U.S.G.S. STATION OSCEOLA 2.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1878 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THOMPSON AND MESERVES PURCHASE, ABOUT 680 METERS W OF MAIN SUMMIT.  POINT CUT IN HEAVY ROCK FORMING TOP OF STONE CAIRN, AND HELIOTROPED FROM.  CHAS. E. LOWE, RANDOLPH, WOULD BE THE MAN TO HAVE CHARGE OF SIGNAL.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5.0 MILES NORTHWEST OF BERLIN, 0.75 MILE SOUTHEAST OF THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 110 AND THE MILAN - BERLIN TOWN LINE, 0.15 MILE SOUTH OF STATE ROUTE 110 IN A CLEARING AT THE HIGHEST PART OF A LOW HILL.  STATION IS REACHED AS FOLLOWS--FROM THE COSTELL HOTEL, IN BERLIN, GO NORTHWEST ON STATE ROUTE 110 FOR 5.0 MILES TO POWER POLE 128/127 ON THE LEFT AT CREST OF RIDGE.  TURN LEFT AND GO THROUGH CLEARING 0.15 MILE TO TOP OF HILL AND STATION.  STATION IS A STANDARD U. S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK THAT IS ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 212.0 FEET NORTH NORTHWEST OF AN 8 INCH IN DIAMETER BIRCH TREE WITH A TRIANGULAR BLAZE THAT IS IN A FENCELINE.  R. M. NO. 1, STAMPED MOWING USGS NO 1 1959, IS A STANDARD USC AND GS BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ABOULDER THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  R. M. NO. 2, STAMPED MOWING USGS NO 2 1959, IS A STANDARD USC AND GS BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK THAT IS ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND ABOUT 1 FOOT BELOW STATION ELEVATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.43 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JJC) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY J. CHILDS OF GEODESY WHO OCCUPIED THIS STATION DURING THE SUMMER OF 1959.  THE STATION AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FOREST SERVICE 1965 (FSB) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 AT RYE BEACH. AT RYE BEACH, ROCKINGHAM COUNTY, 250 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE POST OFFICE AND SCHOOL, 114 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER LINE OF A BLACK TOP ROAD, 49 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE WEST CORNER OF A TWO-STORY WHITE FARMHOUSE, 32 FEET NORTHEAST OF A ROCK FENCE, AND IN THE TOP OF AN OUTCROPPING BOULDER.  A UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MR 2 1932.                            STATION RECOVERY (1990)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1990 (MG) MARK NOT FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2018)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2018 (JRO) DID NOT FIND A COMBINED POST OFFICE AND SCHOOL, ALTHOUGH ONCE A LONG-TIME RESIDENT POINTED OUT THE POST OFFICE AT 830 CENTRAL ROAD IN WHAT OTHERWISE APPEARS TO BE A RESIDENCE, I COULD HAVE GONE IN TO ASK. THE DESCRIPTION OF THIS MARK IN THE EXETER 15 MINUTE USGS PUBLICATION ON P. 4 CALLS FOR IT 650 FT (198.1 M) NORTHEAST OF CROSSROADS AS WELL AS 250 FT (76.2 M) NORTHEAST OF THE COMBINED P.O. AND SCHOOL.  THAT LOCATION ROUGHLY SCALES IN GOOGLE EARTH AT N 42 58 40, W 070 46 21, OR ABOUT 800 FT (243.8 M) NORTHEAST OF THE PRESENT PUBLISHED SCALED COORDINATES.  THOSE DISTANCES FALL IN ABOUT THE RIGHT PLACE TO BE AT THE CALLED-FOR DISTANCES SOUTHWEST OF THE FARMHOUSE CORNER AND NE OF THE ROCK FENCE.  HOUSE 804 IS AT THAT LOCATION, A LARGE HOUSE NORTH OF A CATHOLIC CHURCH.  WITH LIMITED TIME REMAINING I CHOSE NOT TO REQUEST PERMISSION TO ACCESS THE PROPERTY ON THIS VISIT.  THE DESCRIBED AREA APPEARS TO FALL IN A PLANTED AREA WHERE ONE MIGHT HAVE TO BE CAREFUL NOT TO DISTURB THE GARDEN.  NO BOULDER WAS OBVIOUS THERE.  THE USGS REFERENCE MARK TO THIS MARK, A CHISELED SQUARE IN THE LOWEST STEP, IS DESCRIBED AS BEING AT THE POST OFFICE AND TOWN HALL.  SO THE BUILDING APPARENTLY SERVED AT LEAST IN 1943 AS P.O., SCHOOL AND TOWN HALL.                            STATION RECOVERY (2018)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2018 (JRO) SEARCHED FOR, NOT FOUND, BELIEVE LOST.  THE TIES INTERSECT IN A GARDEN AREA ABOUT 5 FT (1.5 M) NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST EDGE OF THE DRIVEWAY TO 804 CENTRAL ROAD AT COORDINATES SCALED IN GOOGLE EARTH AS N 42 58 39.2, W 070 46 21.1 AND ENTERED AS SUCH IN THIS RECOVERY NOTE. AS BEST COULD BE DETERMINED, THE HOUSE AT THAT ADDRESS IS THE TWO-STORY WHITE FARMHOUSE REFERRED TO IN THE DESCRIPTION AND THE BUILDING HOUSING FORMER COMBINATION POST OFFICE AND SCHOOL, NOW ONLY POST OFFICE, IS AT 830 CENTRAL ROAD.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (NCS) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LITTLETON, 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BETHLEHEM AND ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. AGASSIZ.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A LARGE ROUNDED BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 18 INCHES.  IT IS STAMPED MT AGASSIZ 3 1965, IS 30 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE FIELD-STONE OBSERVATORY BUILDING AND 25 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER.  MT. AGASSIZ 2 R.M. 1, OUT OF THE WAY OF PROPOSED CONSTRUCTION, WAS LEFT INTACT.  THE ARROW DOES NOT POINT TO THE STATION. IT IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT WILL BE TO THE EAST OF THE NEW BUILDING.  R.M. 3 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT. AGASSIZ 3 R.M. 3 1965, SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT FORMS A STEP IN THE PATHWAY TO THE WEST DOOR OF THE OBSERVATION BUILDING.  IT IS 4.3 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE BUILDING.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (WMJ) THE STATION MARK, THE STEM FOR MT AGASSIZ 2, REFERENCE MARK 1, THE STEM FOR REFERENCE MARK 2 AND REFERENCE MARK 3 WERE RECOVERED.  THE DISTANCE TO MT AGASSIZ 2 AND TO REFERENCE MARK 3 FAILED TO AGREE WITH THE 1965 LIST.  A NEW AND COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LITTLETON, 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BETHLEHEM AND ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. AGASSIZ. IT IS JUST WEST OF THE OBSERVATION BUILDING.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 302 AND STATE HIGHWAY 142, IN BETHLEHEM, GO SOUTH ON STATE HIGHWAY 142 FOR 1.05 MILES TO THE MT AGASSIZ BASE HOUSE ON THE LEFT, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW MT AGASSIZ ROAD UP THE MOUNTAIN FOR 0.75 MILE TO THE OBSERVATION BUILDING AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MT AGASSIZ 3 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER PROJECTING 24 INCHES.  IT IS 30 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF BUILDING AND 25.4 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF BUILDING.  MT AGASSIZ 2 IS THE STEM OF THE ORIGINAL DISK, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP 3 INCHES UNDERGROUND.  IT IS 125 FEET NORTH-NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF BUILDING, 68 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE END OF THE BLACK TOP ROAD LEADING TO BUILDING AND 55 FEET NORTH OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF A CIRCLE DRIVEWAY.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MT AGASSIZ 2 NO 1 1958 SET IN THE TOP OF A SQUARE CONCRETE POST AND IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 44 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF CIRCLE DRIVEWAY AND 18 FEET WEST OF THE CENTER OF BLACK TOP ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS THE STEM OF THE ORIGINAL DISK, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND. IT IS 67.5 FEET NORTH-NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF BUILDING AND 33 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF CIRCLE DRIVEWAY.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A STANDARD DISK, STAMPED MT AGASSIZ 3 NO 3 1965, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER PROJECTING 12 INCHES.  IT IS 30.5 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF BUILDING AND 4.3 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF BUILDING.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 4 FEET.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BETHLEHEM
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SUMMIT OF BELKNAP MOUNTAIN WHICH IS APPROXIMATELY 5.25 MILES EAST OF LACONIA AND 3.0 MILES SOUTHEAST OF GILFORD.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE FROM TRIANGULATION STATION GUNSTOCK 1860 TO THE CENTER OF THE BASE OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER, DISTANCE BEING 56.54 FEET (17.233 METERS) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF STATION GUNSTOCK 1860.  THE LOOKOUT TOWER IS A SQUARE CABIN SUPPORTED BY FOUR LEGS AND IS APPROXIMATELY 35 FEET IN HEIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1978 (GEL) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1958. NEW MEASUREMENTS WERE MADE TO THE CENTER OF THE TOWER FROM STATION GUNSTOCK 1860 AND COMPARED FAVORABLE TO THE 1958 DATA.  SEE GUNSTOCK 1860.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS THE TOP CENTER OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER WHICH IS LOCATED ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. CARRIGAIN APPROXIMATELY 8 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF BARTLETT AND 12 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF NORTH WOODSTOCK.  THE LOOKOUT TOWER IS A SQUARE CABIN SUPPORTED BY FOUR LEGS AND IT IS APPROXIMATELY 35 FEET HIGH.  NOTE--THIS STATION WAS NOT VISITED BY THIS PARTY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (RG) NOT FOUND, PRESUMED DESTROYED.   THE OLD TOWER (BUILT IN 1940) WAS REPLACED IN 1982 WITH THE CURRENT TOWER AND THE MARK WAS THEREFORE LOST.  REMNANTS OF OLD CONCRETE WERE FOUND NEARBY WHICH WERE PROBABLY FROM THE FOUNDATION FOR THE OLD TOWER.   THE STATION MARK FOR PF0943 'CARRIGAIN 2' IS NO LONGER CENTERED UNDER THE CURRENT TOWER SO THE LOCATION OF THE OLD TOWER IS NOT THE SAME AS THAT OF THE CURRENT TOWER.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JBW) THE STATION IS A WOODEN POLE WITH TWO RED LIGHTS AT THE TOP, AND PAINTED IN ALTERNATE SECTIONS OF ORANGE AND WHITE, LOCATED ON A PROMINENT HILL ABOUT 1/2 MI. W OF THE KEENE AIRPORT AND ABOUT 2-1/2 MI. S OF KEENE.  THE POLE IS ABOUT 50 FT. HIGH.  THIS IS AN INTERSECTION STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (FBM) THE INTERSECTION STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED WITH THE ONE EXCEPTION--THERE IS BUT ONE RED LIGHT ON TOP OF THE POLE RATHER THAN THE TWO AS DESCRIBED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION. THE LOCAL AIRPORT AUTHORITY STATES THAT THERE WAS BUT ONE LIGHT ORIGINALLY PLACED ON THE POLE AND THAT THERE HAS NEVER BEEN TWO.  OBSERVATIONS TAKEN FROM TRIANGULATION STATION HUGGINS 1957 GAVE A CHECK OF 2 SECONDS TO THE LIGHT ON TOP OF THE POLE, WHEREAS OBSERVATIONS TO THE POLE MISSED CHECKING THE AZIMUTH BY APPROXIMATELY 20 SECONDS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1974 (BGH) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1979)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1979 (RPD) STATION DID NOT GET GOOD AZIMUTH CHECKS.  GOOD POSSIBILITY IT HAS LISTED SOME MORE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--0.5 MILES WEST OF KEENE AIRPORT.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. KEARSARGE NORTH WHICH IS APPROXIMATELY 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF NORTH CONWAY.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE TO THE CENTER OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER FROM TRIANGULATION STATION TOP, DISTANCE BEING 27.27 FEET (8.312 METERS) NORTH-NORTHEAST OF STATION TOP.  THE LOOKOUT IS A SQUARE CABIN SUPPORTED BY FOUR LEGS AND IS APPROXIMATELY 35 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1976)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1976 (JLO) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY W.E.R. IN 1958. THE TOWER IS NOW ABANDONED BUT STILL IN GOOD CONDITION. A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE TO THE CENTER OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER FROM TRIANGULATION STATION TOP, THE DISTANCE BEING 7.883 METERS.  DESCRIBED BY GREGORY S. NELSON                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1988 (JBD) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS THE TOP CENTER OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER WHICH IS LOCATED ON THE SUMMIT OF MT. OSCEOLA, APPROXIMATELY 7.5 MILES SOUTHEAST OF LINCOLN AND 7 MILES EAST-NORTHEAST OF FAIRVIEW.  THE LOOKOUT TOWER IS A SQUARE CABIN SUPPORTED BY FOUR LEGS AND IS APPROXIMATELY 35 FEET HIGH.  NOTE--THIS STATION WAS NOT VISITED BY THIS PARTY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2011 (EP) LOOKOUT TOWER HAS BEEN REMOVED.

BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1989 (JRO) THIS STATION WAS SET CLOSE ENOUGH IN 1989 TO THE POSITION OF THE USGS DISK FOUND IN 1958 AND NAMED MT WASH (PF0951) TO BE CALLED MT WASH RESET.   IT WAS APPARENTLY SET AT EXACTLY THE HEIGHT OF THE FORMER USGS MARK -6284-.  THAT MARK WAS DESCRIBED IN 1958 BY WER AS BEING CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SHARP-TOPPED BOULDER.  HOWEVER, THE PRESENT BOULDER IS ESSENTIALLY FLAT.  IT IS ABOUT 5 FT (1.5 M) EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE WOODEN POST HOLDING THE SIGN THAT MARKS THE SUMMIT, 6.65 FT (2.0 M) EASTERLY OF A RIVET DRILLED IN A ROCK ABOUT 2 FT (0.6 M) WEST OF THE SIGN POST AND ABOUT 2 FT (0.6 M) NORTH OF THE NORTH BOTTOM EDGE OF A LARGE STONE CAIRN.  NO INFORMATION WAS AVAILABLE FOR THE RIVET, WHICH IS WEST OF THIS MARK BUT ABOUT TWO FT (0.6 M) CLOSER TO IT THAN THE BOLT KNOWN AS MT WASHINGTON RESET (PF0950) WAS.  DISTANCES, NORTH AZIMUTH AND HEIGHT DIFFERENCE ARE LISTED TO OTHER DISKS ON THE SUMMIT.  MT WASHINGTON 4 - ON OBSERVATORY TOWER, FOR AZIMUTH ORIENTATION - 42.07 M (138.0 FT) - 333 DEG TO THE TOWER - HT DIFF NOT OBSERVED.   MT WASHINGTON RM 1 - 10.87 M (35.7 FT) - 33 DEG TO THE RM - AND 3.68 M (12.1 FT) ABOVE RM 1. MT WASHINGTON RM 2 - 13.72 M (45.0 FT) - 222 DEG TO THE RM - AND 2.49 M (8.2 FT) ABOVE RM 2.   MT WASHINGTON RM 3 - 10.11 M (33.2 FT) - 278 DEG TO THE RM - AND 1.26 M (4.1 FT) ABOVE RM 3.   MT WASHINGTON 3 - 25.97 M (85.2 FT) - 300 DEG TO THE STATION - AND 1.85 M (6.1 FT) ABOVE IT.   MT WASHINGTON 3 RM 2 - 12.49 M (41.0 FT) - 314 DEG TO THE RM - AND 0.79 M (2.6 FT) ABOVE THIS RM.                            STATION RECOVERY (2014)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2014 (JRO) THE MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AND USED IN A LEVELING PROJECT TO CONNECT THE USGS MARKS FROM 1925 EVERY MILE ALONG THE MOUNT WASHINGTON AUTO ROAD AND THE USGS AND NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY MARKS ON TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN TO NAVD88, LEVELING SOUTH FROM GORHAM ALONG RIGHT 16.  THE STAMPING IS FAINT AND THE DISK WAS MADE WITH AN UNUSUAL DIMPLE OR BUMP IN ITS MIDDLE.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS ABOUT 10 MILES SOUTHWEST OF GORHAM, ON THE SUMMIT OF MOUNT WASHINGTON, AND IS ON LAND OWNED BY DARTMOUTH COLLEGE.  TO REACH FROM THE SOUTHEAST JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 16 AND U.S. HIGHWAY 2 IN GORHAM, GO SOUTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 16 FOR 7.9 MILES TO THE GLEN HOUSE ON THE LEFT AND ENTRANCE TO MOUNT WASHINGTON TOLL ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  PASS THROUGH ENTRANCE AND FOLLOW THE TOLL ROAD, UP MOUNTAIN, FOR 7.9 MILES TO SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON 3 1958 IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 84.5 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE TIP TOP SNACK BAR, 32 FEET EAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF SNACK BAR AND 23.5 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF A DRAINAGE PIPE.  NO UNDERGROUND STATION MARK WAS SET.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON 3 NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 4 FEET BY 8 FEET.  IT IS 83 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF SNACK BAR AND 58 FEET NORTH OF DRAINAGE PIPE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON 3 NO 2 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 4 FEET BY 6 FEET.  IT IS 23.5 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE NOST NORTHERLY WATER TANK AND 21 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE DRAINAGE PIPE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 1851-1934, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON 1851 1934 NO 1, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 6 FEET BY 8 FEET.  IT IS ABOUT 6 FEET NORTH OF FOOT PATH IN ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 1851-1934, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON NO 2 1851 1934, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 2 FEET BY 3 FEET, THE DISK IS ON THE WEST SLOPE OF THE BOULDER.  IT IS 23.5 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE LARGEST WATER TANK AND 15 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF SNACK BAR.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 1851-1934, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON 1851 1934 NO 3, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE BOULDER WHICH SUPPORTS THE NORTH WATER TANK.  IT IS AT THE WEST SIDE OF A 12 INCH BY 12 INCH TIMBER, UNDER THE NORTH SIDE OF THE TANK.  MT WASHINGTON 1877, IS A COPPER BOLT 1 INCH IN DIAMETER CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A DEPRESSION IN THE ROCK.  IT IS UNDER THE LARGEST WATER TANK ABOUT 2 FEET FROM THE NORTHEAST SIDE.  MT. WASH. (USGS BM) IS A U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK STAMPED 6284 FT.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SHARP-TOPPED BOULDER WHICH MARKS THE HIGHEST POINT OF MOUNTAIN.  IT IS 1.4 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST SIDE OF THE LARGEST WATER TANK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 15 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1980 (CLN) THE STATION MARK, MT WASHINGTON 1877, MT WASH USGS AND THE 5 REFERENCE MARKS WERE ALL RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1958 DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR RECOVERY OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 (DKA) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2014)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2014 (JRO) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 13.3 MI (21.4 KM) SOUTHEAST OF JEFFERSON, 11.7 MI (18.8 KM) EAST OF TWIN MOUNTAIN AND 10.6 MI (17.1 KM) NORTHWEST OF JACKSON.  TO REACH, TAKE EITHER THE MOUNT WASHINGTON AUTO ROAD FROM NH 16 ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN OR THE COG RAILROAD FROM US 302 ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN.  IT IS 9.6 M (31.5 FT) EAST OF THE EAST ROOF LINE OF TIP TOP LODGE AND 1.25 M (4.1 FT) SOUTH OF THE NORTH ROOF LINE EXTENDED.  INVERSES - DISTANCE AND NORTH AZIMUTH - TO OTHER NEARBY MARKS ARE LISTED.  MT WASHINGTON 4 (PF0952) ON OBSERVATORY TOWER, 24.4 M (80.1 FT) - AZIMUTH FROM NORTH 8 DEGREES TO THE TOWER FOR AZIMUTH ORIENTATION. MT WASHINGTON REFERENCE MARK 1 (DA5227) - 28.46 M (93.4 FT) - 99 DEG TO THE RM. MT WASH RESET, USGS MARK BY SUMMIT SIGN AND ROCK CAIRN - 25.82 M (84.7 FT) - 121 DEG TO THE STATION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2014 (JRO) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 13.3 MI (21.4 KM) SOUTHEAST OF JEFFERSON, 11.7 MI (18.8 KM) EAST OF TWIN MOUNTAIN AND 10.6 MI (17.1 KM) NORTHWEST OF JACKSON.  NOTE-THIS MARK IS ON THE SUMMIT OF MOUNT.  WASHINGTON. markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1980 (CLN) THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED BY A CO-OPERATIVE EFFORT BY THE NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY AND MR. BRADFORD WASHBURN TO GET A POINT ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN FOR UN-OBSTRUCTED LINE OF SIGHT IN ALL DIRECTIONS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 16.1 KM (10 MI) SW OF GORHAM AND ON THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE TOWER OF THE NEW MT WASHINGTON OBSERVATORY ATOP THE SUMMIT OF MOUNT WASHINGTON.  THE STATION MARK STAMPED MT WASHINGTON 4 1980 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CENTER OF THE CONCRETE TOWER ON TOP OF THE MT WASHINGTON OBSERVATORY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 (DKA) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN A LARGE STRUCTURE WITH FOUNDATIONS ON BEDROCK

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1849 (TMD) THE APEX OF MOUNTAIN MAY BE ABOUT 3/4 ACRE IN EXTENT, A MASS OF LOOSE ROCK.  WITHIN THE SPACE ARE 2 SMALL ELEVATIONS ABOUT 50 FEET APART AND NEARLY OF SAME HEIGHT.  ON THE SOUTHWESTERN ONE A DRILL HOLE IN THE DEPRESSION OF A LARGE FLAT ROCK CONTAINS A COPPER BOLT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1871)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1871 (GAP) A SIGNAL WAS ERECTED ON MOUNT WASHINGTON.  MCDONNELLS STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED, BUT A NEW COPPER BOLT WAS SET, NOT ON THE VERY HIGHEST PART OF THE MOUNTAIN BUT IN A CREVICE NEAR THE SUMMIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1874)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1874 (GWD) IN 1868 MOUNT WASHINGTON WAS VISITED AND THE STATION FOUND, THE COPPER BOLT IN PLACE AS IN 1860.  IT IS PERHAPS 6 OR 8 FEET BELOW THE HIGHEST POINT.  BUT THERE SHOULD BE NO GREAT DIFFICULTY IN FINDING IT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1879)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1879 (RDC) THE POSITION IS MARKED BY 2 SEMI-CIRCLES, ONE UPON EACH SIDE OF ROOF, THE CENTER OF THE TWO BEING 13.67 FEET FROM THE FRONT END OF BUILDING AND 11.50 FEET FROM THE EAVES.  THREE 4-INCH SCREWS ARE SET IN THE CIRCUMFERENCE OF THE CIRCLE, FORMING AN EQUILATERAL TRIANGLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1897)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1897 (ATM) THE BOLT MARKING THE MOUNT WASHINGTON STATION WAS FOUND, AFTER THE REMOVAL OF A PORTION OF THE PLANK FLOOR OF THE OBSERVATORY, AND CONSIDERABLE RUBBISH UNDERNEATH IT.  THE BOLT IS COPPER, 1 INCH IN DIAMETER, PROJECTS ABOUT 1/4 INCH ABOVE THE ROCK AND HAS A TOP IN THE FORM OF A TRUNCATED CONE WHICH IS BUT SLIGHTLY MARRED.  IT IS IMBEDDED IN A SOLID DEPRESSION (NOT A CREVICE) OF WHAT AT FIRST APPEARS TO BE BEDROCK BUT WHICH IS PROBABLY ONLY A VERY LARGE ROCK JUDGING FROM THE OUTSIDE APPEARENCE OF THE SUMMIT.  THE DEPRESSION WHERE THE BOLT IS LOCATED IS 2-1/2 FEET BELOW AND ABOUT 5 FEET WNW FROM THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOVE THE FLOOR INTO THE OBSERVATORY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1921 AN ATTEMPT WAS MADE TO RECOVER THIS STATION, BUT IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO FIND POSITIVE EVIDENCE OF ITS EXACT POSITION.  TWO IRON PINS SUCH AS WERE FOUND ON MT. MORIAH WERE IN PLACE AND A HOLE IN THE ROCK THAT MAY HAVE CONTAINED THE STATION MARK WAS SEEN.  THE COPPER BOLT SUPPOSED TO MARK THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  A LARGE WATER TANK NOW COVERS THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THERE IS A POSIBILITY THAT THE SUMMIT WAS BLOWN OFF TO MAKE A SUITABLE FOUNDATION FOR IT.  NOTE--COPIED FROM A LETTER FROM T.P. PENDLETON, U.S.G.S. DATED AUGUST 25, 1921.                            STATION RECOVERY (1933)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1933 (HSS) RECOVERY NOTE OF H.S. SHAW--THE STATION IS WITHIN A FEW FEET OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND MAY BE REACHED BY A PRIVATE TOLL ROAD ON THE E SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN, OR BY A COG RAILROAD ON THE W SIDE.  THE ROAD, 8 MILES LONG, IS USUALLY PASSABLE FOR AUTOMOBILES FROM ABOUT JUNE 1, UNTIL IT IS BLOCKED BY SNOW IN THE FALL, AND THE RAILROAD IS IN OPERATION DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS ONLY.  NEAR THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN IS A WOODEN WATER TANK, ABOUT 22 FEET IN DIAMETER AND 16 FEET HIGH, SUPPORTED ON HEAVY TIMBERS. THESE TIMBERS REST ON THE ROCK AND ON HEAVY BLOCKS, BETWEEN TWO OF WHICH THE BOLT CAN BE SEEN ABOUT 2 FEET UNDER THE TANK.  THE BOLT APPEARS TO BE FIRMLY IN PLACE AND A CROSS IS STILL DISCERNIBLE ON ITS ROUNDED HEAD.  A U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK, STAMPED 6284 FEET MARKS THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCK AND THE BOLT BEARS A LITTLE S OF W FROM THE BENCH MARK, DISTANT AN INCH OR TWO MORE THAN 5 FEET, MEASURED ALONG THE SLOPE, THE ELEVATION OF THE BOLT BEING SOME 2 1/2 FEET BELOW THE BENCH MARK.  THESE MEASUREMENTS WERE MADE ONLY ROUGHLY, BECAUSE OF THE PRESENCE OF THE TANK.  THE VIEW FROM THE VICINITY OF THE STATION IS OBSTRUCTED BY BUILDINGS AND BY THE TANK, EXCEPT FROM ABOUT WNW THROUGH N TO ABOUT ENE.  IN THE GENERAL VICINITY OF THE STATION I FOUND SEVERAL IRON BOLTS, WHICH APPEARED TO HAVE ONCE SERVED AS ANCHOR BOLTS FOR THE OLD OBSERVATORY OR FOR OTHER STRUCTURES.  AT THE TIME OF MY VISIT, JUNE 4, 1933, THE FOLLOWING BUILDINGS WERE ON THE SUMMIT--SUMMIT HOUSE, A WOODEN HOTEL.  TIP TOP HOUSE, WITH WALLS OF LOOSE STONES AND A WOODEN ROOF, CONNECTED WITH THE SUMMIT HOUSE BY A COVERED PASSAGEWAY.  CAMDEN COTTAGE, A WOODEN BUILDING USED AS A CAMP BY CLIMBERS.  STAGE OFFICE, ALSO OF WOOD, USED BY PATRONS OF THE AUTO ROAD AND ALSO OCCUPIED AS A METEOROLOGICAL OBSERVATORY IN 1932-3, DURING THE INTERNATIONAL POLAR YEAR.  THERE IS ALSO A GARAGE JUST BELOW THE SUMMIT.  ALL THESE BUILDINGS HAVE BEEN BUILT SINCE JUNE 1908, WHEN A FIRE SWEPT THE SUMMIT AND DESTROYED EVERYTHING BUT THE STONE WALLS OF THE TIP TOP HOUSE. THE OBSERVATORY, OR TOWER, WHICH WAS SITUATED OVER THE STATION FOR MANY YEARS, IS SAID TO HAVE BEEN PULLED DOWN IN 1902.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1934 (KGC) THE COPPER BOLT MARKING THE STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED BY H.S. SHAW IN HIS NOTE OF 1933.  THE BOLT CHECKS THE DESCRIPTION OF C.C.Y., IN 1897 THE ONLY EXCEPTION NOTED WAS THAT IS SEEMS TO BE MORE NEARLY W THAN WNW (AS STATED IN HIS NOTE) FROM THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE MOUNTAIN, HOWEVER, ON ACCOUNT OF THICK WEATHER AN ACCURATE DIRECTION COULD NOT BE DETERMINED.  THE BOLT IS NOW UNDER A WOODEN WATER TANK.  THE TANK IS ABOUT 22 FEET IN DIAMETER AND 16 FEET IN HEIGHT AND IS SUPPORTED BY A CRIBBING OF 12- BY 12-INCH TIMBERS.  THE BOLT IS ABOUT 2 FEET UNDER THE NW SIDE OF THE TANK AND A PLUMB-BOB STRING SUSPENDED OVER IT CAN BE SEEN FROM SEVERAL PLACES ABOUT THE TANK.  THE BOLT IS 1 INCH IN DIAMETER, WITH SLIGHTLY FLATTENED HEAD AND WITH CROSS MARKS STILL VISIBLE ON IT.  IT PROJECTS ABOUT 1/4 INCH ABOVE THE ROCK AND IS IN A DEPRESSION IN THE ROCK 4-1/2 FEET NEARLY DUE W FROM THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN.  A U.S.G.S. BENCH MARK, E1. 6284 MARKS THE HIGHEST POINT, A SHARP-TOPPED BOULDER AS DESCRIBED BY C.C.Y., IN 1897.  THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN CONSISTS OF A MASS OF BOULDERS OF VARIOUS SIZES AND AT NO PLACE IS ONE ABLE TO DISTINGUISH SOLID LEDGE.  TO PRESERVE THE CENTER OF THE COPPER BOLT 3 STANDARD REFERENCE MARKS WERE INSTALLED, EACH ONE IN A LARGE BOULDER FIRMLY IMBEDDED IN THE GROUND.  FROM THESE REFERENCE MARKS THE CENTER MAY BE REPRODUCED BY THE ANGLES AND DISTANCES AS SHOWN ON THE FOLLOWING SKETCH.  IT IS LIKELY THAT A MORE PERMANENT WATER TANK MAY BE BUILT ON THE SUMMIT AND THE STATION MARK COVERED OR DESTROYED.  IN THAT CASE REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 CAN BE OCCUPIED AS AN ECCENTRIC STATION, IF IT IS NOT POSSIBLE TO REPRODUCE THE CENTER AND OCCUPY IT.  A 25-FOOT TOWER ON REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 WOULD CLEAR THE BUILDINGS AND TANK ON THE SUMMIT.  A CLEAR VIEW FROM THE GROUND AT REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 MAY BE HAD FROM ABOUT W TO ENE.  THE TOP OF THE TANK GIVES A CLEAR VIEW ALL AROUND THE HORIZON. THE SUMMIT OF THE MOUNTAIN IS READILY ACCESSIBLE DURING THE MONTHS JUNE TO OCTOBER BY PRIVATE TOLL ROAD AND COG RAILWAY.  NO TOLL WAS CHARGED FOR OUR VISIT.  DISTANCES SHOWN WERE MEASURED WITH STEEL TAPE IN METERS.  THE ANGLES SHOWN WERE MEASURED WITH A NEW ONE MINUTE TRANSIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1943 (GBG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN ORIGINAL AND VARIOUS RECOVERY NOTES.  THE REFERENCE MARKS ESTABLISHED IN 1934 WERE ALSO RECOVERED AND DISTANCES CHECKED.  A TACK WAS PLACED IN THE DECKING OVER THE TOP OF THE TANK DIRECTLY OVER THE STATION, BUT THE POINT WAS OCCUPIED ONLY FOR TURNING ANGLES TO THE U.S.G.S. STATION MT. WASHINGTON 2, WHICH IS THE STEEL RADIO TOWER ON THE SUMMIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION MARK AND ALL THREE REFERENCE MARKS AND THE USGS BM WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1934 DESCRIPTION OF K.G.C..  ALL MARKS WERE FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  DUE TO A SECOND WATER TANK WHICH HAS BEEN BUILT JUST WEST OF THE WATER TANK MENTIONED IN THE 1934 DESCRIPTION, THE MARKS ARE NOW USELESS.  SINCE NONE OF THE MARKS COULD BE USED A MT WASHINGTON 3 WAS ESTABLISHED AT A POINT FROM WHICH A TIE COULD BE MADE TO THE OLD STATION.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE FROM TRIANGULATION STATION MT WASHINGTON 3 TO TRIANGULATION STATION MT WASHINGTON 1877, DISTANCE BEING 81.54 FEET (24.852 METERS) SOUTHEAST OF STATION MT WASHINGTON 3.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2004 (DKA) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2014)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2014 (JRO) NOT RECOVERED.  NOTE-NO TRACE OF A COPPER BOLT IN THIS AREA EXISTS.  THE MARK WAS PROBABLY REMOVED ALONG WITH THE WATER TOWER THAT USED TO BE ABOVE IT.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1979 THE BASE LINE IS LOCATED NORTHWEST OF NASHUA IN THE MEDIAN STRIP BETWEEN THE MAIN RUNWAY AND THE TAXIWAY OF THE NASHUA MUNICIPAL AIRPORT.   THE 0 METER POINT IS NEAR THE SOUTHEAST END OF THE RUNWAY.  IT IS 135 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE MAIN RUNWAY, 92 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHERN EDGE OF THE TAXIWAY, 74.5 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE WESTERN EDGE OF THE END TAXIWAY AND 10 FEET SOUTHWEST OF TOPOGRAPHIC STATION AP STA B ASH 1973.   ALL OF THE MARKS ARE STANDARD CALIBRATION BASE LINE DISKS SET IN THE TOP OF 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENTS THAT ARE FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE.  ALL OF THE METER POINTS HAVE UNDERGROUND MARKS SET ABOUT 4.5 FEET BELOW THE SURFACE.   THE BASE LINE IS A NORTHWEST-SOUTHEAST LINE WITH THE 0 METER POINT ON THE SOUTHEAST END.  IT IS MADE UP OF THE 0, 150, 400, AND 1400 METER POINTS.  AN 800 METER POINT WAS SET BUT NOT TIED INTO THE BASE LINE.   THIS BASE LINE WAS ESTABLISHED IN CONJUNCTION WITH ALLAN H. SWANSON INCORPORATED AND THE NEW HAMPSHIRE LAND SURVEYORS ASSOCIATION.  FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT MR. ALLAN SWANSON, 3 CONGRESS STREET, NASHUA, NEW HAMPSHIRE 03060. TELEPHONE 603-883-2057.                            STATION RECOVERY (1998)  RECOVERY NOTE BY WOOLPERT CONSULTANTS 1998 (BBS) DESCRIBED BY WOOLPERT LLP 1998 (ARL) .  THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 9.3 KM (5.75 MI) SOUTH OF MERRIMACK, 4.7 KM (2.90 MI) WEST OF NASHUA AT THE BOIRE FIELD AIRPORT IN NASHUA.  OWNERSHIP--CITY OF NASHUA, C/O ROYCE RANKIN JR.  AIRPORT MANAGER, BOIRE FIELD / NASHUA AIRPORT, 93 PERIMETER ROAD, NASHUA NH 03063, PHONE NUMBER 603-882-0661.  CONTACT THE AIRPORT MANAGER A MINIMUM OF 24 HOURS PRIOR TO ENTRY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 3 (EXIT 7) AND STATE HIGHWAY 101A (AMHERST STREET) , PROCEED NORTHWEST 0.5 KM (0.30 MI) ALONG AMHERST STREET TO THE JUNCTION OF CHARON AVE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND PROCEED SOUTHWEST 0.5 KM (0.30 MI) ALONG CHARON AVENUE TO THE JUNCTION OF PINE HILL ROAD. TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED NORTHWEST 0.56 KM (0.35 MI) ALONG PINE HILL ROAD TO THE JUNCTION OF PERIMETER ROAD ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED NORTH 1.05 KM (0.65 MI) ALONG PERIMETER ROAD TO THE AVIATION AUTHORITY BUILDING AND A GATE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE BUILDING. CONTINUE THROUGH THE GATE AND PROCEED NORTHEAST 0.24 KM (0.15 MI) ALONG A RAMP TO THE JUNCTION OF A TAXIWAY.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED SOUTHEAST 0.24 KM (0.15 MI) ALONG THE TAXIWAY TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS CALIBRATION BASELINE DISK STAMPED--CBL 800--, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE STATION HAS AN UNDERGROUND MARK APPROXIMATELY 1.5 M (4.9 FT) BELOW THE SURFACE.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 14.00 M (45.93 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF NORTH 50 DEGREES EAST FROM THE MAIN TAXIWAY, 126.37 M (414.60 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF NORTH 44 DEGREES WEST FROM THE WEST EDGE OF TAXIWAY BRAVO, 40.69 M (133.50 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF SOUTH 50 DEGREES WEST FROM THE EDGE OF RUNWAY 17-32, 15.61 M (51.21 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF NORTH 53 DEGREES WEST FROM A USGS MONUMENT STAMPED--ARP ASH 1973--.  THIS STATION IS DESIGNATED AS THE PRIMARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1999)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1999 (LJL) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2009)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2009 (PT) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED

TOLMANS BY TEAM THROUGH FIELD AND PASTURE TO WITHIN 1/3 MILE FROM THE TOP.  THENCE MOSTLY THROUGH PASTURE.  STATION IS A LITTLE E OF SUMMIT AND A FEW FEET LOWER BECAUSE FROM THE HIGHEST POINT, MOUNTAINS CROTCHET AND MONADNOCK (SECONDARY STATIONS) COULD NOT BE SEEN.  STATION IS MARKED BY A HOLE DRILLED IN ROCK, AROUND WHICH IS DRILLED A TRIANGLE WHOSE W SIDE POINTS N.  WOODS ARE ON W, LOW SHRUBS ON THE OTHER SIDES.  S 22 DEG W, 35 FEET DISTANT, IS AN ARROWHEAD DRILLED IN ROCK, POINTING TO STATION.  AND ABOUT 32-1/2 FEET W IS A MAPLE TREE, PERHAPS 18 FEET HIGH.                            STATION RECOVERY (2003)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2003 (TSM) THE MARKER SETTING IS GIVEN AS BEING A ROCK OUTCROP A LITTLE EAST OF SUMMIT AND A FEW FEET LOWER... THERE IS PRESENTLY NO SIGNIFICANT EXPOSED OUTCROP ANYWHERE IN THE AREA. I SEARCHED OVER A THREE ACRE ZONE AND LIFTED THE MOSS FROM A FEW STONES WITHOUT FINDING THE BENCHMARK OR THE REFERENCE MARK SAID TO BE TO THE SSW OF IT. I COULD NOT IDENTIFY THE MAPLE TREE THAT WAS 18 FEET HIGH 130 YEARS AGO.

DODD IS 17.4 METERS (57 FEET) W OF STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (WFD) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS LOCATED ON THE GROUNDS OF DARTMOUTH COLLEGE IN HANOVER, ABOUT 200 FEET SOUTH OF BARTLETT TOWER (A CYLINDERICAL STONE TOWER, WITH OBSERVATION PLATFORM AND A CONICAL ROOF), AND 100 FEET EAST OF THE EASTERNMOST BUILDING OF THE ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATORY.  STATION MARK IS AN IRON PIN SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH.  IT IS 3/4-INCH DIAMETER AND PROJECTS 1/2 INCH FROM THE BOTTOM OF A 2-INCH DEPRESSION IN THE ROCK.  A RING OF FLAT STONES SURROUND THE STATION, FROM WHICH 6 FLATTENED IRON RODS PROJECT (ONE BROKEN), THE RODS EQUIDISTANT FROM ONE ANOTHER AND ALL ARE 4.9 FEET FROM THE STATION MARK.  THE RING OF STONES WAS THE FORMER FOUNDATION OF AN ORNAMENTAL WROUGHT-IRON BOWER OR SUMMER-HOUSE LONG SINCE REMOVED.  TWO 3/4-INCH ROUND IRON PINS, BOTH BENT AWAY FROM THE STATION, PROJECTS 4 INCHES FROM BEDROCK, ONE 18.4 FEET SOUTHEAST AND THE OTHER 16.6 FEET WEST OF THE MARK.  THERE IS ALSO A 3/4 INCH DRILL HOLE SUNK AT AN ANGLE 1.7 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE MARK.  TO REACH FROM THE TRAFFIC LIGHT AT MAIN AND WHEELOCK STREETS AT HANOVER, GO EAST ON WHEELOCK FOR 0.15 MILE TO A CROSSROAD, TURN LEFT AND GO UPGRADE FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE OBSERVATORY AND THE STATION IN THE REAR.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (DCW) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION BY W.F.D. IN 1964 IS ADEQUATE AND COMPLETE FOR RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1978)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1978 (DHB) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2006)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2006 (RAH) FOUND AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION, EXCEPT 2ND REFERENCE MARK IS LOCATED 11.6 FEET WEST, NOT 16.6 FEET. ALSO FOUND ADDITIONAL METAL LOOP IN BEDROCK ABOUT 11.5 FEET TO THE NORTHWEST.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY VERMONT GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 (CHR) GENERAL LOCATION, HANOVER, NH.  TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF NH ROUTE 10 (MAIN STREET) AND NH ROUTE 10A (WHEELOCK STREET), GO EAST ALONG NH ROUTE 10 FOR 0.15 MI (0.2 KM) TO THE INTERSECTION OF CROSBY STREET RIGHT AND OBSERVATORY ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHEAST ALONG OBSERVATORY ROAD FOR 0.1 MI (0.2 KM) TO THE MAIN OBSERVATORY BUILDING AND THE SITE OF THE MARK ON THE RIGHT.  THE MARK IS A 2 CM (1 INCH) DIAMETER IRON PIN SET IN THE TOP OF A MASSIVE ROCK OUTCROP WHICH IS SURROUNDED BY A RING OF SIX FLAT, EMBEDDED GRANITE BLOCKS.  THE PIN PROJECTS 1 CM (0 INCH) ABOVE THE BOTTOM OF A 4 CM (2 INCH) TRIANGULAR DEPRESSION IN THE TOP OF THE OUTCROP.  IT IS 9.2 M (30.2 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE HEAD OF THE BRONZE ROBERT FROST SEATED STATUE, 23.9 M (78.4 FT) EAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE MOST NORTHEASTERLY BRICK BUILDING IN THE OBSERVATORY COMPLEX, 3.5 M (11.5 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF A 10 CM (4 INCH) DIAMETER IRON ANCHOR DRIVEN INTO THE OUTCROP, 5.6 M (18.4 FT) EAST OF A BENT 16 MM (0.6 INCH) DIAMETER IRON ROD DRIVEN INTO THE OUTCROP, 5.6 M (18.4 FT) NORTHWEST OF ANOTHER BENT 16 MM (0.6 INCH) DIAMETER IRON ROD DRIVEN INTO THE OUTCROP, 64.8 M (212.6 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTH-SOUTHWEST SIDE OF THE BARTLETT CYLINDRICAL STONE MASONRY TOWER AND 0.4 M (1.3 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE MOST SOUTHWESTERLY OF TWO DRILL HOLES IN THE OUTCROP.

ON HIGHWAY 1A ABOUT 4 MILES SE OF PORTSMOUTH AND ABOUT 1/4 MILE S OF CONCORD POINT.  A LARGE 3-STORY WHITE FRAME BUILDING WITH GREEN SHUTTERS.  THE BUILDING HAS A STRIP OF RED SHINGLES ON ROOF.  THE UPPER SECTION OF ROOF HAS BLACK SHINGLES.  A PORCH IS ON E AND S SIDE OF FIRST FLOOR.  CUPOLA IS PYRAMIDAL SHAPE WITH AN OBSERVATION PLATFORM ON TOP AND FLAGPOLE IN CENTER. ROOF OF CUPOLA IS RED-SHINGLED.  A WINDOW IS ON EACH FACE OF CUPOLA.  BUILDING IS ABOUT 300 FEET W OF OCEAN.  THERE IS NO NAME ON BUILDING. N OF A GRAVEL ROAD AND TELEPHONE LINE LEADING TO TWO HOUSES ON THE EXTREME END OF THE POINT, AND ABOUT 300 FT. S OF A TWO-STORY FRAME RESIDENCE. HIGHER THAN THE SURROUNDING GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS W AND REFERENCE MARK 2 IS N OF THE STATION.
