STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION SUBMITTED BY P.L.B. IN 1941 IS ADEQUATE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS 37.10 FT. (11.308 M.) SW OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS 28.88 FT. (8.802 M.) N OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 2.6 MI SE FROM PORTSMOUTH. 2.6 MILES SOUTHEAST ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 1 A FROM THE MASONIC TEMPLE AT PORTSMOUTH, ROCKINGHAM COUNTY, THENCE 1.3 MILES NORTHEAST ALONG OLD STATE HIGHWAY 1 A, 0.15 MILE WEST OF THE EXTREME END OF ODIORNES POINT, AT THE T-JUNCTION OF A GRAVEL ROAD LEADING EAST TO THE END OF THE POINT, 165 FEET EAST OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE HIGHWAY, 50 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER LINE OF THE ROAD, 100 YARDS NORTH OF THE SHORE, AND IN THE TOP OF OUTCROPPING LEDGE ROCK.  A CORPS OF ENGINEERS, U.S. ARMY, STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ODIORNES PT 143 1941.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION AND THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCES TO THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE MEASURED WITH A STEEL TAPE AND THE DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS FOUND TO BE IN AGREEMENT WITH THE MEASUREMENT IN THE 1943 RECOVERY NOTE BY P.L.B.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE AND CORRECT WITH THE FOLLOWING EXCEPTIONS--  THE TWO-STORY FRAME RESIDENCE AND THE TELEPHONE LINE NO LONGER EXIST.  THE STATION IS ON THE GROUNDS OF FORT DEARBORN, 171.0 FT. NE OF THE S FENCE POST OF THE MOST S GATE TO THE RESERVATION, AND 50.5 FT. N OF THE CENTER OF A GRAVEL ROAD. IT IS A CORPS OF ENGINEERS, U.S. ARMY, STANDARD DISK, STAMPED ODIORNES PT 143 1941.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED ODIORNES PT NO 1 1941 143.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED ODIORNES PT NO 2 1941 143.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (WD) FORT DEARBORN IS NOW THE ORDIORNES POINT STATE PARK.  THE STATION IS MOUNTED IN A LOW, OVERGROWN ROCK OUTCROPPING IN AN AREA OF THE PARK THAT IS NOT MAINTAINED.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE MAIN DRIVEWAY ENTRANCE TO THE PARK, WALK SOUTHEAST AND SOUTH FOR 470 FEET ON A PAVED BIKE PATH THAT PARALLELS THE HIGHWWAY TO A SMALL CLEARING AMONG SEVERAL LARGE PINE TREES ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND WALK EAST THROUGH THE CLEARING FOR 90 FEET TO THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2007 (JLH) STATION, RM 1, AND RM 2 ALL RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2017)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2017 (JRO) THE MARK IS AT ODIORNES PT STATE PARK, ABOUT 500 FT (152.4 M) SOUTHERLY FROM THE ENTRANCE ROAD.  THE MARK AND BOTH RMS WERE RECOVERED USING THE 2005 RECOVERY NOTE AND GPS TO GET IN THE AREA.  A SMALL CAIRN WAS BUILT ABOUT A FOOT NORTH OF EACH MARK.  THE MAIN STATION IS LOWER AND IN A SMALLER OUTCROP THAN THE TWO RMS, A REVERSAL OF THE USUAL SITUATION.  IT IS 100 FT (30.5 M) EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE WEST END OF THE SOUTHERLY OF TWO IRREGULAR STONE WALLS THAT RUN APPROXIMATELY EAST-WEST, 95 FT (29.0 M) EAST OF THE BIKE PATH, 65 FT (19.8 M) SOUTHERLY OR SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF THE WALL, ABOUT 50 FT (15.2 M) NORTH OF A PATH THROUGH THE WOODS KNOWN AS AN EAGLE SCOUT TRAIL. S-A-S COMPUTED BETWEEN THE TWO RMS IS 14.791 M (48.5 FT).  RM 1 IS 71 FT (21.6 M) EAST OF THE BIKE PATH, 60 FT (18.3 M) SOUTHEAST OF THE WEST END OF THE WALL AND 55 FT (16.8 M) SOUTHERLY OF THE WALL, ABOUT 3 FT (0.9 M) ABOVE THE STATION.  RM 2 IS 101 FT (30.8 M) EAST OF THE BIKE PATH, 92 FT (28.0 M) EAST OF THE WEST END OF THE WALL AND 36 FT (11.0 M) SOUTHERLY OF THE WALL, ABOUT 2 FT (0.6 M) ABOVE THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2018)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2018 (JRO) RECOVERED THE MARKS BUT SOMEONE KNOCKED DOWN AND SCATTERED THE CAIRNS PLACED BY EACH MARK LAST YEAR.

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF ORANGE.  HILL IS MOSTLY LEDGE. FROM EAST CANAAN GO TO THE HOUSE OF CHAS. H. HISCOCK ABOUT 3 MILES NE FROM EAST CANAAN AND FROM THERE TO TOP 3/4 MILE. SIGNAL SET ON WHITE LEDGE AT S END OF PEAK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FOREST SERVICE 1959 (FSB) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGH, BARE, SOUTHERN PEAK OF OLD TUG MTN.  IT LIES ABOUT 2.07 MILES NORTH NE OF THE TOWN OF ORANGE, ABOUT 3.75 MILES SOUTH OF BUCKS CORNER, AND ABOUT 8.13 MILES WEST OF ROGER LEDGE ON THE WEST SHORE OF NEWFOUND LAKE.  UPON RECOVERY OF THE STATION, THE THREE BENT IRON BOLTS USED IN GUYING THE ORIGINAL SIGNAL WERE FOUND.  CENTERED IN THE TRIANGLE FORMED BY THE BOLTS WAS AN UNSTAMPED STANDARD USGS BRONZE TABLET.  NO DATA FOR THIS TABLET WAS AVAILABLE WHEN REQUESTED.  TABLET SETS ON HIGHEST POINT OF PEAK AND WHERE USC AND GS MARK WOULD HAVE BEEN, THOUGH STATION IS LISTED AS UNMARKED.  DURING TRIANGULATION BY THE USC AND GS IN 1959, A USC AND GS LITE MANNED BY USFS WAS CENTERED OVER THE USGS TABLET, HEIGHT 3.72 FEET.  THIS RAY WAS FOR CHECK PURPOSES AS THE STATION ITSELF IS AN UNCHECKED INTERSECTED POSITION.  THE ANGLES CONCLUDED FROM PUBLISHED AZIMUTHS DO NOT EQUAL 180 DEG PLUS SE BUT TOTAL 179 DEG 59 MIN 59.4 SEC.  TO REACH FROM JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 4 AND STATE HIGHWAY 118 IN CANAAN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 118 FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AS PER SIGN MOUNT CARDIGAN STATE FOREST AND GO EASTERLY ON MAIN ROAD FOR 0.95 MILE TO THE ORANGE TOWNLINE.  CONTINUE ON THE MAIN ROAD FOR 1.7 MILES TO A ROAD FORK JUST AFTER CROSSING BRIDGE.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW ROAD UPSTREAM, PARALLEL TO NO. 7 BROOK FOR ABOUT 0.95 MILE.  HERE, WITH OLD BARN ON LEFT, ROAD TURNS RIGHT.  AT HIS POINT AN OLD ROAD GOES STRAIGHT AHEAD TO A MICA MINE AND IS PASSABLE WHEN DRY AND VEHICLE NOT TOO LOW SLUNG.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD ABOUT A MILE TO STREAM CROSSING AT A SHARP BEND, SUMMIT IS VISIBLE ON THE LEFT. NO TRAIL TO SUMMIT, PACK ONE HOUR.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1876 (ETQ) BEGIN THE ASCENT OF THE MOUNTAIN FROM THE CENTER HARBOR ROAD NEAR THE COLD RIVER BRIDGE, WHENCE A PATH LEADS TO THE TOP. SUMMIT IS LEDGY WITH A FEW DEAD TREES STANDING.  STATION IS MARKED BY A BOLT AND TRIANGLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1934 (RE) BEGIN THE ASCENT OF THE MOUNTAIN 0.5 MILE FROM WEST OSSIPEE ON THE ROAD TO CENTER HARBOR, WHERE A TRAIL MARKED MT. WHITTIER LEADS TO THE TOP OF A LOW PEAK.  THE TRAIL THEN CONTINUES ON ACROSS A VALLEY TO THE SUMMIT OF OSSIPEE MT.  THE SUMMIT IS PARTLY WOODED, BUT THE POINT WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED IS BARE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A BOLT AND TRIANGLE.  THE TRIANGLE IS VERY INDISTINCT.  MAGNETIC DIRECTIONS--WHITEFACE N 37 DEG 30 MIN W.  PEQUAWKET N 29 DEG E.  PLEASANT N 65 DEG E.  WASHINGTON N 4 DEG E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1954 A THREE-DAY SEARCH WAS MADE AND THE STATION IS BELIEVED DESTROYED DUE TO A FOREST FIRE ON OSSIPEE MOUNTAIN AND MT. SHAW VICINITY IN 1953.  IT WAS FOUND THAT EXTENSIVE BLASTING WAS DONE TO CHECK THE FIRE NEAR THE SITE OF THE STATION.  NO LARGE ROCKS WERE FOUND.  ONLY AN IRON BOLT STICKING 6 IN. ABOVE GROUND WAS FOUND AND THAT IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN AN ANCHOR FOR THE LOOKOUT TOWER WHICH WAS ONCE THERE.

BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) HILLS JUST TO THE S ARE CALLED SOUTH MOUNTAINS OR SHARON MOUNTAINS.  TO REACH THE STATION GO UP ON W SPUR OF MOUNTAIN TO THE HOUSE OF MR. DANIEL EDES, WHO LIVES ABOUT 1 MILE FROM THE SUMMIT. HIS HOUSE IS REACHED FROM THE MOUNTAIN HOUSE IN LYNDEBORO BY TAKING THE PETERBORO ROAD OVER THE N SPUR OF PETERBORO MOUNTAIN, AND TURNING TO THE LEFT SO AS TO KEEP ALONG THE MOUNTAIN. MR. EDES, WHO IS IN CHARGE OF THE SIGNAL IS 3 MILES FROM PETERBORO MOUNTAIN.  HIS POST OFFICE ADDRESS IS PETERBORO, NEW HAMPSHIRE.  MR. EDES HAS THE CARE OF THE UPPER PASTURE LAND WHICH IS OWNED IN PART OR JOINTLY BY J.E. MONROE, OF BEDFORD, MASSACHUSETTS.  ASCENT ON THE W SIDE THROUGH OPEN PASTURE AND OVER LEDGES. LONG BUT NOT VERY DIFFICULT.  STATION IS MARKED BY A HOLE IN ROCK AROUND WHICH IS DRILLED A TRIANGLE ONE OF WHOSE SIDES POINTS N AND S AND IS 6 INCHES FROM THE HOLE.  THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN CONSISTS OF 3 SEPARATE PEAKS ABOUT 150 OR 200 FEET APART IN A LINE RUNNING ABOUT NW BY N.  THE MOST SOUTHERLY OF THESE IS HIGHEST BUT LITTLE CAN BE SEEN FROM IT (TOWARDS THE N) OF THE LOWER LAND.  THE STATION IS THEREFORE, PUT ON THE MIDDLE ONE.  THE TOP IS LEDGE WITH SCRUB GROWTH OF LOW TREES ON THE E AND S WHICH MAY SOMETIME HAVE TO BE CUT AWAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2006)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2006 (DKA) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 ON THE PATUCCAWA MOUNTAIN, WHICH IS IN THE TOWNS OF NORTH DEERFIELD AND NOTTINGHAM, ABOUT 800 FEET ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE SEA.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND ON A LARGE ROCK HAVING A GREATER SLOPE TO THE NW.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 1/2-INCH IRON BOLT FIRMLY IMBEDDED IN THE ROCK, AT THE HIGHEST POINT.  THE NEAREST RAILROAD STATION IS LEE.  ABOUT 2 MILES FROM THE STATION IS AN OLD AND LITTLE USED ROAD WHICH TURNS TO THE LEFT UP A STEEP HILL FROM THE MAIN ROAD.  THIS ROAD LEADS TO A FARMHOUSE JUST S OF THE MOUNTAIN.  IT IS ABOUT A 10-MINUTE WALK FROM THE STATION TO THE FARMHOUSE, THE FOOT OF THE STEEP PART BEING ABOUT 1/4 MILE FROM THE HOUSE.  IT IS BEST TO GO NE FROM THE FARMHOUSE TO A ROCK FENCE AT THE FOOT OF THE STEEP PART.  FOLLOW THIS FENCE UNTIL A LITTLE ROCKY GULLY IS REACHED (ABOUT 100 YARDS FROM BEGINNING OF STEEP CLIMB), THEN FOLLOW UP THIS GULLY.  THIS LEADS TO THE SUMMIT OF THE RIDGE ABOUT 100 YARDS TO THE EASTWARD OF THE STATION.  THE FOLLOWING ARE REFERENCES--FOUR 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLES ARE RESPECTIVELY, 0.51 METER FROM THE STATION, N 48 DEG 40 MIN E.  0.445 METER FROM THE STATION, S 10 DEG 20 MIN E. 0.600 METER FROM THE STATION, N 75 DEG 20 MIN W.  0.605 METER FROM THE STATION, N 70 DEG 20 MIN W.  THREE 1/2-INCH BOLTS (BENT) ARE, RESPECTIVELY, 1.81 METERS FROM THE STATION,  N 32 DEG 20 MIN E.  1.93 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 20 DEG 00 MIN E.  3.015 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 85 DEG 20 MIN W.  THE BOLT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 INCHES FROM THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1931 (HSS) THE STATION IS ON THE NORTHWESTERNMOST OF THE PATUCCAWA MOUNTAINS, CALLED THE NORTH OR UPPER MOUNTAIN.  I FOUND THE IRON STATION-BOLT, THE 4 DRILL HOLES AND THE 3 BENT BOLTS.  THE STATION-BOLT IS BROKEN OFF FLUSH WITH THE LEDGE, HOWEVER, IT SEEMS TO BE FIRMLY IN PLACE.  I FOUND 3 OTHER DRILL HOLES WHICH ARE NOT MENTIONED IN THE DESCRIPTION, ALTHOUGH THEY SEEMED TO BE AS OLD AS THE OTHERS.  ONE OF THESE HOLES, A SMALL ONE, IS 2.60 METERS FROM THE STATION, ABOUT S 17 DEG E, AND MAY HAVE SERVED TO MARK THE LINE TO GUNSTOCK.  ANOTHER, IN WHICH THERE ARE 3 SMALL IRON WEDGES, IS 2.25 METERS FROM THE STATION, ABOUT S 73 DEG W, AND THE THIRD IS 2.51 METERS, ABOUT S 74 DEG W AND MAY HAVE MARKED THE LINE TO AGAMENTICUS.  THESE AZIMUTHS WERE ONLY VERY ROUGHLY DETERMINED AND ARE NOT AT ALL EXACT.  THE VIEW FROM THE STATION IS LARGELY OBSCURED BY THE UPPER PORTIONS OF NEARBY TREES, BUT LINES COULD READILY BE OPENED IN MOST DIRECTIONS.  A STEEL FIRE TOWER OF THE NEW HAMPSHIRE FORESTRY DEPARTMENT IS ABOUT 1.5 MILES SE, ON THE SOUTH OR LOWER MOUNTAIN AND IS AN INTERSECTION STATION OF THE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, CALLED LOOKOUT.  IT IS MORE ACCESSIBLE THAN STATION PATUCCAWA.  A STATE FOREST RESERVATION COVERS MOST OF THE REGION (918 ACRES) AND INCLUDES BOTH THE FIRE TOWER AND STATION PATUCCAWA, THE LATTER BEING NEAR THE NORTHWESTERN EDGE.  THE MOUNTAIN CAN BEST BE REACHED FROM ROUTE 101, WHICH IS THE STATE ROAD FROM PORTSMOUTH AND EXETER TO MANCHESTER.  AT A POINT ABOUT 3 MILES NW OF THE VILLAGE OF RAYMOND A GOOD ROAD LEADS FROM ROUTE 101 TO DEERFIELD, PASSING WITHIN ABOUT 2 MILES OF THE STATION.  LOCAL INFORMATION SHOULD BE OBTAINED FOR A NEARER APPROACH.  THE MOUNTAIN IS LITTLE FREQUENTED AND I FAILED TO FIND A TRAIL TO THE SUMMIT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1939)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1939 RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (RCY) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. A NEW TO REACH DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--TO REACH FROM THE DEERFIELD TOWNSHIP POST OFFICE IN DEERFIELD CENTER GO NORTHEASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 107 FOR 0.7 MILE TO FORKS, TAKE RIGHT FORK FOR 0.2 MILE TO BRIDGE OVER STREAM, CONTINUE AHEAD FOR ABOUT 0.05 MILE TO REVERSE Y AND GRAVEL SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW GRAVEL ROAD FOR 2.9 MILES TO FARMHOUSE AND ETT.  FROM HERE PACK EASTERLY TO HIGHEST POINT OF RIDGE AND STATION.  ABOUT 1/2 HOUR PACK.  A 15 FOOT WOODEN STAND NOW STANDS OVER THE STATION AND SHOULD BE SERVICEABLE FOR APPROXIMATELY TWO OR THREE YEARS WITH MINOR REPAIR TO THE HEAD OF THE INNER STAND AND A NEW PLATFORM FOR THE OUTER STAND.  VISIBILITY IS CLEAR IN MOST DIRECTIONS EXCEPT SOME CLOSE TREES BLOCK VIEW TO THE NORTH.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RCA) THE STATION, PEASE AIR FORCE BASE NORTH TANK, IS THE TOP-CENTER OF 400,000 GAL., 237 FOOT HIGH, CHECKERED, ELEVATED, WATERTANK.  LOCATED AT THE JUNCTION OF PORTSMOUTH AVE. AND NEW MARKET STREET ON PEASE AIR FORCE BASE IN PORTSMOUTH, NEW HAMPSHIRE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (RMB) INASMUCH AS THERE IS NO AVAILABLE DESCRIPTION, RECOVERY OF STATION IS SOMEWHAT UNCERTAIN.  THE GEOGRAPHIC POSITION FALLS ON THE PRESENT FIRST CONGREGATIONAL CHURCH OF PEMBROKE, WHICH, UPON LOCAL INQUIRY, HAS STOOD IN THAT SAME SPOT SINCE APPROXIMATELY 1850.  HOWEVER, THE CHURCH RECORDS SHOW THAT IT WAS REMODELED IN 1871 AND 1889.  LOCAL INFORMATION DEVELOPS THE FACT THAT THE STEEPLE WAS REBUILT ON ONE OR THE OTHER OF THESE DATES.  THE PRESENT WHITE CLAPBOARD STEEPLE WITH SHINGLE ROOF MAY OR MAY NOT BE THE ORIGINAL OBJECT USED BUT IT STANDS IN SUBSTANTIALLY THE SAME POSITION AND IS CLOSE ENOUGH TO BE USED FOR AIR-PHOTO MAPPING.  THE CHURCH IS ON THE EASTERLY SIDE OF ROUTE U.S. NO. 3 AND 5 1/2 MILES SOUTH OF CONCORD, AT THE NORTHERLY END OF THE SETTLEMENT OF PEMBROKE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1948)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1948 (BK) DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.  THE POINT RECOVERED WAS THE PEMBROKE CHURCH WHERE THE POSITION FALLS AS STATED IN PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1984)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1984 (WH) PEMBROKE CHURCH SPIRE.  THIS IS A CONGREGATIONAL CHURCH LOCATED ON N.H. RTE 3 ABOUT MIDWAY OF PEMBROKE ST.  IT IS 0.6 MILE WEST OF THE WAR MEMORIAL IN PEMBROKE PARK ON THE NORTH SIDE OF ROAD AND 0.6 MILE SOUTH OF A LARGE PLAQUE DESIGNATING WHERE THE CHURCH FIRST STOOD IN 1733.  IT WAS MOVED TO ITS PRESENT LOCATION AROUND 1850.  IT IS IN USE AND WELL MAINTAINED HAS DOUBLE SQUARED BELFRY, TOPPED BY TALL SPIRED WEATHERVANE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1991)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1991 (FAF) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1878 (ETQ) THIS IS THE NORTHERN OF TWO CONE-SHAPED PEAKS ENTIRELY BARE.  IT IS ABOUT 200 FEET HIGHER THAN THE SOUTHERN ONE AND IS REACHED FROM THE FARMHOUSE OF HENRY HOLTON.  GO FROM HOLTONS HOUSE BY THE PATH OF THE BLUEBERRY PICKERS TO THE BALD PART OF THE FIRST PEAK AND FOLLOW AROUND THE E SIDE OF IT INTO THE RAVINE WHICH SEPARATES THE PEAKS, WHERE A STREAM OF WATER IS DISCOVERED.  THENCE UP THE BARE SIDE OF THE SECOND OR PERCY PEAK.  IT IS IN THE S PART OF TOWN NEAR THE LINE OF STARK.  SIGNAL IS ON THE NE PART OF THE TOP, WHICH IS ABOUT AN ACRE IN EXTENT, ON A SPOT RAISED A FEW FEET ABOVE THE REST OF THE SUMMIT.  SIGNAL IS IN CHARGE OF HENRY HOLTON, GROVETON, NEW HAMPSHIRE.  STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF STRATFORD, NEW HAMPSHIRE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED. A COMPLETELY NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTHEAST OF GROVETON, ABOUT 3.75 MILES NORTHWEST OF PERCY.  ON THE MOST NORTHERLY AND HIGHEST PEAK OF THE PERCY PEAKS.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE SUMMIT.  THE STATION MARK IS AN IRON ROD SET IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND HAS A TRIANGULAR TRENCH AROUND IT.  THERE IS ALSO A USGS DISK SET INSIDE OF THE TRIANGLE TRENCH AND ALMOST TOUCHES THE IRON ROD IT IS SO CLOSE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 110 AND 16 IN BERLIN, GO WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 110 FOR 11.7 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 110A AND 110 IN WEST MILAN.  CONTINUE ON STATE HIGHWAY 110 FOR 5.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND A SIGN PERCY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.4 MILE TO A T ROAD JUST EAST OF THE RAILROAD DEPOT IN PERCY.  TURN LEFT AND GO 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.35 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO 0.1 MILE TO A FORK JUST PAST A GATE AND A SIGN ON A TREE PERCY PEAKS.  TAKE RIGHT FORK AND GO 0.35 MILE TO A FORK AND A SIGN ON A TREE PERCY PEAKS.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO FOR 0.3 MILE TO A FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO FOR 0.25 MILE TO ROWELLS BROOK, THIS IS ETT FOR TWO WHEEL DRIVE. CONTINUE AHEAD ON THE MAIN ROAD FOR 1.2 MILES TO A REVERSE FORK, TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT. CONTINUE AHEAD FOR ABOUT 50 YARDS TO ANOTHER SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO 0.35 MILE TO ETT.  FROM HERE PACK NORTHWESTERLY UP THE TRAIL TILL IT ENTERS THE WOODS.  THEN PACK WESTERLY UP THE TRAIL UNTILL IT IS ABOVE THE TIMBERLINE, THEN PACK NORTHERLY UP THE BARE ROCK TO THE SUMMIT, WHICH IS PARTLY COVERED WITH SCRUB FIR TREES, AND THE STATION ON THE NORTHEAST PART OF THE SUMMIT. IT IS ABOUT A 1.5 HOUR PACK.  REFERENCE MARK NO 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND IS ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE DISK IS STAMPED PERCY PEAK 1878 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND IS ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  THE DISK IS STAMPED PERCY PEAK NO 2 1878 1959.                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2011 (DKA) THE STATION IS IN GOOD CONDITION. RM1 HAS ONLY THE STEM LEFT
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (PLB) STATION IS ON THE WOODED SUMMIT OF PEVERLY HILL, 2.8 MILES SSW OF THE CENTER OF PORTSMOUTH, 0.3 MILE W OF U.S. HIGHWAY 1, AND 0.25 MILE S OF THE PEVERLY HILL ROAD, ON THE PROPERTY OF JOHN IAFOLLA CONSTRUCTION COMPANY OF DEDHAM, MASSACHUSETTS, WHO HAS A STORAGE LOT AT THE N BASE OF THE HILL. REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS IN THE BRUSH S OF THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS AT THE E EDGE OF A TRAIL ROAD W OF THE STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK COULD BE SET THAT WOULD BE VISIBLE FROM THE GROUND.  STATION IS REACHED FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PORTSMOUTH BY GOING S ON U.S. HIGHWAY 1 FOR 2.5 MILES TO THE PEVERLY HILL ROAD TO THE W, WHICH IS JUST S OF SOME TOURIST CABINS, THENCE RIGHT (W) ON THE PEVERLY HILL ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE CONSTRUCTION COMPANYS LOT ON THE S, TURN LEFT (S) THROUGH GATE AND CONTINUE ON A FAIRLY WELL TRAVELED TRAIL 0.25 MILE TO WHERE THE ROAD STARTS TO DESCEND AND THE STATION IS ABOUT 50 YARDS TO THE E. THE REFERENCE MARKS HAVE BEEN DESTROYED BY EXCAVATIONS ON THE S AND W SIDES OF THE STATION.  THE STATION ITSELF WILL PROBABLY BE DESTROYED IN THE FUTURE. IT IS ABOUT 2.3 MILES WNW OF RYE BEACH, 7.0 MILES SSW OF PORTSMOUTH, AND ABOUT 0.8 MILE SE OF A RAILROAD OVERPASS ON U.S. HIGHWAY 1, ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. GILLMAN GOSS OF RYE, NEW HAMPSHIRE. THE USFS STATION PLYMOUTH WAS THEN ESTABLISHED ON THE EASTERN HEIGHT OF THIS FLAT TOPPED MOUNTAIN AND DURING THE COURSE OF WORK, TWO DRILL HOLES WERE FOUND UNDER A SMALL ROCK CAIRN SURROUNDING A SIGN PLYMOUTH MTN. ELEV. 2187.  NO IRON BOLTS OR CHISELED TRIANGLES WERE FOUND.  THE ONE HOLE WHICH APPEARED TO HAVE POSSIBILITIES OF BEING THE OLD USC AND GS STATION LATER COMPUTED TO HAVE A POSITION OF--LATITUDE 43 DEG 42 MIN 32.160 SEC AND LONGITUDE 71 DEG 43 MIN 26.104 SEC. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 MILES SOUTHWEST OF MANCHESTER, 16 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF NASHUA, AND ON THE SOUTHWEST END OF A LOW ROCKY RIDGE ON THE NEW BOSTON BOMBING RANGE AREA.  IT IS 36 FEET NORTH OF A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 5 FEET, 25 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER LINE OF A TRACK ROAD AND 2.6 FEET NORTHWEST OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN A 10 X 10 INCH CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS STAMPED POND 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET AND IS ON THE NORTH SLOPE OF RIDGE.  THE DISK IS STAMPED POND NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET AND IS ON THE SOUTH SLOPE OF RIDGE.  THE DISK IS STAMPED POND NO 2 1959.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 14 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1986)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1986 (REP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED ON THIS DATE. NO OTHER MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR AT THIS TIME.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 14.5 KM (9.0 MI) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF DOWNTOWN MANCHESTER, 12.9 KM (8.0 MI) NORTH OF MILFORD, 6.4 KM (4.0 MI) SOUTHEAST OF NEW BOSTON AND AT THE NEW BOSTON AIR FORCE TRACKING STATION. OWNERSHIP--US AIR FORCE, C/O COMMANDER, DET 2 AFSCFCC, NEW BOSTON AIR FORCE STATION, AMHERST NH 03031, PHONE 603-472-3911.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 101 AND 122, WHICH IS JUST SOUTHEAST OF AMHERST, GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 101 FOR 3.5 KM (2.2 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, HORACE GREELEY ROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HORACE GREELEY ROAD FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) TO A FORK, CHESTNUT HILL ROAD TO THE LEFT.  KEEP LEFT ON CHESTNUT HILL ROAD FOR 4.8 KM (3.0 MI) TO THE ENTRANCE TO THE NEW BOSTON U.S. AIR FORCE TRACKING STATION ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND PASS THROUGH THE GATE FOR 30 METERS (100 FT) TO A ROAD LEFT, JUST BEFORE THE FIRE STATION ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT ON A PAVED THEN DIRT ROAD, UPHILL FOR 0.6 KM (0.35 MI) TO A DIRT ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) TO A WOODS ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT ON THE WOODS ROAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.15) TO A FORK, KEEP RIGHT ON A WOODS ROAD AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT IN A CLEARING THAT IS NOW OVERGROWN WITH BRUSH.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD CGS DISK STAMPED---POND 1959---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT 25 CM ON SIDE FLUSH WITH GROUND.  LOCATED 7 METERS (23 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD, 4.21 METERS (13.81 FT) SOUTH FROM A WOODEN WITNESS POST AND 0.80 METERS (2.62 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A METAL WITNESS POST. THE UNDERGROUND MARK WAS NOT CHECKED AT THIS TIME.  THIS STATION IS LOCATED ON A U.S. AIR FORCE MILITARY RESERVATION AND IS A HIGH SECURITY AREA.  A GOVERNMENT ID IS REQUIRED TO ENTER THE RESERVATION.  FAA AIRPORT SURVEYS, NEW ENGLAND, SEPTEMBER-OCTOBER 1986.  THIS STATION IS SUITABLE FOR GPS SURVEYS.  DESCRIBED BY R.T. WOODRUFF.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY HONEYWELL INCORPORATED 2004 STATION RECOVERY ONLY.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT SEARCHED FOR.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1994 (RAH) THE STATION IS LOCATED JUST EAST OF PORTSMOUTH, NH AT THE USCG STATION FOR PORTSMOUTH HARBOUR IN NEW CASTLE, NH.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM HIGHWAY 95/1 ROTARY IN PORTSMOUTH, PROCEED SOUTHEAST ON BY-PASS 1 FOR 1.6 MI (2.6 KM) TO HIGHWAY 1.  CONTINUE SOUTH ON HIGHWAY 1 FOR 0.5 MI (0.8 KM) TO INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 1 AND ELWIN ROAD. TURN LEFT (EAST) ON ELWIN ROAD AND CONTINUE FOR 1.45 MI (2.33 KM) TO INTERSECTION OF ELWIN ROAD AND ROUTE 1A.  TURN LEFT (NORTHWEST) ON ROUTE 1A AND PROCEED 0.45 MI (0.72 KM) TO INTERSECTION OF ROUTE 1A AND 1B. TURN RIGHT (NORTHEAST) ON ROUTE 1B FOR 2.6 MI (4.2 KM) TO ENTRANCE ROAD TO FORT CONSTITUTION AND USCG STATION PORTSMOUTH HARBOR (WHERE ROUTE 1B CHANGES FROM MAIN STREET TO WENTWORTH ROAD). TURN RIGHT (EAST) ON TO ACCESS ROAD AND PROCEED EAST FOR 0.03 MI (0.05 KM) TO FORT CONSTITUTION TURN OFF.  TURN RIGHT (EAST) CONTINUING 162 FT (49.4 M) TO ROCK OUTCROP ON THE RIGHT AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 195.5 FT (59.6 M) NORTH NORTHWEST OF A POWER POLE, 189.3 FT (57.7 M) EAST OF A BLACK FIRE HYDRANT, 73.5 FT (22.4 M) SOUTHEAST OF A FIRE HYDRANT, 73.5 FT (22.4 M) SOUTH OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A CONCRETE BUILDING FOUNDATION, AND 16.8 FT (5.1 M) NORTH OF THE ROAD CURB.$FOR ACCESS CONTACT CWO-4 MICHAEL E. PENDLETON, COMMANDING OFFICER, USCG STATION PORTSMOUTH HARBOR, NEW CASTLE, NH 03854-0600, PHONE (603) 436-4415.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1995 (ALG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY JE CHANCE AND ASSOCIATES 2005 (JWC) RECOVERED FOR THE USACE REGIONAL COASTAL MAPPING PROJECT.  EXCELLENT FOR AIRBORNE KGPS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2014)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATNL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMIN 2014 (DTM) STATION IS LOCATED BETWEEN TOWN OF NEW CASTLE PARKING LOT AND UNH JUDD GREGG MARINE COMPLEX PARKING LOT, ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF SULLIVAN LANE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2016)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2016 (JRO) THERE IS PUBLIC ACCESS TO THIS AREA NOW, APPARENTLY NOT CONTROLLED BY USCG ANY MORE.  THE MARK IS 5 FT (1.5 M) ABOVE SULLIVAN LANE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2019)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 2019 (HJC) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

A WATER TANK ON THE CREAMERY, IN AN ADJACENT BUILDING, IS STILL INTACT, HOWEVER, THIS IS PROBABLY THE STATION. BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1928 (GCM) RECOVERED UNCHANGED.  BUILDING NO LONGER USED AS A SCHOOL. THE PORTSMOUTH FRANKLIN SCHOOLHOUSE CUPOLA IS LOCATED IN PORTSMOUTH ON MAPLEWOOD AVENUE, AT THE INTERSECTION OF MAPLEWOOD AVENUE AND PROSPECT STREET, IN AN OLD ABANDONED SCHOOL BUILDING.  THE NAME FRANKLIN SCHOOL IS ON THE BUILDING IN LARGE PAINTED LETTERS.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1928 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED UNCHANGED.  KNOWN LOCALLY AS FORT POINT LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (PLB) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS THE LIGHTHOUSE ON FORT POINT, NEWCASTLE, NEW HAMPSHIRE.  IT IS A WHITE CONICAL STRUCTURE WITH A FOG-SIGNAL HOUSE ATTACHED.  THE LIGHT FLASHES GREEN, IS 52 FEET ABOVE THE WATER, AND ACCORDING TO THE LIGHT LIST, IT WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1771 AND REBUILT IN 1877.  THIS STATION WAS CALLED PORTSMOUTH HARBOR LIGHT IN THE RECOVERY OF G.C.M. IN 1928.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1941.  THE FOLLOWING SHOULD BE ADDED TO THE 1941 DESCRIPTION--  AT THE S ENTRANCE TO PORTSMOUTH HARBOR.  AT FORT CONSTITUTION. THIS STATION IS ALSO KNOWN AS FORT POINT LIGHTHOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2000)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2000 (RPM) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (WD) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) NO DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION WAS AVAILABLE TO THIS PARTY AND ALTHOUGH A SEARCH WAS MADE IN THE GENERAL AREA INDICATED BY THE GEOGRAPHIC POSITION, NO TRACE OF A MARK WAS FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2007 (JLH) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN NORTHERN RYE ON THE GROUNDS OF ODIORNE POINT STATE PARK.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF US ROUTES 1 AND 1A IN PORTSMOUTH, TRAVEL SOUTHEASTERLY ALONG RT 1A FOR 6.1 KM (3.8 MI) TO A GATED GRAVEL ROAD. (NOTE THAT IS ROAD IS 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) NORTHEAST ALONG RT 1A FROM THE MAIN ENTRANCE TO ODIORNE POINT STATE PARK.) TURN LEFT (NE) AND FOLLOW THE ROAD FOR 125 METERS TO A GRAVEL ROAD. TURN RIGHT (SE) AND FOLLOW THE ROAD ABOUT 225 METERS TO A REVERSE Y INTERSECTION OF A DIRT ROAD LEFT AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   THE MARK IS A 4 CM (1.5 IN) DRILL HOLE IN THE HIGHEST POINT OF A 7.5 M BY 10 M ROCK OUTCROP RISING ABOUT 1.2 M ABOVE THE SURROUNDING GROUND. THE MARK IS LOCATED 19.8 M (65 FT) NE FROM A 60 CM (24 IN) MAPLE LOCATED IN THE INTERSECTION OF THE ROADS, 18.6 M (61 FT) NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE GRAVEL ROAD, AND 10.1 M (33 FT) SOUTH FROM A STONE WALL.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1912 STATION IS ON A LARGE ROCK, 6 FEET HIGH, NE OF C.F. EASTMANS HOUSE, THE STATION IN 1898 WAS MARKED BY A DRILL HOLE IN THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCK.  IN 1912 A STANDARD U.S.C. AND G.S. DISK STATION MARK WAS PLACED IN THE HOLE AND SURROUNDED BY LEAD.  THE HOLE WAS 2 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 5 INCHES DEEP.  A STANDARD DISK WITNESS MARK IS SET IN STONE 28.74 METERS FROM THE STATION, IN AZIMUTH 208 DEG 37 MIN.  A CROSS CUT IN THE BARN FOUNDATION IS 10.50 METERS FROM THE STATION, IN AZIMUTH 18 DEG 39 MIN.  THE NW CORNER OF THE BARN IS 10.48 METERS AND THE NE CORNER 14.14 METERS FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1928)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1928 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  TABLET EXTENDS FREE 1/2 INCH ABOVE ROCK AND MAY BECOME LOOSE BEFORE LONG.  EASTMANS HOUSE IS GONE.  A NEW HOUSE WHOSE WINGS PARTIALLY SURROUND THE ROCK AT A DISTANCE OF 2 METERS HAS BEEN BUILT BY DR. GRAVES OF CONCORD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION EXCEPT FOR THE FOLLOWING DISCREPANCIES--  1.  STATION IS ON LARGE ROCK 5 FEET HIGH, NOT 6 FEET HIGH.  THE FOLLOWING SHOULD BE ADDED TO THE DESCRIPTION--  1.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS NO LONGER VISIBLE FROM STATION BECAUSE OF NEW HOUSE WINGS THAT HAVE BEEN BUILT.  2.  HOUSE IS NOW OCCUPIED BY U.S. ARMY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE ROCK IN WHICH IT IS SET IS TOO SMALL TO OCCUPY WITHOUT A 12-FOOT STAND, SO ANOTHER STATION WAS LOCATED NEARBY AND CALLED DEARBORN.  THE WALL OF THE HOUSE NEAREST THE STATION IS STILL STANDING BUT THE REST OF THE HOUSE HAS BEEN TORN DOWN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION AND THE REFERENCE MARK WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. THE DISTANCE TO THE REFERENCE MARK WAS MEASURED WITH A STEEL TAPE AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  THE BARN FOUNDATION AND DR. GRAVES HOUSE HAVE BOTH BEEN DESTROYED.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING EXCEPTIONS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ODIORNES POINT, ON THE GROUNDS OF FORT DEARBORN, ABOUT 0.2 MI. E OF THE MOST S GATE TO THE FORT, 106 FT. NW OF THE CENTER OF THE MOST N OF THREE GUN EMPLACEMENTS, 87 FT. SE OF THE S ONE OF TWO STONE FENCE POSTS, AND 61 FT. E OF A ROCK FENCE.  THE STATION MARK IS STAMPED C AND G AND IS SET IN A ROCK AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED.  THE REFERENCE MARK IS NE OF THE STATION, SET IN A ROCK OUTCROP AND IS NOT STAMPED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (WD) FORT DEARBORN IS NOW THE ORDIORNES POINT STATE PARK.  TO REACH FROM THE SOUTH END OF THE PARK'S GRAVEL PARKING AREA, WALK EASTERLY ON A PAVED PATH FOR ABOUT 400 FEET.  FOLLOW THE PATH AS IT BENDS SOUTHERLY AND CONTINUE FOR ABOUT 200 FEET TO A PAVED PATH ON THE RIGHT LEADING TO A SMALL PICNIC AREA.  WALK WEST FOR 70 FEET TO THE LARGE BOULDER AND THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2007 (JLH) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2017)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2017 (JRO) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1916 (FHB) IN EMBERTON TOWNSHIP, 3 MILES SOUTH - SOUTHWEST OF CHARTIERVILLE, QUEBEC, ON THE EASTERN HILL OF THE TWIN PEAKS KNOWN AS PROSPECT HILL, ON A ROCK HUMP AT THE EXTREME NORTH EDGE OF THE SUMMIT AND THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE HILL.  STATION MARK--STANDARD BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A HOLE DRILLED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  THE REFERENCE MARKS ARE CROSSES CUT IN LEDGE ROCK AT THE FOLLOWING DISTANCES AND AZIMUTHS FROM THE STATION--18.85 FEET, 12 DEGREES 31 MINUTES, 5.78 FEET, 65 DEGREES 11 MINUTES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1950)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1950 (FHB) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2006)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2006 (RG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT SEARCHED FOR.   NOTE THAT THIS STATION IS ABOUT 50 FEET NORTH OF THE BOUNDARY, BEYOND THE BOUNDARY SWATH.  THERE ARE SEVERAL MOUNDS IN THE AREA OF SIMILAR HEIGHT.  THE STATION IS ON THE ONLY MOUND WITH EXPOSED ROCK.  THE DISK WAS PARTLY COVERED BY VEGETATION AND WAS READILY VISIBLE.

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF NORTH HOLDERNESS.  LAND OWNED BY DAVID B. PULSIFER.  SIGNAL IS ON THE EAST PART OF HIGHEST PART OF MOUNT.  SUMMIT IS LEDGE AND SOIL.  SIGNAL IS IN CHARGE OF JOHN B. HENCKINS, OF PLYMOUTH.  TO REACH STATION GO TO THE HOUSE OF JOHN B. HENCKINS, THENCE TO TOP BY CARRIAGE ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) STATION MARK, AN IRON PIN LEADED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK AND SURROUNDED BY A CHISELED TRIANGLE, WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW STATION, PROSPECT MT 2, WAS ESTABLISHED BY THIS PARTY, DISTANCE BEING 0.43 FEET (0.130 METERS) NORTHWEST OF STATION PROSPECT 1873.  THE NEW STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PROSPECT MT 2, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET.  IT IS ON THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF THE TRIANGLE CHISELED IN THE BEDROCK WHICH SURROUNDS STATION PROSPECT 1873.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF ASHLAND, 4 MILES NORTHEAST OF PLYMOUTH AND ON THE FLAT OUTCROP LEDGE AT THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF THE SUMMIT OF PROSPECT MOUNTAIN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PLYMOUTH, GO NORTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.15 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.75 MILE TO ROAD FORKS AND TRAFFIC TRIANGLE, KEEP RIGHT FORK FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW SURFACED ROAD TOWARD GOLF CLUB FOR 1.3 MILES TO A FORK, KEEP LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW SURFACED ROAD FOR 1.5 MILES TO WHERE THE ROAD TURNS LEFT JUST BEFORE REACHING A RED, 2-CAR GARAGE AND A DIM TRACK ROAD ON THE RIGHT, TURN RIGHT INTO FIELD WHICH IS END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR 2-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCKS.  WITH A 4-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK KEEP RIGHT TRAIL DOWN ACROSS SMALL DRAIN, THENCE LEFT UP THE SIDE OF THE RIDGE FOLLOWING OLD TRAIL TO WHERE TRAIL SEEMS TO END, THENCE PACK EASTERLY TO THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF THE SUMMIT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  (THERE IS AN OLD TRAIL TO THE TOP BUT IT IS VERY DIM AND HARD TO FOLLOW BUT IT IS EASIER TO CLIMB OVER THE ROCKS RATHER THAN GOING THROUGH THE BLOWN DOWN TREES NEAR THE TOP.)  STATION MARK, IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PROSPECT MT 2 1958, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE OUTCROP OF BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET.  IT IS NEAR THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF THE SUMMIT OF PROSPECT MOUNTAIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PROSPECT MT 2 NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE OUTCROP OF BEDROCK.  IT IS ON THE NORTHWEST SLOPE OF THE HILL AND ABOUT 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED PROSPECT MT 2 NO 2 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE OUTCROP OF BEDROCK.  IT IS ON THE WEST SLOPE OF THE HILL AND ABOUT 1.5 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE PLACE TO SET AN AZIMUTH MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1980 (JS) PROSPECT MT 2 RECOVERED GOOD, PROTECTED BY PILE OF ROCKS AND SMALL WOODEN STRUCTURE (6 FEET).
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY WOOLPERT CONSULTANTS 1998 (BBS) DESCRIBED BY WOOLPERT LLP 1998 (ARL) .  THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 9.0 KM (5.60 MI) EAST OF NEWMARKET, 5.1 KM (3.15 MI) SOUTH OF THE MAINE AND NEW HAMPSHIRE STATE LINE, 4.7 KM (2.90 MI) WEST OF PORTSMOUTH, AT THE PEASE INTERNATIONAL TRADEPORT. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1912 NEAR THE UPPER WATCH HOUSE BELONGING TO WILLIS SANDS LIFE SAVING STATION. STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1930 I VISITED THIS STATION ON MAY 24TH AND NOVEMBER 16TH, 1930, AND FOUND THAT IT WAS MARKED WITH A STANDARD COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY DISK WHICH, ALTHOUGH SOMEWHAT DEFACED, WAS FIRMLY IN PLACE AND REASONABLE LEGIBLE.  ABOUT 5 INCHES SE OF THE STATION MARK WAS A DRILL HOLE CONTAINING THREE RUSTY BOLTS AND ABOUT 19 INCHES NNW OF THE MARK WAS ANOTHER DRILL HOLE WITH A SINGLE BOLT.  STATION IS NEAR THE SHORE BOULEVARD AND MAY BE REACHED BY FOLLOWING THIS BOULEVARD FOR A DISTANCE OF ABOUT 1.1 MILES N OF THE WALLIS SANDS COAST GUARD STATION.  THE WATCH HOUSE REFERRED TO IN THE DESCRIPTION IS NO LONGER IN THE VICINITY, HAVING BEEN MOVED AWAY SEVERAL YEARS AGO, I BELIEVE. STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK AND PULPIT ROCK WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCES WERE MEASURED WITH A STEEL TAPE AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE AND CORRECT WITH THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONS--  THE STATION MARK IS A CORPS OF ENGINEERS, U.S. ARMY, DISK, STAMPED PULPIT ROCK 142 1941 AND PROJECTS 2 IN.  A STEEL TOWER, ABOUT 75 FT. HIGH, HAS BEEN ERECTED OVER THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS STAMPED PULPIT ROCK NO 1 142 1941 AND PROJECTS ABOUT 1 FT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT 1956 A REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 (PULPIT ROCK) DATED 1941 AND LOCATED IN THE TOP OF ONE OF OUR HIGHWAY BOUNDS AT ODIORNES POINT, RYE, NEW HAMPSHIRE HAS BEEN DISTRUBED BY A LOCAL PARTY. THE HIGHWAY BOUND WAS FOUND BROKEN OFF AT GROUND LEVEL AND IS BEING REPLACED.  A NEW DISK STAMPED PULPIT ROCK NO 2 1956 WAS RESET IN THE NEW BOUND ON DECEMBER 19, 1956 AND IS 159.17 FEET FROM THE STATION.  THIS MARK IS IN THE SAME LOCATION AS WAS PREVIOUS R.M.L. PULPIT ROCK (DESTROYED).  IT IS NOW SET IN A NEW 7-INCH SQUARE GRANITE STATE HIGHWAY BOUND, 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND. THE ELEVATION OF THE NEW MARK WAS NOT DETERMINED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2018)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2018 (JRO) DID NOT FIND THE MARK AFTER TRAVERSING TO THE LOCATION FROM TWO NEARBY SHORT-SESSION STATIC POINTS AND DIGGING DOWN ABOUT A FOOT UNTIL HITTING WHAT TURNED OUT TO BE A ROCK.  FAIRLY WELL SATISFIED THAT THE SURFACE MARK IS GONE, OR ELSE THE GPS POINTS AND SUBSEQUENT TRAVERSE WERE WRONG.  VERY LIKELY THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS STILL THERE, BEST RECOVERED USING VRS TO NAVIGATE TO THE SPOT.  THE PROPERTY OWNER AT 825 HIGHWAY 1A, 2-STORY GREY FRAME HOUSE WITH FLAGPOLE IN THE FRONT YARD, WAS COOPERATIVE AND WOULD LIKELY APPROVE EXCAVATION FOR THE UNDERGROUND MARK AND RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF A SURFACE MARK.  COORDINATES WERE ESTABLISHED BY 30-MINUTE STATIC OBSERVATION AND JAVAD DPOS COMPUTATION ON THE UNSTAMPED RM DISK IN AN OUTCROP IN THE SOUTH SIDE YARD OF THE HOUSE.  N 43 01 59.73007, W 70 43 08.78853.  AS NOTED IN THE DESCRIPTION OF THIS STATION PULPIT ROCK 142, THE UNSTAMPED DISK IS A REFERENCE MARK TO THE OLD STATION, MEANING PULPIT ROCK OC0442. THE INVERSE FROM PULPIT ROCK OC0442 TO THE UNSTAMPED RM IS 310-15-53, 227.0 FT.  THE UNSTAMPED RM IS 314-21-11, 85.3 FT FROM A GRANITE HWY ROW MONUMENT OR BOUND.  PULPIT ROCK IS 127-48-19, 142.0 FT (43.3 M) AND ACROSS THE HIGHWAY FROM THE GRANITE ROW MONUMENT.

A NEW TO-REACH DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS- FROM THE JUNCTION OF NH ROUTE 10 AND US ROUTE 4 (A TRAFFIC LIGHT) IN WEST LEBANON, NH, GO EAST ON DANA STREET 2 BLOCKS TO A 4-WAY STOP. TAKE PASTURE LANE TO THE CUL-DE-SAC AT ITS END, WHERE A PAVED PRIVATE ROAD LEADS EAST.   FOLLOW THE PRIVATE ROAD PAST TWO PRIVATE RESIDENCES TO THE END OF PAVEMENT. CONTINUE ON GRAVEL/DIRT ROAD TO TOWER SITE AT TOP OF CRAFTS HILL. STATION IS ABOUT HALFWAY BETWEEN TWO MOST SOUTHERLY TOWERS, 18 FEET EAST OF CENTERLINE OF ACCESS ROAD, UNDER POWER DISTRIBUTION LINES, IN TOP OF ROCKY OUTCROP.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2.5 MI. E OF RYE CENTER, 7.0 MI. N OF HAMPTON BEACH, 7.25 MI. S OF PORTSMOUTH, ON A POINT OF LAND KNOWN AS RAGGED NECK, AND ON THE U.S. GOVERNMENT MILITARY RESERVATION.  IT IS ON A FLAT SANDY ROCKY PLOT OF GROUND, 96 FT. NW OF THE EXTREME POINT, 150 FT. NE OF THE NE POINT, AND 83.5 FT. N OF THE CENTER OF THE U.S. ARMY SEARCHLIGHT BASE.  IT IS A STANDARD STATION DISK, STAMPED RAGGED NECK 1943 AND SET FLUSH WITH THE ROCK SURFACE IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK, ABOUT 6- BY 10-IN. IN DIAMETER, PROJECTING 2 IN.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS SW OF THE STATION, 30 FT. NW OF THE END OF THE POINT, AND AT THE E EDGE OF THE CLEARED SPOT. IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED RAGGED NECK NO 1 1943 AND SET FLUSH WITH THE ROCK SURFACE IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SW OF THE STATION, 50 FT. NW OF THE CENTER OF THE U.S. ARMY SEARCHLIGHT, AND 50 FT. N OF THE SW SIDE OF THE POINT.  IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED RAGGED NECK NO 2 1943 AND SET FLUSH WITH THE ROCK SURFACE IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS ABOUT 0.3 MI. S-SW OF THE STATION, 3 FT. SE OF A STONE FENCE LINE, 186 FT. S OF THE SE CORNER OF A RED BARN, AND 126 FT. S OF THE S END OF THE BREAKWATER.  IT IS A STANDARD AZIMUTH-MARK DISK, STAMPED RAGGED NECK 1943 AND SET FLUSH WITH THE ROCK SURFACE IN A BOULDER, ABOUT 2- BY 3-FT. IN DIAMETER, PROJECTING 18 IN.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FARRAGAT HOTEL ON RYE BEACH, GO NE ON STATE ROUTE NO. 1-A FOR 3.0 MI. TO WHERE 1-A MAKES A SHARP LEFT TURN, AND A SIGN ON THE LEFT POINTING STRAIGHT AHEAD TO RAGGED NECK, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON A SANDY ROAD FOR 0.1 MI. TO THE ARMY SEARCHLIGHT AND THE STATION AS DESCRIBED.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION, GO BACK TO STATE ROUTE 1-A, BEAR LEFT AND CONTINUE FOR 0.55 MI. TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A SIGN SAUNDERS LOBSTERS, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW A DIRT ROAD E FOR 0.45 MI. TO THE MARK ON THE RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 27 M.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 0.5 MI SE FROM RYE BEACH. 0.5 MILE SOUTHEAST ALONG A BLACK TOP ROAD FROM THE POST OFFICE AT RYE BEACH, ROCKINGHAM COUNTY, THENCE 2.9 MILES NORTHEAST ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 1 A, ON RAGGED NECK POINT, 250 YARDS SOUTHEAST OF A SHARP CURVE IN THE HIGHWAY, 85 FEET WEST OF THE EDGE OF A PILE OF LOOSE BOULDERS ALONG THE END OF THE POINT, AND 78 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF A SEARCHLIGHT TOWER.  A STANDARD TRIANGULATION-STATION DISK, STAMPED RAGGED NECK 1943 AND SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE POST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCES WERE MEASURED WITH A STEEL TAPE AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  AN HOURS SEARCH BY THREE MEN FAILED TO REVEAL ANY TRACE OF THE AZIMUTH MARK.  THE RED BARN HAS BEEN RAZED AND THE SOUTH END OF THE SEAWALL CANNOT BE DETERMINED ON THE GROUND.  THE PUBLISHED DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING CORRECTIONS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE GROUNDS OF THE RYE HARBOR STATE PARK ON THE NORTH SIDE OF RYE HARBOR.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS EAST OF THE STATION, 30 FEET WEST OF THE END OF THE POINT AND 0.5 FEET UNDERGROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SOUTH OF THE STATION, THE ROCK IN WHICH IT IS SET PROJECTS 4 INCHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1988 (RSR) MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2018)  RECOVERY NOTE BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2018 (JRO) SEARCHED FOR THE MARKS FROM TWO OPUS POINTS SET NEARBY BUT FOUND NOTHING.  SEEMS LIKE THE MAIN STATION COULD BE THERE, FALLING AS IT DID IN SOLID HIGH GROUND, ALTHOUGH PROBING A SQUARE ABOUT TWO FEET ON A SIDE CENTERED ON THE POSITION SET OUT FROM AN OPUS POINT TURNED UP NOTHING BY ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS CONSIDERED LOST - TOO FAR BELOW THE STATION AND IN THE ACTIVE SURF AREA AT HIGH TIDE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS ALSO PROBABLY LOST, ALTHOUGH ON THE LAND SIDE OF THE ROCK SEAWALL, BUT IN AN AREA OF ALL STONES.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (RMB) GO TO NORTH EDGE OF CONCORD ON U.S. HIGHWAY NO. 3 TO THE CITY WATER WORKS AT PENACOOK STREET.  PROCEED WESTWARD ON PENACOOK ST. (FORMERLY LONG POND ROAD) 1.7 MILES TO A SHARP BEND IN THE ROAD JUST BEFORE REACHING THE HOUSE ON THE JORDAN FARM (FORMERLY FARNHAM).  AT THIS POINT, TAKE FARM AND QUARRY ROAD THROUGH THE WOODS TO THE STATION WHICH IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF RATTLESNAKE HILL.  THE STATION WAS RECOVERED BUT THE BOLT HAS BEEN REPLACED BY A STANDARD U.S.G.S BRASS DISC.  THE TRIANGLE CUT AROUND THE ORIGINAL MARK IS STILL VISIBLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JBW) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN RECOVERY NOTE BY R.M.B. IN 1942.  THERE ARE NOW NUMEROUS STEEL RODS SET IN DRILL HOLES AT VARIOUS DISTANCES FROM THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CITY WATER WORK BUILDING AT THE INTERSECTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 3 AND PENACOOK STREET, NEAR THE N EDGE OF CONCORD, GO 1.7 MI. W ON PENCOOK STREET TO A GRAVEL ROAD ON RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.45 MI. N TO A FORK, TAKE LEFT FORK 0.05 MI. TO ANOTHER FORK, TAKE LEFT FORK 0.15 MI. TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL, FROM HERE PACK ABOUT 0.2 MI. N-NE TO HIGHEST PART OF A WOODED HILL AND THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (RCY) STATION RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED, DUE TO ROAD CHANGES A NEW TO REACH FOLLOWS--TO REACH FROM THE CITY WATER WORKS BUILDING AT THE INTERSECTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 3 AND PENACOOK STREET, NEAR THE NORTH EDGE OF CONCORD, GO 1.7 MILES WEST ON PENACOOK STREET TO TOP OF GRADE AND SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW GRAVEL ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO FORKS, TAKE RIGHT FORK AND GO 0.25 MILE TO FORKS, TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO 0.2 MILE TO FORKS, TAKE RIGHT FORK AND GO ABOUT 200 YARDS TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR COMMERCIAL TYPE TRUCK.  FROM HERE PACK NORTH EASTERLY ON DIM WOODS ROAD TO HIGHEST POINT OF HILL.  ABOUT 10 MINUTES PACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1979)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1979 (RPD) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN 1961 IN GOOD CONDITION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2.0 MILES NW OF STATE HOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2004 (SWL) DESCRIPTION INADEQUATE. THERE ARE MANY TRAILS FROM SNOWMOBILES AND ATVS THROUGHOUT THE AREA.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2008 (RRS) FOUND CHISELED TRIANGLE AND BOLT IN ROCK LEDGE AT HIGHEST NATURAL POINT OF HILL, SLAG PILE .1 MILE S IS PROBABLY HIGHER   AS MENTIONED THERE ARE MANY OLD QUARRY ROADS NOW USED AS MTN BIKE TRAILS, BUT CAN DRIVE TO WITHIN .3 MILES OF STATION FROM E WITH PERMISSION OF WARDEN NH STATE PRISON

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF MOULTONBORO.  LAND OWNED BY L.L. HUNTRESS.  TO REACH GO FROM CENTER HARBOR TO HOUSE OF HERBERT STURTEVANT ABOUT 4 MILES N FROM CENTER HARBOR, THENCE TO TOP BY BRIDLE PATH 1-3/4 MILES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1876)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1876 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF MOULTONBORO.  TO REACH GO TO HOUSE OF GEO. MACK ABOUT 1 MILE W OF THE BIG-ROCK SCHOOLHOUSE, THENCE SOUTHERLY TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  SUMMIT IS BARE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A BOLT AND TRIANGLE CUT IN THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1934 (RE) TO LOCATE THE STATION GO FROM MOULTONBORO TO THE ROAD THAT LEADS TO THE FIRE LOOKOUT WHICH IS ON THE SUMMIT.  THE STATION IS 32 FEET NW OF THE LOOKOUT AND IS MARKED BY A BOLT AND TRIANGLE WITH A FLAGPOLE SET IN A PILE OF ROCKS DIRECTLY OVER IT.  MAGNETIC DIRECTIONS--WHITEFACE N 23 DEG E.  GUNSTOCK S 2 DEG E.  PLEASANT N 78 DEG E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION. STATION WAS FOUND TO BE NORTHEAST OF THE RED HILL LOOKOUT TOWER INSTEAD OF NORTHWEST AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1934 RECOVERY NOTE.  TWO NEW REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET.  A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS ABOUT 5.0 MILES NORTH OF MEREDITH, 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF MOULTONBORO AND 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CENTER SANDWICH, ON THE SUMMIT OF RED HILL MOUNTAIN AND IS ON PROPERTY OF THE STATE FOREST SERVICE.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN MOULTONBORO, GO SOUTHERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 25 FOR 2.6 MILES TO A ROAD FORK ON THE RIGHT. TAKE RIGHT FORK, DIRT ROAD, AND GO 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT, THE RED HILL ROAD.  TURN RIGHT, GO 1.8 MILES TO A FARM HOUSE AND WHERE THE ROAD MAKES A SHARP LEFT TURN, THIS IS END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR 2-WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK.  (FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL A NARROW ROAD LEADS TO SUMMIT OF RED HILL AND IS PASSABLE FOR A FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE JEEP ONLY.) FOLLOW THE NARROW ROAD, UP HILL, FOR 1.7 MILES TO SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS A 1-INCH IRON PIN, NO STAMPING, LEADED INTO A 1-1/2 INCH DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  THE IRON PIN IS 1 INCH BELOW THE SURFACE OF ROCK.  THE OUTCROP OF ROCK MARKS THE HIGHEST POINT OF MOUNTAIN.  IT IS 36 FEET EAST OF THE MOST NORTHERLY LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 32.5 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE MOST SOUTHERLY LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, AND 51 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF A FIRE PLACE BUILT OF ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED RED HILL NO 1 1873, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS 3 FEET BY 5 FEET AND FLUSH WITH SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS ON EASTERLY SLOPE OF PEAK, 62 FEET EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE MOST SOUTHERLY LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, AND 30 FEET NORTH OF FIRE PLACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED RED HILL NO 2 1873, IS CEMENTED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  THE OUTCROP OF ROCK FORMS A SMALL LEDGE ON WEST SLOPE OF PEAK.  IT IS 84 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF SHELTER AND 27 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE MOST SOUTHERLY LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE FROM STATION RED HILL 1873 TO THE CENTER, AT BASE, OF THE RED HILL LOOKOUT TOWER, DISTANCE BEING 40.55 FEET (12.360 METERS) SOUTHWEST OF THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2017)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2017 (JWM) I DID NOT FIND THE DEFINED BOLT AT THE BENCHMARK?S LOCATION. INSTEAD, I FOUND THAT A TRIANGULATION STATION STANDARD DISK HAS BEEN PLACED ON TOP OF THE LOCATION OF THE STATION MARK AND HAS BEEN CEMENTED IN PLACE. IT IS STAMPED U.S. COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY TRIANGULATION STATION AND RED HILL 1873. THERE ARE NO CRACKS IN THE DISK?S CEMENT.  AS I DID NOT FIND THE DEFINED BOLT, I CANNOT SAY THAT I RECOVERED THE BENCHMARK. NOR CAN I SAY THAT IT HAS BEEN DESTROYED, AS IT MAY STILL BE BELOW THE TRIANGULATION STATION STANDARD DISK.  I RECOVERED THE TRIANGULATION STATION STANDARD DISK AT N 43? 45.350? W 071? 27.470?  I RECOVERED REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 AT N 43? 45.341? W 071? 27.474?  I MADE A NON-EXHAUSTIVE SEARCH FOR REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND DID NOT RECOVER IT.  DIGITAL PHOTOS ARE AVAILABLE ON OC1360 WWW.GEOCACHING.COM.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATE FOREST SERVICE LOOKOUT TOWER IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF MOULTONBORO AND 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CENTER SANDWICH, ON THE SUMMIT OF RED HILL MOUNTAIN.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE FROM TRIANGULATION STATION RED HILL 1873 TO THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER, DISTANCE BEING 40.55 FEET (12.360 METERS) SOUTHWEST OF STATION RED HILL 1873.  THE LOOKOUT TOWER IS A SQUARE WOODEN CABIN SUPPORTED BY A FOUR-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE AND IS ABOUT 35 FEET IN HEIGHT OVERALL.                            STATION RECOVERY (2017)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2017 (JWM) THE  STATION MARK WAS DEFINED IN 1958 AS A SQUARE WOODEN CABIN AND WAS 27' HIGH. A NEW CABIN WAS PLACED IN 1972, RAISING THE TOWER ABOUT TEN FEET. THERE IS A FIRE LOOKOUT TOWER ON TOP OF RED HILL, BUT IT IS NOT THE ONE THAT WAS DEFINED IN 1958 AS BEING THE BENCHMARK. THAT IS THE BASIS FOR ME TO SAY THAT THE DEFINED BENCHMARK WAS DESTROYED.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (PLB) STATION IS LOCATED ON ROLLINS HILL, IN STRATHAM TOWNSHIP, ABOUT 3 MILES ENE OF EXETER, ABOUT 2.6 MILES WNW OF NORTH HAMPTON CENTER, ON THE PROPERTY OF MISS FLORENCE ROLLINS WHO LIVES ABOUT 0.15 MILE E OF THE STATION.  IT IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL, ABOUT 300 FEET N OF THE N SIDE OF AN ORCHARD, 9 FEET S OF A WILD-CHERRY TREE, AND 6 FEET S OF A STONE FENCE WHICH RUNS SW-NE OVER THE TOP OF THE HILL.  MONUMENT PROTRUDES ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  SURFACE AND UNDERGROUND MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE, AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS WSW OF THE STATION AND 10 FEET N OF STONE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 14 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS N OF THE STATION, ABOUT 80 FEET NW OF STONE FENCE.  REACHED FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PORTSMOUTH BY GOING S ON U.S. HIGHWAY 1, 8.0 MILES TO A T-ROAD RIGHT MARKED HOBBS ROAD, EXETER, THENCE RIGHT 0.2 MILE TO T-ROAD, THENCE RIGHT 0.35 MILE TO JUNCTION MARKED WALNUT AVE., NEW MARKET, EXETER, THENCE LEFT 0.3 MILE TO T-ROAD JUST AFTER PASSING CEMETERY, THENCE RIGHT 2.3 MILES TO T-ROAD LEFT, THENCE LEFT 0.3 MILE TO THE ROLLINS HOME WHICH IS ONE OF A PAIR OF HOUSES ON THE S SIDE OF ROAD JUST AFTER PASSING A SMALL CHURCH.  THE STATION IS ON THE HILL DUE W OF THE HOUSE AND A TRUCK MAY BE TAKEN TO THE STATION BUT INQUIRY WILL HAVE TO BE MADE AT THE ROLLINS HOME.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCE TO THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE MEASURED WITH A STEEL TAPE AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING EXCEPTIONS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 700 FT. SE OF THE HOME OF M.P. RUNNELLS, ABOUT 600 FT. S OF THE ROAD, ABOUT 300 FT. W OF THE W SIDE OF AN ORCHARD, AND 6 FT. E OF A STONE FENCE WITH ROCKS WHICH RUNS N AND S OVER THE TOP OF THE HILL.  STATION IS STAMPED ROLLINS 1941 AND PROJECTS 4 IN.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS ON THE W SIDE OF THE STONE FENCE.  IT IS STAMPED ROLLINS NO 1 1941.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS NW OF THE STATION, ON THE W SIDE OF THE STONE FENCE.  IT IS STAMPED ROLLINS NO 2 1941.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (JLH) STATION AND RM 1 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  RM 2 NOT SEARCHED FOR.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF MOULTONBORO, 1.0 MILE SOUTHEAST OF BEARCAMP POND, ON THE EAST SIDE OF STATE HIGHWAY 25 AND IS BELIEVED TO BE ON HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CONWAY, GO SOUTH ON STATE HIGHWAY 16 FOR 15.8 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 16 AND 25, TURN RIGHT ON STATE HIGHWAY 25 AND GO 3.3 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 113, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON STATE HIGHWAY 25 FOR 1.9 MILES TO THE TOWN OF SOUTH TAMWORTH, CONTINUE SOUTHERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 25 FOR 3.5 MILES TO A PRIVATE ROAD RUNNING NORTHEAST ALONG THE SIDE OF THE BANK AT REAL ESTATE SIGN AND STATION ON THE LEFT.  STATION MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS STAMPED SANDWICH 1958.  THE SURFACE DISK IS SET IN A SQUARE CONCRETE POST WHICH PROJECTS 2 INCHES.  IT IS 45.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF STATE HIGHWAY 25, 12 FEET EAST OF A SMALL REAL ESTATE SIGN, 14 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE DIRT ROAD AND 4 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF A WHITE GUARD RAIL POST.  THE UNDERGROUND DISK IS SET IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE 48 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SANDWICH NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET ON THE NORTH SIDE.  IT IS 14.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE DIRT ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SANDWICH NO 2 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 3 FEET ON THE NORTH SIDE.  IT IS 19.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE DIRT ROAD.  AZIMUTH MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED SANDWICH 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 1 FOOT.  IT IS 37.5 FEET SOUTH OF THE CENTER OF STATE HIGHWAY 25, 27 FEET EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF A CONCRETE CULVERT AND 12 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE LINE.  A STANDARD WITNESS POST WAS SET 5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE MARK.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION, GO SOUTHERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 25 FOR 0.45 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP RIGHT FORK AND FOLLOW STATE HIGHWAY 25 FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE ON FOOT TRAIL ALONG THE TELEPHONE LINES FOR ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES TO FIRE TOWER AT TOP OF SIGNAL MOUNTAIN AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK SET IN A DRILLHOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK AND STAMPED SIGNAL NO 1 1959 IS 54 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A CABIN AND 33 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF FIRE TOWER. (REFERENCE MARK NO. 2), A STANDARD GEOLOGICAL DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK IS 5 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE STEPS OF FIRE TOWER AND 6 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST LEG OF FIRE TOWER.
