THE UNDERGROUND DISK IS SET 30 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE IN AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  STAMPED STARK NO 1 1959.  AND SET FLUSH.  IT IS 34.5 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH RAIL.  11.5 FEET SOUTH OF A 10-INCH PINE TREE WITH TRIANGLE BLAZE AND METAL WITNESS SIGN.  ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  STAMPED STARE NO 2 1959.  AND SET FLUSH.  IT IS 29.0 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH RAIL.  ABOUT 1 FOOT HIGHER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 3 AND ROUTE 110 AT THE SOUTH EDGE OF GROVETOWN.  GO EAST ON ROUTE 110 FOR 2.6 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD NORTH.  CONTINUE ON ROUTE 110 FOR 0.4 MILE TO TRIANGLE BLAZED 10-INCH PINE TREE AND METAL WITNESS SIGN ON RIGHT AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY US ARMY 1941 (PLB) STATION IS LOCATED ON THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE PARAPET OF BATTERY DAVID HUNTER AT FORT STARK, JUST N OF THE BATTERY COMMAND PEDESTAL.  U.S.E. STATION H, A BRASS PLUG SET IN THE CONCRETE, IS 2.948 M. SW OF THE STATION.  IT IS A U.S. ARMY MAP-CONTROL DISK, COUNTERSUNK IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE.  BOTH REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS, SET IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE PARAPET.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS NE OF THE STATION, ABOUT 2 FT. S OF THE N EDGE AND 32 FT. E OF THE W EDGE OF THE PARAPET.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SE OF THE STATION, 2.1 FT. N OF THE S EDGE AND 31.7 FT. E OF THE W EDGE OF THE PARAPET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) THE STATION HAS BEEN DESTROYED BY U.S. ARMY CONSTRUCTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. NO PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION WAS AVAILABLE AND A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON JAFFREY POINT, NEWCASTLE ISLAND, AT FORT STARK, S OF THE FIRE CONTROL BUILDING, 22.8 FT. S OF THE EDGE OF THE CONCRETE ABUTMENT, 15.9 FT. S-SW OF A VENTILATOR PIPE, 11.3 FT. NW OF THE NE CORNER OF THE OBSERVATION POST, AND 9.7 FT. E OF THE EDGE OF THE ABUTMENT.  IT IS A U.S.E. DISK, STAMPED STARK 145 1941 AND COVERED WITH 1 FT. OF EARTH AND SOD.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS NE OF THE STATION, IN THE S ABUTMENT OF THE SECOND EMPLACEMENT FROM THE CONTROL BUILDING, 32 FT. E OF THE W CORNER OF THE ABUTMENT, 24 FT. W OF THE E CORNER OF THE ABUTMENT, AND 17.4 FT. E-NE OF THE VENTILATOR PIPE. IT IS A STANDARD REFERENCE-MARK DISK, STAMPED STARK 145 NO 1 1941 AND SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE ABUTMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1991)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1991 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1994)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1994 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (WD) FOUND THE STATION, REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED EXCEPT THAT FORT STARK IS NOW A STATE HISTORICAL PARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2007 (JLH) STATION, RM 1, AND RM 2 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) THE STATION IS ABOUT 13-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF GORHAM, AND ABOUT 2-1/4 MILES NORTHEAST OF JEFFERSON, ON THE WEST ONE OF TWO HIGH PEAKS OF THE PLINY RANGE, AND IS ON THE PROPERTY OF MR. HERBERT L. MALCALM.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 2 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16, AT THE WEST EDGE OF GORHAM, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 2 FOR 12.9 MILES TO THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 115 AND 12.  CONTINUE ON U.S. HIGHWAY 2 FOR 3.4 MILES TO THE WAUMBEK HOTEL IN JEFFERSON.  TURN RIGHT ON A SIDE ROAD WHICH IS OPPOSITE THE DRIVEWAY ENTRANCE TO WAUMBEK HOTEL AND GO NORTHERLY, UP HILL, FOR 0.15 MILE TO A ROAD FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTHERLY ON WOODS ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A ROAD FORK. TAKE LEFT FORK, GO 0.1 MILE TO A COVERED WELL ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTHERLY ON WOODS ROAD FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO A SMALL SIGN ON TREE STARR TRAIL BEAR RIGHT, ON A LOGGING ROAD FOR ABOUT 1/4 MILE TO A SIGN ON TREE PATH.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW A FOOT TRAIL TO SUMMIT AND THE STATION.  ABOUT A 2-1/2 HOUR PACK.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK, NO STAMPING, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER 7 FEET BY 15 FEET AND PROJECTS ABOUT 2 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS 12 FEET WEST OF THE FOOT TRAIL, 14 FEET NORTHWEST OF A BLAZE ON A SMALL PINE TREE, 6 FEET WEST OF A BLAZE ON A SMALL PINE TREE, AND ABOUT 100 FEET NORTH OF THE SHELTER.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED STARR KING USGS NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 12 FEET BY 6 FEET AND PROJECTS ABOUT 8 FEET ON THE EAST SIDE.  IT IS 13 FEET EAST OF THE FOOT TRAIL AND 2 FEET WEST OF THE EAST EDGE OF BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED STARR KING USGS NO 2 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH IS ABOUT 2 FEET BY 2 FEET AND PROJECTS 1 FOOT ABOVE THE GROUND.  IT IS 20 FEET WEST OF THE FOOT TRAIL.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET.  A DRILL HOLE IN THE SAME BOULDER AS THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND TO BE 0.875 METERS (2.87 FEET) WEST OF THE STATION DISK.                            STATION RECOVERY (2010)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2010 (DKA) I DID NOT LOOK FOR THE RM'S AS MOSS IS COVERING ALL THE BOULDERS IN THE AREA AND  I DID NOT BRING UP A METAL DETECTOR.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1875 (ETQ) TO REACH THIS MOUNTAIN GO TO JEFFERSON VILLAGE AND TAKE A BRIDLE PATH JUST ABOVE WAMBEO HOUSE AND GO 2-1/2 MILES N TO THE TOP.  THE SUMMIT IS CLEAR THOUGH THE WOODS REACH NEARLY TO THE TOP.  STATION IS MARKED BY BOLT AND TRIANGLE.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1917 (JDC) IN STEWARTSTOWN TOWNSHIP, ON TOP OF A ROCK BLUFF, AN OUTCROP ON THE SOUTH END OF THE RIDGE ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE CONNECTICUT RIVER, OVERLOOKING WEST STEWARTSTOWN.  STATION MARK IS A BRONZE DISK OF THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA SET IN A CREVICE IN THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION. STATION IS NOW ON THE PROPERTY OF THE ST. REGIS PAPER COMPANY AND IS LOCATED ON THE NORTH END OF A RIDGE AND NOT THE SOUTH END AS STATED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A DISK OF THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILLHOLE IN THE LARGE ROCK OUTCROP AND THE DISK IS STAMPED STEWART NO 1 1917.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 8 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF ROCK OUTCROP.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK AND IS STAMPED STEWART NO 2 1959.  TO REACH STATION FROM THE RAILROAD DEPOT IN WEST STEWARTSTOWN GO SOUTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 3 FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT. TURN LEFT ON BACK POND ROAD AND GO 0.75 MILE TO A FIELD ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO 0.45 MILE TO A SMALL ABANDONED SHED AT THE NORTH EDGE OF CULTIVATED FIELD.  TURN LEFT OFF FIELD ROAD AND GO 0.05 MILE TO THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF FIELD AND END END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTH NORTHWEST FOR ABOUT FIVE MINUTES TO THE ROCK LEDGE AT THE HIGHEST POINT AND STATION.  1959 OBSERVATIONS TAKEN FROM A 4 FOOT WOOD STAND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (NP) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NEW DESCRIPTION--IN STEWARTSON TOWNSHIP ON A ROCK BLUFF, AN OUTCROP ON THE SOUTH END OF THE RIDGE OVERLOOKING WEST STEWARTSTOWN, N.H. TO REACH THE STATION, FROM THE BRIDGE CROSSING THE CONNECTICUT RIVER AT CANAAN, VERMONT, PROCEED 0.2 MILES EAST TO THE INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 114 AND 3.  TURN NORTH AND PROCEED 0.25 MILES, THEN TURN EAST ONTO A ROAD WHICH CROSSES THE RAILROAD TRACKS AND PROCEED FOR 0.25 MILES TO A SMALL ROAD BETWEEN TWO HOUSES, LEADING UP TO THE FIELD BELONGING TO THE ST. REGIS COMPANY.  FROM THE FIELD THERE IS A TRAIL WHICH LEADS TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  STATION MARK--AN IBC TRIANGULATION TABLET CEMENTED ON TOP OF THE SHAFT OLD TABLET WHICH WAS SET IN A CREVICE IN THE ROCK.  A YELLOW WITNESS POST WAS SET ON A TREE NEARBY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1974)  RECOVERY NOTE BY VT DEPT OF HIGHWAYS 1974 (LMC) STATION RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION, TABLET APPARENTLY REPLACED BY IBC WITH IBC TABLET SOMETIME SUBSEQUENT TO 1959.  1 - STATION MARK SHOULD BE SET LOWER, ABOUT 3 INCHES, INTO THE LEDGE, CONCRETE IS BREAKING AWAY.  2 - RM NO. 1 IS IN PLACE BUT HAS BEEN WORKED LOOSE BY VANDALS (PROBABLY AN OLD SPLIT-SHANK TABLET).  3 - RM NO. 2 SHEARED OFF BY VANDALS, HOLLOW SHANK REMAINS.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) TO REACH GO FROM WARNER VILLAGE.  TAKE  WHAT IS CALLED THE MINK HILL ROAD TO THE HOUSE OF A.W. HARRIMAN, ON THE S SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN.  THENCE THE ASCENT TO THE SUMMIT IS STEEP, THROUGH PASTURE AND WOODS.  THE STATION MARK IS A HOLE DRILLED IN THE ROCK, HOLDING A LEAD BOLT.  A TRIANGLE IS DRILLED AROUND THE STATION MARK, ONE SIDE OF WHICH POINTS N AND S.  THE STATION MARK IS N 49 DEG W, MAGNETIC BEARING, FROM A LARGE BOULDER, IN WHICH A HOLE IS DRILLED FOR A RANGE MARK.  THE STATION AND SIGNAL ARE IN CHARGE OF A.W. HARRIMAN, OWNER OF THE LAND, WARNER, NEW HAMPSHIRE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (CEB) THE MARK IS NOT STAMPED.  THE LEAD BOLT AND CHISELED TRIANGLE ARE STILL READILY IDENTIFIABLE.  DID NOT SEARCH FOR RANGE MARK.  LEFT 4 FT HIGH PILE OF STONES OVER MARK.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1915 (JEM) IN AUCKLAND TOWNSHIP, ABOUT 3 MILES NORTH OF MALVINA, QUEBEC, RAILROAD STATION, IN VERY SWAMPY GROUND AT THE HEAD OF HALLS STREAM, AND 52 FEET WEST OF MONUMENT 507.  STATION MARK--STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN A 3 - FOOT CONCRETE - FILLED DRAIN TILE.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BOTTLE FILLED WITH GRAVEL AND BURIED 4 INCHES BELOW THE TILE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (WMS) THE CONCRETE IS VERY POOR BUT THE TABLET APPEARS TO BE IN A GOOD LOCATION.
markers.setting: SET IN CONCRETE IN A CLAY TILE PIPE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES NORTH-NORTHWEST OF PLYMOUTH. ABOUT 7 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF WARREN.  ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES NORTHEAST OF RUMNEY.  ON THE TOP OF MT. STINSON.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  STAMPED STINSON 1959, AND FLUSH WITH THE OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  IT IS 18.04 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF MT. STINSON LOOKOUT TOWER.  AND ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE MOUNTAIN.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG BASE OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER.  IT IS STAMPED STINSON NO 1 1959.  PROJECTS ABOUT 24 INCHES AND IS ABOUT THE SAME ELEVATION AS THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  STAMPED STINSON NO 2 1959. AND FLUSH WITH THE OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  IT IS 21.2 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF MT. STINSON LOOKOUT TOWER. 46.0 FEET SOUTH OF A TELEPHONE POLE.  AND ABOUT 1.0 FOOT LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  TO REACH FROM RUMNEY, NEW HAMPSHIRE, POST OFFICE GO NORTH ON STINSON LAKE ROAD FOR 4.0 MILES TO GRAVEL SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND SIGN CAMP WUNNEGEN FOR GIRLS.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.3 MILE TO FORKS AND SIGN CAMP WUNNEGEN RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.45 MILE TO A T-ROAD AND SIGN STINSON MT TRAIL.  TURN RIGHT ON TRAIL CROSSING A WOODEN BRIDGE FOR 0.25 MILE TO WHERE THE FOOT TRAIL TURNS LEFT**.  THIS IS ETT UNLESS YOU HAVE A 4-WHEEL DRIVE JEEP WITH A WINCH.  WITH A JEEP CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON TRACTOR ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO WHERE ROAD BEARS LEFT.  CONTINUE ON TRACTOR ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO GAP IN OLD ROCK FENCE AND CROSSROADS.  TURN RIGHT FOR ABOUT 250 FEET TO WHERE ROAD TURNS SHARP LEFT UP HILL.  TURN LEFT ON TRACTOR ROAD FOR 0.5 MILE TO WOODEN BRIDGE.  CROSS BRIDGE AND CONTINUE 1.5 MILES TO LOOKOUT TOWER AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  **WITHOUT A JEEP TURN LEFT ON THE FOOT TRAIL AND PACK ABOUT 1-1/2 HOURS ON TRAIL AS MARKED TO TOP OF MOUNTAIN AND STATION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS 2-1/2 OR 3 MILES NE FROM THE VILLAGE OF RUMNEY CENTER.  SIGNAL SET ON LEDGE ON HIGHEST POINT ON W END OF BALD PART OF MOUNTAIN.  TO REACH STATION GO TO HOUSE OF J.B. ELLIOTT 1-1/2 MILES FROM SAID VILLAGE, FROM THERE ABOUT E TO TOP OF MOUNTAIN.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ON TOP OF STINSON MTN. ABOUT 7 MILES NORTHWEST OF PLYMOUTH.  ABOUT 7 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF WARREN. IT IS A FOUR-LEGGED STEEL STRUCTURE WITH A WOOD BUILDING ON TOP.  IT IS ABOUT 50 FEET IN HEIGHT AND THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE APEX OF THE ROOF.  A MEASUREMENT WAS MADE FROM STATION STINSON TO THE CENTER OF THE TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1961)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1961 (CWM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN THE ORIGIONAL DESCRIPTION.

BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) THIS HILL IS AT THE RIGHT FROM THE ROAD LEADING FROM STODDARD TO MARLOW, BACK OF THE HOUSE OF NATHAN D. CURTIS.  LAND OWNED BY CURTIS.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST POINT ON A LEDGE, AND MARKED BY A LEAD BOLT IN THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1957 (JBW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE MARK IS NOW UNDER THE PITCHER MOUNTAIN LOOKOUT TOWER ABOUT 1 FT. W OF THE INTERSECTED CENTER OF THE TOWER, AND 1.5 FT. SE OF A 1-1/2-FT. HIGH IRON PIN. TWO REFERENCE MARKS AND AN AZIMUTH MARK WERE ESTABLISHED.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 9 AND 123 (ABOUT 15 MI. NE OF KEENE), GO N ON STATE HIGHWAY 123 FOR 4.6 MI. TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE NW ON STATE HIGHWAY 123 FOR 0.4 MI. TO A GRAVEL ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT FOR ABOUT 100 FT. AND RIGHT AGAIN (THROUGH A GATE) AND FOLLOW GRAVEL ROAD FOR 0.3 MI. TO END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK E AND N UP TRAIL TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS ON TOP OF A LARGE, 4-FT. HIGH OUTCROP OF BEDROCK ON THE NE EDGE OF THE MOUNTAIN TOP.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK AND IS STAMPED STODDARD MT NO 1 1873.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS IN A 2-FT. HIGH OUTCROP OF BEDROCK ON THE SE EDGE OF THE MOUNTAIN TOP.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK AND IT IS STAMPED STODDARD MT NO 2 1873.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS IN A TRIANGULAR-SHAPED BOULDER 5- BY 3- BY 3-FT. HIGH IN A FENCE ROW.  IT IS 29 FT. SE OF A POWERLINE POLE, 26 FT. NE OF THE CENTERLINE OF STATE HIGHWAY 123, AND 15 FT. NW OF A FENCE CORNER.  THE DISK IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE BOULDER AND IT IS STAMPED STODDARD MT 1873.  THE STATION MARK IS A LEAD BOLT IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 1 METER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (GAM) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  NO SEARCH WAS MADE FOR THE AZIMUTH MARK.  THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NH PUB WORK + HWYS 1982 (PSB) THE STATION, REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 AND THE AZIMUTH MARK WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION. A METAL BUILDING HAS BEEN BUILT NEXT TO THE STATION AND IT IS NOT POSSIBLE TO OCCUPY IT AT THIS TIME. THE BUILDING BLOCKED MEASUREMENTS TO THE REFERENCE MARKS.  NO DISTANCE WAS TAPED BETWEEN REFERENCE MARKS DUE TO BRUSH ON LINE.  A PRECISE TAPE TRAVERSE TIE WAS MADE TO STATION 425-0160 NHDPWH WHICH WAS USED AS THE MAIN CONTROL POINT.  THE STATION IS A LEAD PLUG IN A DRILL HOLE SURROUNDED BY A CHISELED TRIANGLE AND IS SET IN A LARGE ROCK OUTCROP AT THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN.  THE STATION IS UNDER THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF A FIRE LOOKOUT TOWER. 3.0 METERS (9.9 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE NORTHWEST LEG OF THE TOWER, 2.7 METERS (8.8 FT) NORTHEAST FROM THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF THE TOWER, 0.3 METERS (1.1 FT) WEST FROM THE CONCRETE FOUNDATION OF THE METAL BUILDING.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---STODDARD MT NO 1 1873---, SET INTO A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP. 20 METERS (66 FT) NORTHEAST FROM THE NORTHEAST LEG OF THE TOWER, 8.8 METERS (29 FT) NORTHEAST FROM THE NORTHEAST GUY WIRE ANCHOR, 28.7 METERS (94 FT) NORTHWEST FROM THE SOUTHEAST GUY WIRE ANCHOR, 28.3 METERS (93 FT) NORTHEAST FROM THE NORTHWEST GUY WIRE ANCHOR.  MARK IS 1.2 METERS BELOW THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED ---STODDARD MT NO 2 1873---, SET INTO DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP.  20 METERS (66 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF THE TOWER, 17.7 METERS (58 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE SOUTHEAST LEG OF THE TOWER, 8.4 METERS (27.5 FT) SOUTH FROM THE SOUTHEAST GUY WIRE ANCHOR, 4.9 METERS (16 FT) EAST FROM AN UNUSED ANCHOR BOLT.  MARK IS 2 METERS BELOW THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS A STANDARD NHDPWH DISK STAMPED---425 0160---, SET INTO A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP.  5.8 METERS (19 FT) SOUTH FROM THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF THE TOWER, 7.9 METERS (26 FT) SOUTHWEST FROM THE SOUTHEAST LEG OF THE TOWER, 13.1 METERS (43 FT) WEST FROM THE SOUTHEAST GUY WIRE ANCHOR, 6.1 METERS (20 FT) EAST FROM THE SOUTHWEST GUY WIRE ANCHOR.  MARK IS 0.674 METERS BELOW THE STATION.  THE AZIMUTH MARK WAS POSITIONED FROM STATION --425-0160 NHDPWH--DURING THIS SURVEY AND HAS A COMPLETE DESCRIPTION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY NH PUB WORK + HWYS 1982 (PSB) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2.4 KM (1.5 MI) NORTHWEST OF STODDARD, 5.6 KM (3.5 MI) SOUTHEAST OF MARLOW, 9.7 KM (6.0 MI) SOUTH OF WASHINGTON, IN THE TOWN OF STODDARD.  ON STATE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN STODDARD GO NORTHWEST FOR 4.2 KM (2.6 MI) ON STATE HIGHWAY 123 TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. OPPOSITE A DIM FIELD ROAD ON THE LEFT.   THE STATION IS A STANDARD NGS DISK STAMPED---STODDARD MT 1873---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A 1-METER BY 1-METER BOULDER WHICH IS IN A STONE  WALL AND ABOUT 1.2 METERS ABOVE THE HIGHWAY.  7.9 METERS (26.0 FT) EAST FROM THE CENTERLINE OF THE HIGHWAY, 2.1 METERS (7.0 FT) WEST FROM A WIRE FENCE LINE, 9.3 METERS (30.5 FT) SOUTH FROM POWER LINE POLE NUMBER 68/NET+T/PSCO/31/65, 80 METERS (250 FT) SOUTH FROM A ROAD LEADING EAST TO A FIELD.                            STATION RECOVERY (2020)  RECOVERY NOTE BY WALKERSVILLE SOUTHERN RR 2020 (MFM) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 STATION IS ON THE E END OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE SUMMIT OF STRATHAM HILL.  THE PORTSMOUTH AND EXETER ELECTRIC CARS PASS ALONG THE ROAD JUST N OF THE HILL.  A 1/2-INCH IRON BOLT, THE TOP BENT OVER, IS SUNK IN A LARGE ROCK JUST OVER THE TOP OF THE HILL TOWARD THE N, JUST W OF THE STATION IS AN OLD CIRCULAR SUMMER-HOUSE WITH A POST INSIDE HAVING A BRASS PLATE WITH NUMEROUS DIRECTIONS MARKED UPON IT.  STILL FARTHER W IS A LARGE FLAGPOLE WITH TOP MAST AND WELL GUYED WITH HEAVY WIRE.  IT IS SET IN SOLID CONCRETE FOUNDATION AND IS 18 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN SOLID ROCK WHICH PROJECTS A FEW INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE FOLLOWING ARE REFERENCES--A FLAGPOLE 29.68 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 66 DEG 25 MIN E.  CENTER OF SUMMERHOUSE, 17.30 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 63 DEG 56 MIN E. AND AN IRON BOLT IN ROCK, 8.14 METERS FROM THE STATION, S 7 DEG 57 MIN E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1928)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1928 (GCM) STATION IS ON THE E END OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE SUMMIT OF STRATHAM HILL.  THIS HILL IS INCLUDED IN STRATHAM HILL PARK. THE PORTSMOUTH AND EXETER ELECTRIC CAR LINE TRACK WAS TAKEN UP IN 1911.  THE ORIGINAL STATION MARK, A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN SOLID ROCK, PROJECTING A FEW INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND, AND WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE OLD SUMMER-HOUSE HAS BEEN DESTROYED, THE POST WITH DIRECTIONS HAS BEEN REMOVED.  ON THE LOCATION OF THE OLD SUMMER-HOUSE, JUST W OF THE STATION, IS A METAL CIRCULAR DIAL SUPPORTED ON 6 IRON POSTS, ESTABLISHED BY U.S. SURVEY, AUGUST, 1910.  THIS DIAL GIVES ELEVATION OF POINT AS WELL AS DIRECTIONS AND DISTANCES TO VARIOUS POINTS.  THE LARGE FLAGPOLE WITH TOP MAST WIRE GUYS, IS IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE IRON BOLT WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  DISTANCES WERE CHECKED.  APPROXIMATE NEW REFERENCE--STAR IN CENTER OF DIRECTION DIAL IS 34.2 FEET FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1930)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1930 I VISITED THIS LOCALITY FREQUENTLY, THE LAST TIME BEING DECEMBER 10, 1930.  THE DRILL HOLE WHICH MARKS THE STATION IS IN GOOD CONDITION, APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN UNDISTURBED, AND MAY BE EASILY FOUND.  THE FLAGPOLE AND BENT BOLT REFERRED TO IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION REMAIN AS STATED, BUT THE SUMMER-HOUSE WAS REMOVED SOME YEARS AGO.  THERE IS, HOWEVER, A SUBSTANTIAL CAST-IRON TABLE, OR DIAL, WITH THE NAMES OF NUMEROUS PROMINENT OBJECTS ARRANGED RADIALLY, IN RAISED LETTERS.  THE TABLE IS ABOUT 4 FEET IN DIAMETER AND HAS SIX LEGS WHICH ARE SET IN SOLID CONCRETE BASE.  THE CENTER OF THE TABLE IS ABOUT 34.4 FEET FROM THE STATION AND BEARS ABOUT 6-1/4 DEG W OF THE FLAGPOLE, OR ABOUT S 72 DEG 40 MIN E, VIEWED FROM THE STATION.  STRATHAM HILL, ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED, HAS BEEN A PUBLIC PARK, CALLED STRATHAM HILL PARK, SINCE 1906.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS OPEN, WITH ONLY A FEW SMALL TREES AND BUSHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NEW HAMPSHIRE GEODETIC SURVEY 1931 A SUBSTANTIAL STEEL FIRE-TOWER IS BEING BUILT NEAR THE STATION, FOR THE NEW HAMPSHIRE FORESTRY DEPARTMENT.  THE TOWER IS ABOUT 20 FEET SQUARE AT THE BASE, AND THE CENTER OF THE SQUARE IS ABOUT 18.4 FEET FROM THE STATION, IN AZIMUTH ABOUT 315 DEG 35 MIN.  THE TOWER IS TO BE ABOUT 65 FEET HIGH, I AM TOLD, AND IT WILL BE A PROMINENT LANDMARK.  IN OTHER RESPECTS THE STATION APPEARED TO BE IN THE SAME CONDITION AS WHEN I REPORTED ON IT IN 1930, AND I FOUND NOTHING TO INDICATE THAT IT HAD BEEN DISTURBED IN THE PROCESS OF INSTALLING THE FOUNDATIONS FOR THE TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (PLB) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS ON THE E END OF THE HIGHEST SUMMIT OF STRATHAM HILL 1.5 MILES NE OF STRATHAM AND 2.9 MILES W OF GREENLAND.  THE DRILL HOLE MARKING THE STATION APPEARS NOT TO HAVE BEEN DISTURBED IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF A SUBSTANTIAL STEEL FIRE TOWER FOR THE NEW HAMPSHIRE FOREST SERVICE SO CLOSE TO THE STATION TO THE SE THAT AN OBSERVING TOWER CANNOT BE BUILT OVER THE STATION.  STRATHAM 2 WAS ESTABLISHED SE OF THE FIRE TOWER AND TIED INTO THE STATION BY DISTANCE AND DIRECTION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION, AS DESCRIBED IN 1928. DESCRIPTION COMPLETE, CORRECT, AND ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RCA) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY L.A. LAPINE IN 1973 AND WAS FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STATION WAS NOT OCCUPIED AT THIS TIME.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PORTSMOUTH.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (JLH) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (PLB) STATION IS ON THE SUMMIT OF STRATHAM HILL WHICH IS INCLUDED IN THE STRATHAM HILL STATE PARK, ABOUT 1.5 MILES NE OF STRATHAM AND 3.0 MILES BY ROAD W OF GREENLAND RAILROAD STATION.  IT IS SE OF A SUBSTANTIAL FIRE-TOWER BUILT BY THE NEW HAMPSHIRE FOREST SERVICE, 54.1 FEET FROM THE SE LEG AND 57.7 FEET FROM THE SW LEG, 10.5 FEET E OF THE RANGE BETWEEN THE CENTER OF THE FIRE TOWER AND A LARGE FLAGPOLE TO THE NW.  STATION MONUMENT PROTRUDES ABOUT 5 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  SURFACE, UNDERGROUND, AND REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK IS NE OF THE STATION, E OF THE FIRE TOWER, AND ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MONUMENT.  THE DIRECTION STAND IS A LARGE CIRCULAR CAST-IRON SLAB MOUNTED ON SIX LEGS NW OF THE FIRE TOWER, BETWEEN IT AND THE FLAGPOLE, AND HAS ON IT THE DIRECTION AND DISTANCES TO NUMEROUS WELL KNOWN POINTS OVER THE COUNTRY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) STATION RECOVERED AND FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ACCURATE AND ADEQUATE.  DIFFERENCES WERE FOUND IN THE DIRECTION TO THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND TO STRATHAM 1851--05 FT 55 IN AND 01 FT 09 IN RESPECTIVELY.  A DISTANCE AND DIRECTION WAS TAKEN TO A 1/2-INCH BOLT THAT IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BOULDER.  IT IS 30 FEET N OF THE NW CORNER OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER.  BOLT IS ABOUT 5 INCHES LONG AND IS BENT OVER.  BOULDER PROJECTS ABOUT 3 INCHES.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 8 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (LAL) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, STRATHAM 1851 AND THE DIRECTION STAND WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE BENT BOLT REFERENCE POINT WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  THE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION BETWEEN THE REFERENCE POINTS CHECKED ADEQUATELY.  A NEW AND COMPLETE DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN STRATHAM HILL PARK, ABOUT 4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PORTSMOUTH, 3 MILES SOUTH OF THE ROCKINGHAM-STRAFFORD COUNTY LINE, ON THE SUMMIT OF STRATHAM HILL JUST EAST OF A LOOKOUT TOWER AND ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE TOWN OF STRATHAM.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 95 AND STATE HIGHWAY 101, THAT IS SOUTHWEST OF PORTSMOUTH.  GO WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 101 FOR 1.8 MILES TO STATE HIGHWAY 151 ON THE LEFT, CONTINUE WESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 101 FOR 3.3 MILES TO THE ENTRANCE TO STRATHAM HILL PARK ON THELEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON PARK ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A LOCKED GATE, PASS THRU GATE AND CONTINUE SOUTHERLY FOR 0.1 MILE TO A CROSSROAD, TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO NORTHEAST UP STEEP GRADE, ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND STATION, AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED STRATHAM 2 1941, IS SET IN THE TOP OF A 12X12 INCH CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 64.4 FEET EAST OF THE CENTER OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 17 FEET NORTHWEST OF A 20 INCH PINE TREE, 17 FEET NORTHEAST OF A 16 INCH PINE TREE AND 13 FEET SOUTH OF A 16 INCH PINE TREE.  STRATHAM 1851, IS MARKED BY A 1/2 INCH DRILL HOLE IN AN OUTCROPING BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 59.7 FEET NORTHEAST OF A 20 INCH PINE TREE, 17 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND 8.8 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED STRATHAM 2 NO 1 1941, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12X12 INCH CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 27 FEET NORTH OF A 16 INCH PINE TREE AND 21 FEET NORTHWEST OF A 14 INCH PINE TREE.  DIRECTION STAND, IS A METAL CIRCULAR DIAL, 3 FEET IN DIAMETER WHICH HAS THE NAMES OF NUMEROUS PROMINENT OBJECTS ARRANGED RADIALLY IN RAISED LETTERS, SUPPORTED BY 6 IRON POSTS WHICH ARE SET IN CONCRETE AND PROJECTS 3.1 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 42.6 FEET WEST NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 42.9 FEET WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER AND 30.5 FEET NORTHEAST OF A 20 INCH PINE TREE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PORTSMOUTH.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 74 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RCA) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK 1, STRATHAM 1851 AND THE DIRECTION STAND WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY L.A. LUPINE IN 1973 AND WERE IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION TO REACH THE STATION WAS FOUND TO BE ADEQUATE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PORTSMOUTH.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 74 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2005 (JLH) STATION AND RM 1 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ATOP THE TREE TOP LODGE HOTEL ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF FRANCONIA IN THE SUGAR HILL RESORT AREA. IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET IN HEIGHT AND THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE BALL ATOP THE FLAGPOLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 10-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF COLEBROOK, ABOUT 10-1/2 MILES NORTH NORTHEAST OF GROVETON AND ABOUT 8 MILES EAST OF NORTH STRATFORD ON THE SUMMIT OF SUGARLOAF MOUNTAIN.  STATION IS 7 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF LOOKOUT CABIN.  THE MARK IS A STANDARD U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DISK WITH NO STAMPING AND IS CEMENTED FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE TO STATION FROM TRIANGULATION STATION SUGARLOAF AND THE DISTANCE IS 6.094 METERS OR 19.99 FEET WEST.  TO REACH STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 3 AND STATE HIGHWAY 110 IN THE SOUTH EDGE OF GROVETON GO NORTHEAST ON STATE HIGHWAY 110 FOR 2.6 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO 1.2 MILES TO A BRIDGE.  CONTINUE FOR 0.95 MILE TO FORKS.  TAKE LEFT FORK FOR 0.4 MILE TO FORKS.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW MAIN WOODS ROAD FOR 7.35 MILES TO FORKS.  TAKE LEFT FORK FOR 1.0 MILE TO BRIDGE.  CONTINUE FOR 0.1 MILE TO WOODS ROAD LEFT AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTHWEST ON WOODS ROAD ALONG THE LEFT SIDE OF SMALL BROOK FOR ABOUT 15 MINUTES TO FORKS AND SIGN LOOKOUT STATION.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW MAIN WOODS ROAD FOR 30 MINUTES TO END OF ROAD.  CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON GOOD TRAIL FOR 30 MINUTES TO SMALL CLEARING AND CABIN.  CONTINUE ON TRAIL FOR 20 MINUTES TO SUMMIT AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  FROM END OF TRUCK TRAVEL TO SUMMIT IS ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES AND MAY BE PARTLY DRIVEN WITH A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE IN DRY WEATHER.                            STATION RECOVERY (2011)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2011 (DKA) THE DISK HAS BEEN PRIED UP A BIT BUT IS IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) STATION IS APPROXIMATELY 4.5 MILES WEST-NORTHWEST OF UPPER KIMBALL LAKE, 4.0 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF NORTH CONWAY AND ON THE TOP OF MT. KEARSARGE NORTH.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN NORTH CONWAY, GO NORTH ON U.S. HIGHWAY 302 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16 FOR 1.95 MILES TO A RAILROAD CROSSING, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON THE RIGHT (HURRICANE MT. ROAD), TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON HURRICANE MT.  ROAD FOR 1.05 MILES TO A CROSSROAD, (CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOR APPROXIMATELY 100 FEET TO THE AZIMUTH MARK WHICH IS SET IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.) CONTINUE EAST ON HURRICANE MT. ROAD FOR 0.4 MILE TO A SMALL PARKING AREA ON THE LEFT AT SIGNS PEQUAWKET TRAIL MT. KEARSARGE NORTH AND THIS IS THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE FOLLOW THE TRAIL NORTHERLY FOR APPROXIMATELY 3 MILES TO THE LOOKOUT TOWER AND THE STATION.  (ABOUT LESS THAN HALFWAY UP THE TRAIL THERE IS A SPRING ABOUT 30 YARDS SOUTH OF THE TRAIL.) ABOUT A 3 HOUR PACK.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOP 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  IT IS 16 FEET SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 15 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A STONE FOUNDATION AND 4.3 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A GUY WIRE PEG WHICH IS EMBEDDED IN ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOP NO 1 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  IT IS 64 FEET WEST-SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FOREST SERVICE STATION DISK STAMPED 469 1934, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  IT IS 31.5 FEET NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  AZIMUTH MARK, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TOP 1958, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT.  IT IS 41 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF SURFACED ROAD, 75 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF HOUSE AND 25 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A WHITE FLAG POLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1976)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1976 (JLO) THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND WITH THE TOP OF THE DISK REMOVED AND STEM IN PLACE IN THE DRILL HOLE. REFERENCE MARK 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED. REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION AND THE DIRECTION CHECKED, A DIFFERENCE OF 0.020 METERS WAS NOTED IN THE DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK 2. THE AZIMUTH MARK WAS FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION BUT WAS NOT OBSERVED AT THIS TIME DUE TO THE WEATHER AND VALLEY FOG.   THE STATION IS LOCATED ATOP MT. KEARSARGE NORTH, ABOUT 4 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF NORTH CONWAY 5 MILES WEST OF THE MAINE/NEW HAMPSHIRE BORDER AND ON THE PROPERTY OF WHITE MOUNTAIN NATIONAL FOREST.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN NORTH CONWAY, NEW HAMPSHIRE, GO EAST FOR 0.05 MILE TO U.S. HIGHWAY 302. TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 2.0 MILES TO A RAILROAD CROSSING, CONTINUE NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY ON HURRICANE MOUNTAIN ROAD FOR 1.1 MILES TO THE AZIMUTH MARK ON THE LEFT, JUST AFTER PASSING A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE EASTERLY FOR 0.4 MILE TO A SMALL PARKING AREA FOR BACK PACKERS AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK NORTHERLY ON MT. KEARSARGE NORTH FOOT PATH FOR APPROXIMATELY 3 MILES OR ABOUT 3 HOURS TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN, A LOOKOUT TOWER AND THE STATION. ABOUT HALFWAY UP THE TRAIL. THERE IS A SPRING ABOUT 100 FEET SOUTH OF THE TRAIL.   STATION MARK IS THE ETCHED CENTER OF A BRONZE STEM CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK. IT IS 16.4 FEET SOUTH- SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF A LOOKOUT TOWER AND 4.3 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A GUY WIRE PEG IMBEDDED IN THE ROCK.   REFERENCE MARK 1, STAMPED ---TOP NO 1 1958---, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK. IT IS 64.0 FEET WEST- SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST LEG OF THE LOOKOUT TOWER.   REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED ---469 1934---  IS A U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FOREST SERVICE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK. IT IS 31.0 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTHWEST LEG OF THE LOOK- OUT TOWER.   AZIMUTH MARK, STAMPED ---TOP 1958---, IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE THE GROUND. IT IS 40.0 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTERLINE OF HURRICANE ROAD AND 75 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A HOUSE.   HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.   DESCRIBED BY G.E. NELSON                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1988 (JBD) MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY PROFESSIONAL LAND SURVEYOR 2013 (JRO) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. IT IS ABOUT 160 FT (48.8 M) EAST OF THE INTERSECTION, 40 FT (12.2 M) NORTH OF HURRICANE MOUNTAIN ROAD, 75 FT (22.9 M) SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A RED FRAME HOUSE, 2 FT (0.6 M) NORTH OF A SMALL TREE AND UNDER THE TREE BRANCHES, ABOUT 7 FT (2.1 M) HIGHER THAN THE ROAD.  THE BOULDER IN WHICH MARK IS SET PROJECTS ABOUT 0.4 FT (12 CM) ABOVE GROUND AND THE VISIBLE PART OF IT IS NOT WHAT ONE WOULD CALL LARGE.

markers.description: BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF WOLFEBORO, ON LAND OWNED BY THOS. L. COTTON, OF BOSTON, MASS.  TO REACH GO TO HOUSE OF DANIEL JENNESS AND TO SUMMIT N ABOUT 20 RODS THROUGH PASTURE AND MOWING.  SIGNAL IS ON HIGHEST POINT.  TOP IS SOIL AND LEDGE.  D. JENNESS LIVES 1/2 MILE E OF N WOLFEBORO, OR 2-1/2 MILES W OF OSSIPEE CORNER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1933)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1933 (HSS) THE LOCATION OF THE STATION IS SHOWN ON THE U.S.G.S. WOLFEBORO SHEET AND I FOUND IT CONVENIENT TO APPROACH THE STATION FROM A ROAD, SHOWN ON THE MAP, ON THE SE SIDE OF THE HILL.  THE ROAD IS PASSABLE FOR CARS AND THE STATION IS REACHED BY WALKING UP AN EASY SLOPE THROUGH A FIELD WHICH IS PARTLY GROWN UP WITH SMALL TREES AND BUSHES.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY AN IRON ROD, SET IN AN EXPOSED LEDGE AND SURROUNDED BY A TRIANGLE CUT IN THE ROCK, THE ROD PROJECTING ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE THE LEDGE.  ABOUT 5.45 FEET WSW OF THE STATION IS A BENT IRON ROD WHICH DOUBTLESS WAS USED AS A GUY ANCHOR.  I FOUND OVER THE STATION AN OLD WOODEN QUADRUPOD, WHICH PROBABLY WAS USED BY THE U.S.G.S. DURING THE SURVEY OF THE WOLFEBORO QUADRANGLE.  THE VIEW FROM THE STATION IS OBSTRUCTED BY TREES IN SOME DIRECTIONS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1934)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1934 (RE) TO LOCATE THIS STATION GO TO NORTH WOLFEBORO FROM THERE TAKE THE ROAD THAT GOES E FROM THE VILLAGE.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD TO THE END WHERE THERE IS A PATH THAT LEADS OFF N TO THE SUMMIT.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A BOLT AND A TRIPOD BUILT OF POLES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE ESTABLISHED BY THIS PARTY.  FOLLOWING IS A NEW AND COMPLETE DESCRIPTION.  STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 7.0 MILES NORTHEAST OF WOLFEBORO, 1.5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF OSSIPEE, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A WOODED HILL AND ON LAND OWNED BY MRS. ROSEMOND FERRALD OF EAST WOLFEBORO.  STATION MARK IS AN IRON PIN SET IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK.  THE IRON PIN PROJECTS 4 INCHES AND IS SURROUNDED BY A TRIANGLE CUT IN THE ROCK.  IT IS 8.5 FEET NORTHWEST OF A TRIANGULAR BLAZED PINE TREE WITH A WHITE WITNESS POST NAILED TO IT, 5.4 FEET NORTHEAST OF A BENT IRON PINE WHICH DOUBTLESS WAS USED AS A GUY ANCHOR AND 5.1 FEET NORTHWEST OF A BENT IRON PIN WHICH DOUBTLESS WAS USED AS A GUY ANCHOR.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CARROLL COUNTY COURTHOUSE IN OSSIPEE, GO NORTHWEST FOR 0.2 MILE TO STATE HIGHWAY 28, TURN LEFT ON STATE HIGHWAY 28 AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY FOR 1.4 MILES TO THE WOLFEBORO TOWN LINE, CONTINUE ON STATE HIGHWAY 28 FOR 1.05 MILES TO A CROSSROAD, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 0.95 MILE TO A CROSSROAD AT THE VILLAGE OF NORTH WOLFEBORO, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHEAST FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE END OF THE MAIN TRAVELED ROAD AT A WHITE HOUSE ON THE RIGHT, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD ON DIM ROAD FOR APPROXIMATELY 50 YARDS AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL FOR A TWO WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK.  FROM HERE PACK NORTHWEST FOR APPROXIMATELY 0.4 MILE TO THE HIGHEST POINT OF HILL AND THE STATION.  (A FOUR WHEEL DRIVE TRUCK CAN BE DRIVEN TO STATION BUT WILL HAVE TO BE VERY CAREFUL BECAUSE OF THE JUNIPER BUSHES WHICH COVERS LARGE BOULDERS.)  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TRASK HILL NO 1 1881, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK. IT IS APPROXIMATELY 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED TRASK HILL NO 2 1881, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 8 INCHES ON THE SOUTH SIDE.  IT IS APPROXIMATELY 3 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  THERE WAS NO SUITABLE PLACE TO SET AN AZIMUTH MARK.  OBSERVATIONS TAKEN FROM A 50 FOOT TOWER.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (JCC) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2.5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF FRANCONIA IN THE SUGAR HILL RESORT AREA AND ON THE GROUNDS OF THE TREE TOP LODGE.  STATION IS REACHED AS FOLLOWS--FROM THE U.S. POST OFFICE, IN FRANCONIA, GO NORTHWEST ON STATE ROUTE 18 FOR 0.6 MILE TO A BRIDGE.  CROSS BRIDGE AND FOLLOW STATE ROUTE 117 FOR 2.2 MILES TO SIGN SUNSET HOUSE AND TREE TOP LODGE.  TURN LEFT, AS PER SIGN, AND GO 0.4 MILE TO SUNSET HOUSE ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE 0.1 MILE TO FORKS.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO 0.4 MILE TO TREE TOP LODGE AND STATION ON THE LEFT IN GOLF COURSE.  STATION, STAMPED TREE TOP 1958, IS A STANDARD USC AND GS BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK. IT IS 15.5 FEET EAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE 9TH GREEN, 107.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF BUILDING AND 128.0 FEET SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF A SPRUCE TREE THAT IS 28 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  R.M. 1, STAMPED TREE TOP NO 1 1958, IS A STANDARD USC AND GS BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 8 INCHES.  IT IS 91.0 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A LARGE ROCK OUTCROP THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET, 53.0 FEET EAST OF A WATER PIPE AND ABOUT 6 FEET ABOVE STATION ELEVATION.  R.M. 2, STAMPED TREE TOP NO 2 1958, IS A STANDARD USC AND GS BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 12 INCHES.  IT IS 160.0 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A 30-INCH IN DIAMETER ELM TREE, 117.0 FEET WEST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF BUILDING AND ABOUT 2 FEET ABOVE STATION ELEVATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (RAT) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1959 DESCRIPTION.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS AND THE STATION MARK WERE FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION. THE TREE TOP LODGE FLAGPOLE IS ALSO IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1969 (WMJ) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  A DIFFERENCE WAS NOTED IN THE DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2.  THIS DISTANCE WAS CHECKED IN THE FIELD AND FOUND TO BE CORRECT.  THE DESCRIPTION TO REACH THE STATION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1986)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1986 (REP) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED ON THIS DATE. NO OTHER MARKS WERE SEARCHED FOR AT THIS TIME.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8.0 KM (5.0 MI) SOUTHWEST OF BETHLEHEM, 3.2 KM (2.0 MI) NORTHEAST OF SUGAR HILL, 2.4 KM (1.5 MI) WEST-NORTHWEST OF FRANCONIA AND IN THE FRONT YARD OF A LARGE FRAME HOUSE. OWNERSHIP--JAMES MCCUSKER, 14 BROOKMORE ROAD, AVON CT 06001, PHONE 203-673-2785.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 18, 116 AND 117 ABOUT 1.3 KM (0.8 MI) NORTHWEST OF FRANCONIA.  GO WESTERLY ON HIGHWAY 117 FOR 3.5 KM (2.15 MI) TO A PAVED ROAD ON THE LEFT AT THE TOP OF A GRADE, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON SUNSET HILL ROAD FOR 1.0 KM (0.6 MI) TO A NARROW CROSSROAD (LAFAYETTE RD), CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO THE SECOND GRAVEL DRIVE ON THE LEFT, LEADING TO A 2-STORY FRAME HOUSE AND JUST PAST A SHARP CURVE RIGHT.  TURN LEFT AND GO UPHILL ON THE DRIVEWAY FOR 42 METERS (138 FT) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD CGS DISK STAMPED---TREE TOP 1958---, SET INTO A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK OUTCROP THAT IS SURROUNDED BY A CHISLED TRIANGLE AND FLUSH WITH THE GROUND. 25.0 METERS (82.0 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE DRIVEWAY AND 17.1 METERS (56.0 FT) SOUTH FROM A LONE CLUMP OF BRUSH. BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1886 ON THE SUMMIT OF THE MORE SOUTHEASTERLY OF THE TWO PROMINENT ELEVATIONS KNOWN AS THE UNKONOONUC MOUNTAINS, ABOUT 7 MILES W OF MANCHESTER, 4-1/2 MILES NW OF BEDFORD, AND 2-1/2 MILES W OF GOFFSTOWN.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK.  THE COPPER BOLT ORIGINALLY PLACED THERE HAS BEEN REMOVED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1932)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1932 (HSS) ON THE SUMMIT IS AN 80-FOOT STEEL FIRE TOWER, BUILT ABOUT 1923, AND NEARLY AT THE CENTER OF IT IS A U.S.G.S. TABLET, IN A CONCRETE POST, WHICH WAS PLACED BY C.B. KENDALL, IN 1931.  ACCORDING TO THE FIRE WATCHMAN MR. KENDALL FAILED TO FIND THE STATION OF 1848, ALTHOUGH THEY DID CONSIDERABLE DIGGING.  U.S.G.S. BULLETIN 216 STATES THAT THE STATION WAS USED BY G.T. HAWKINS IN 1903.  BUT IN 1925 R.M. WILSON, OF THE U.S.G.S. FAILED TO FIND THE STATION WHEN HE DETERMINED THE POSITION OF THE FIRE TOWER, CALLING IT UNCANOONUC TOWER.  THE TYPEWRITTEN DESCRIPTION OF THE LATTER STATION IS IN PART AS FOLLOWS--THE STATION WAS ORIGINALLY ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S.C. AND G.S. AND MARKED BY A HOLE DRILLED IN SOLID ROCK.  THIS MARK COULD NOT BE FOUND IN 1925.  A HIGH STEEL FIRE LOOKOUT TOWER HAS BEEN ERECTED ON THE SUMMIT AND THE CENTER OF THIS TOWER MARKS THE LOCATION OF 1925.  IT IS NOT POSSIBLE TO SEE OUT FROM THE GROUND.  THE OLD COAST SURVEY MARK IS PROBABLY ABOUT 2 FEET S AND 5 FEET W OF CENTER OF TOWER.  I VISITED UNCANOONUC MOUNTAIN (NOW USUALLY THUS SPELLED) TWICE DURING THE FALL OF 1932, BUT FAILED TO FIND THE OLD STATION. IT MAY STILL EXIST, HOWEVER, UNDER THE SURFACE, UNLESS IT WAS DESTROYED OR COVERED UP DURING THE BUILDING OF THE FOUNDATIONS OF THE TOWER.  THE VIEW FROM THE GROUND IS MOSTLY OBSTRUCTED BY TREES, BUT IS CLEAR IN ALL DIRECTIONS FROM THE OBSERVATION ROOM OF THE TOWER.  THE STATION MAY BE BEST REACHED FROM MANCHESTER, NEW HAMPSHIRE VIA HIGHWAY NO. 114.  AT A PLACE CALLED SHIRLEY STATION, ABOUT A MILE E OF THE VILLAGE OF GOFFSTOWN, A ROAD MARKED BY SIGNS LEADS S, ABOUT 2.3 MILES, TO THE BASE OF THE MOUNTAIN.  FROM THERE AN ELECTRIC CABLE RAILWAY RUNS TO WITHIN A SHORT DISTANCE OF THE STATION.  THE RAILWAY IS OPERATED DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS (MAY 30 TO ABOUT NOVEMBER 1 IN 1932) AND THE TRIP TAKES BETWEEN 5 AND 10 MINUTES.  THE RAILWAY AND A SHORT PIECE OF ROAD LEADING TO IT ARE NOT SHOWN ON THE U.S.G.S. MILFORD SHEET (EDITION OF 1906) WHICH COVERS THE REGION.  THERE IS A TRAIL NEAR THE RAILWAY.  THE ROAD SHOWN ON THE MILFORD SHEET, ON THE WESTERLY SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN, WAS ONCE A TOLL ROAD, BUT IS SAID TO BE NO LONGER PASSABLE FOR VEHICLES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1933)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1933 (HSS) ON OCTOBER 4, 1933, I FOUND A DRILL HOLE WHICH I THINK IS THE ONE WHICH MARKS THIS STATION, ALTHOUGH IT SEEMS IMPOSSIBLE TO MAKE A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION, AS I HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO FIND ANY MENTION OF ANY REFERENCE MARKS, EITHER IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION OR ELSEWHERE.  IN THE DESCRIPTION OF THE U.S.G.S. STATION UNCANOONUC TOWER, OF 1925, IT IS STATED THAT THE OLD COAST SURVEY MARK IS PROBABLY ABOUT 2 FEET S AND 5 FEET W OF CENTER OF TOWER.  I BEGAN TO DIG AT ABOUT THAT POINT AND AFTER UNCOVERING A NUMBER OF SQUARE FEET OF THE LEDGE AND PROBING CAREFULLY WHERE IT WAS DIFFICULT TO REMOVE ALL THE MOIST SOIL FROM THE VERY ROUGH SURFACE OF THE LEDGE, I FOUND THAT ABOVE-MENTIONED DRILL HOLE, ABOUT 2 FEET OR SO FROM THE POSITION GIVEN IN THE U.S.G.S. DESCRIPTION.  THE AGREEMENT MAY BE EVEN CLOSER, HOWEVER, AS I WORKED FROM THE CENTER OF THE SQUARE FORMED BY THE LEGS OF THE TOWER AND I DID NOT ATTEMPT TO PLUMB DOWN FROM THE TOP OF THE TOWER.  THE DRILL HOLE IS ONLY 1/2 TO 3/4 INCH DEEP, BUT IS DEFINITELY RECOGNIZABLE AS A DRILL HOLE, AND IT SEEMS PROBABLE THAT A PIECE OF THE LEDGE HAS BEEN BROKEN OFF, LEAVING ONLY THE LOWER PART OF THE HOLE.  THE LEDGE IS COVERED WITH ABOUT 9 OR 10 INCHES OF SOIL AT THIS POINT.  THE DRILL HOLE IS 4.72 FEET (HORIZONTALLY) ABOUT 4-3/4 DEG N OF W FROM THE U.S.G.S. TABLET (UNSTAMPED) WHICH WAS SET IN 1931. THIS TABLET IS ABOUT 3 INCHES S OF THE INTERSECTION OF THE DIAGONALS OF THE SQUARE FORMED BY THE TOWER LEGS.  THE INFORMATION IN MY RECOVERY NOTE OF 1932 STILL APPLIES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK (STATION MARK) WAS NOT RECOVERED, THEREFORE A NEW UNKNOONUC 2 WAS ESTABLISHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (GAM) THE STATION MARK AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE TOWN HALL IN GOFFSTOWN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE ROUTE NO. 114 FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT, SOUTHERLY, AND GO 0.9 MILES ON MOUNTAIN ROAD TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO 2.3 MILES TO A FORK.  TURN LEFT AND GO 0.4 MILE TO A FORK AND SIGN SUMMIT MOUNTAIN.  TURN LEFT AND GO 1.0 MILES TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN AND A FORK.  TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.2 MILE TO THE STATION MARK UNDER THE LOOKOUT TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2008 (RG) THE STATION WAS NOT FOUND AFTER ABOUT 1 HOUR SEARCH BY 2 MEN.   STATION MY3799 UNKONOONUC 2  AND UNKONOONUC 2 RM1 WERE FIRST RECOVERED.  GEODETIC DISTANCES FROM THESE 2 DISKS WERE COMPUTED AND THE ESTIMATED DISTANCE FROM THE 1931 USGS DISK (WHICH IS NOW UNDER A SMALL BUILDING) WAS MADE AND A LOCATION WAS DETERMINED.  A HOLE WAS DUG TO BEDROCK WHICH SHOULD HAVE INCLUDED THE STATION WITH AN UNCERTAINTY OF ABOUT +/- 6 INCHES.   THE BEDROCK WAS IRREGULAR BUT NO SIGN OF A DRILL HOLE WAS FOUND. DUE TO THE UNCERTAINTIES IN THE GEODETIC LOCATIONS, THE STATION MAY STILL EXIST UNDERGROUND BEYOND THE RANGE OF OUR SEARCH.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 15 MILES SOUTH OF CONCORD, 7 MILES WEST OF MANCHESTER AND ON TOP OF UNCANOONUC MOUNTAIN AND NEAR THE UNCANOONUC MTN. LOOKOUT TOWER.  IT IS 18.9 FEET NORTH OF THE WEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 9.5 FEET NORTHWEST OF THE NORTH LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 50 FEET EAST NORTHEAST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF RADIO TRANSMITTING BUILDING AND 20.3 FEET NORTH OF THE CONCRETE BASE OF LADDER LEADING UP THE CENTER OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS ABOUT 8 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED UNCANOONUC 2 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 23.5 FEET WEST NORTHWEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A RADIO TRANSMITTING BUILDING, 20 FEET EAST OF A 18 INCH TRIANGULAR BLAZED OAK TREE, 24.5 FEET WEST SOUTHWEST OF THE WEST LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER AND 2.7 FEET EAST OF A GUY WIRE EYE BOLT SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND IS STAMPED UNCANOONUC 2 NO 1 1959.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A USGS MARK THAT IS 9.75 FEET EAST OF THE WEST BASE OF LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 10.12 FEET WEST OF THE NORTH BASE OF LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER, 10.05 FEET WEST OF THE EAST BASE OF LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER AND 9.70 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH BASE OF LEG OF LOOKOUT TOWER.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY BENCH MARK DISK SET IN A 6 X 6 INCH CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 2 INCHES WITH NO STAMPING ON DISK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 114 AND 13 IN GOFFSTOWN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 114 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT SIGN V.F.W. POST 7015.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.9 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 2.3 MILES TO FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD ON LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 1.0 MILE TO SUMMIT OF HILL AND A TRACK ROAD ON RIGHT.  (THIS IS A 1 WAY ROAD.) TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW TRACK ROAD AROUND SUMMIT FOR ABOUT 0.1 MILE TO A TRACK ROAD ON LEFT AND A COUNTY CLUB HOUSE ON RIGHT.  TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW TRACK ROAD FOR ABOUT 0.05 MILE TO STATION AND LOOKOUT TOWER ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF HILL.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 14 METERS. STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (DRA) THE STATION AND BOTH RMS WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AND AS DESCRIBED. markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 15 MILES SOUTH OF CONCORD, 7 MILES WEST OF MANCHESTER AND ON THE WESTERLY SLOPE OF UNCANOONUC MOUNTAIN.  IT IS 227 FEET HIGH, PAINTED RED AND WHITE, STEEL STRUCTURE AND HAS A LIGHT ON TOP OF MAST.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE LIGHT ON TOP.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAY 114 AND 13 IN GOFFSTOWN, GO EASTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 114 FOR 0.05 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT SIGN V.F.W. POST 7015.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.9 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD ON LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 2.3 MILES TO FORK.  TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO SOUTHEASTERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTHERLY ON SURFACED ROAD FOR 1.0 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND STATION ON LEFT JUST BEFORE REACHING SUMMIT OF HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1968 (DRA) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN-- 15 MILES SOUTH OF CONCORD.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 STATION IS ON BIRCH POINT, THE FIRST POINT BELOW THE RAILROAD BRIDGE ON THE P. AND D. R.R., OVER THE BRANCH OF THE RIVER THAT GOES TO BERWICK.  ON A LARGE BOULDER WELL EMBEDDED IN GRAVEL JUST BELOW HIGH TIDE ON THE FARTHEST POINT DOWN THE PISCATAQUA RIVER (W BANK) BELOW THE ENTRANCE OF GREAT BAY.  THERE IS A DEEP BAY JUST N OF THE POINT EXTENDING BACK ALMOST TO THE RAILROAD. THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN THE BOULDER. THERE IS A HIGHER AND APPARENTLY LARGER BOULDER JUST BACK OF THE ONE UPON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED.  IT IS ALMOST MIDWAY BETWEEN THE STATION AND THE BANK, THE LATTER BEING 15 FEET FROM THE STATION.  THERE IS A LARGE CLUMP OF BOULDERS AT THE EXTREME SHARPEST POINT OF THE BLUFF DISTANT 30 FEET FROM THE STATION AND TOWARD THE N.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  ONE HOUR WAS SPENT IN TRYING TO LOCATE THIS STATION.  IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT THIS STATION BE CLASSIFIED AS LOST.

markers.description: BY GEOCACHING 2008 (RG) THE STATION IS MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT WITH LINE ACROSS THE TOP AT THE BOTTOM OF A CONE-SHAPED HOLLOW IN THE TOP OF A DRESSED GRANITE MONUMENT WITH THE TOP CORNERS CUT OFF MAKING AN OCTAGONAL TOP MARKED 'BORDEN 1834'.   THE STATION MARKS THE BOUNDARY LINE BETWEEN THE STATES OF MASSACHUSETTS AND NEW HAMPSHIRE AND IS LOCATED ABOUT 100 FEET EAST OF MONUMENT NO. 51 OF THAT BOUNDARY AND IS EMBEDDED IN A ROCK LEDGE ABOUT 4 FEET NORTH OF A STONE WALL.   THE MONUMENT WAS SET BY SIMEON BORDEN AS PART OF HIS TRIGONOMETRICAL SURVEY OF MASSACHUSETTS (1830-1838). ITS POSITION IS SHOWN ON BORDEN'S MAP ENTITLED 'PLAN OF THE PRINCIPAL TRIANGLES IN THE TRIGONOMETRICAL SURVEY OF MASSACHUSETTS' (1841).   IT'S LOCATION IS GIVEN IN THE BULLETIN OF THE USGS NO. 13 'BOUNDARIES OF THE UNITED STATES AND THE SEVERAL STATES AND TERRITORIES WITH A HISTORICAL SKETCH OF THE TERRITORIAL CHANGES' (1885) AND IN CGS SPECIAL PUBLICATION NO. 76 'TRIANGULATION IN MASSACHUSETTS' (1922).   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF ROUTES 101 AND 119 IN ASBURNHAM MASSACHUSETTS, GO NORTHWEST ON ROUTE 119 ABOUT 1.3 MILES TO A PARKING LOT SIGNED 'MIDSTATE TRAIL' ON THE RIGHT. PROCEED ON FOOT ON AN OLD WOODS ROAD BEARING NORTH AND NORTHEAST ABOUT .9 MILES TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE. DO NOT TAKE ANY OF SEVERAL TRAILS BEARING RIGHT OR LEFT FROM THIS ROAD TILL REACHING THE TOP. AT THE TOP BEAR LEFT (NORTH) AND PROCEED ON A YELLOW BLAZED TRAIL SIGNED 'WAPACK TRAIL' FOR ABOUT .4 MILES TO THE STATE LINE, MARKED BY A STONE WALL RUNNING EAST-WEST. TURN LEFT (WEST) AND PROCEED ALONG A BLUE BLAZED TRAIL SIGNED 'STATE LINE TRAIL'  ADJACENT TO THE STONE WALL FOR ABOUT 100 FEET TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. STATE LINE MONUMENT NO. 51 IS ABOUT ANOTHER 100 FEET FURTHER ALONG THIS TRAIL.   THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  RECOVERY REPORT SUBMITTED BY R. GARLAND OF GEOCACHING.                              STATION RECOVERY (2020)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2020 (CDH) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.setting: SET IN PREFABRICATED CONCRETE POST IMBEDDED IN GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: PTIVE TEXT AVAILABLE.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (PLB) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3.5 MILES SW OF DURHAM, 4.5 MILES NW OF NEWMARKET, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A PARTLY-WOODED HILL LOCALLY KNOWN AS WEDNESDAY HILL, AND ON LAND OWNED BY A MRS. SMITH WHO LIVES ABOUT 0.5 MILE E OF THE STATION.  IT IS IN THE N EDGE OF A SMALL CLEARING ON THE S END OF THE HILL SURROUNDED BY A GROVE OF SMALL PINE TREES.  STATION MARK IS A DISK SET IN A BOULDER ABOUT 4 BY 3 FEET IN DIAMETER THAT PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  IT IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL 1943 AND IS SET FLUSH WITH THE ROCK SURFACE.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  REFERENCE AND AZIMUTH MARKS ARE BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS SSE OF THE STATION SET IN THE EDGE OF THE PINE GROVE.  THE DISK IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL NO 1 1943 AND PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SW OF THE STATION, 10 FEET W OF THE DIM WOODS ROAD, AND IN THE W EDGE OF THE WOODS.  THE DISK IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL NO 2 1943 AND PROJECTS 6 INCHES.  AZIMUTH MARK IS ABOUT 0.3 MILE SSE OF THE STATION, 20 FEET S OF THE GRAVEL ROAD, 10 FEET E OF A FARM ROAD, AND 2 FEET N OF A STONE FENCELINE.  THE DISK IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL 1943 AND PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  TO REACH AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION, GO BACK TO THE MAIN TRAVELED GRAVEL ROAD, TURN LEFT AND GO E FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT THROUGH A BOARD GATE, AND MARK ON THE RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN DURHAM, GO W ON MACADAM ROAD BY THE COLLEGE FOR 1.2 MILES TO CROSSROADS, TURN LEFT AND GO SW FOR 1.35 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO SE FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO S FOR 0.55 MILE TO A REVERSED Y AT A HOUSE ON THE LEFT. BEAR RIGHT AND GO NW FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE TOP OF A SMALL GRADE, A TRIANGULAR BLAZED 4-INCH HICKORY TREE ON THE LEFT, AND A DIM FARM ROAD RIGHT THROUGH A GAP IN STONE FENCELINE.  TURN RIGHT THROUGH GAP IN STONE FENCELINE AND GO N ON DIM ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE NW END OF THE HILL.  HERE TURN SHARP RIGHT AND FOLLOW DIM TRUCK TRACKS AROUND THE W EDGE OF THE HILL TO THE S END AND HIGHEST POINT AND STATION.  OBSERVATIONS MADE FROM A 64-FOOT TOWER.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 23 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1963)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1963 (GAM) THE STATION MARK, AZIMUTH MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION MARK IS A DISK SET IN A BOULDER ABOUT 4 BY 3 FEET IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH THE GROUND IN BRUSH.  IT IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL 1943 AND IS SET FLUSH WITH THE ROCK SURFACE.  NO UNDERGROUND MARK WAS SET.  THE STATION IS 3 FEET SOUTH OF WITNESS SIGN NAILED TO A 3 INCH BIRCH TREE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS SSE OF THE STATION AND 1 FOOT NORTH OF A WITNESS SIGN NAILED TO A 6 INCH PINE TREE.  THE DISK IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL NO 1 1943 AND PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  AZIMUTH MARK IS ABOUT 0.3 MILE SSE OF THE STATION, 20 FEET SOUTH OF CENTERLINE OF THE GRAVEL ROAD, 10 FEET E OF CENTERLINE OF A FARM ROAD, AND 2 FEET N OF A STONE FENCELINE.  THE DISK IS STAMPED WEDNESDAY HILL 1943 AND PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN DURHAM, GO W ON MACADAM ROAD BY THE COLLEGE FOR 1.2 MILES TO CROSSROADS, TURN LEFT AND GO SW FOR 1.35 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO SE FOR 0.6 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT, TURN RIGHT AND GO S FOR 0.55 MILE TO A REVERSED Y AT A HOUSE ON THE LEFT. BEAR RIGHT AND GO NW ON WEDNESDAY HILL ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO THE TOP OF A SMALL GRADE, AND A DIM FARM ROAD RIGHT THROUGH A GAP IN STONE FENCELINE.  TURN RIGHT THROUGH GAP IN FENCELINE AND GO N ON DIM ROAD TO TOP OF HILL AND DIM ROAD TURNS SHARP LEFT.  STATION IS DIRECTLY AHEAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1981)  RECOVERY NOTE BY LOCAL ENGINEER (INDIVIDUAL OR FIRM) 1981 (JIM) WEDNESDAY HILL 1943.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--3.5 MILES SW OF DURHAM.

markers.description: BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1908 (OBF) STATION IS ABOUT 1 MILE FROM GREAT BAY, AND ABOUT 1-1/2 METERS FROM THE STONE WALL BORDERING THE ROAD FROM DOVER TO THE POINT JUST ACROSS GREAT BAY FROM FOX POINT, ABOUT 5 METERS S OF THE SUMMIT OF THE HIGHEST HILL ON THIS ROAD.  THIS IS THE ONLY PROMINENT HILL OVERLOOKING ALL THE COUNTRY AND GREAT BAY TO THE SOUTHWARD.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL ROCK FACE (ROUGH).  TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE CUT IN THE PERPENDICULAR FACES OF VERY LARGE ROCKS IN THE WALL BORDERING THE ROAD.  THE NORTHERN ONE, A CROSS WITH LINES ABOUT 4 INCHES IN LENGTH, IS 2 METERS FROM THE STATION, IN AZIMUTH 206 DEG 45 MIN, THE OTHER, A SHALLOW HOLE IS 1.30 METERS FROM THE STATION, IN AZIMUTH 261 DEG 30 MIN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION COMPLETE, CORRECT, AND ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION AND THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED. THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE WITH THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONS--  THE STATION IS 100 FT. N-NW OF THE INTERSECTION OF A MACADAM ROAD AND A T-ROAD TO THE E, 46 FT. W OF THE CENTER OF THE MACADAM ROAD, AND 20 FT. SW OF TELEPHONE POLE 105.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF U.S. HIGHWAY 4 AND STATE HIGHWAY 16, PROCEED W ON HIGHWAY 4 FOR 1.3 MI., THEN TURN RIGHT (N) ON A MACADAM ROAD AND PROCEED 0.75 MI. TO A T-ROAD INTERSECTION AND THE STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (PLB) THIS INTERSECTION STATION IS THE FLAGPOLE ON THE CUPOLA OF THE WENTWORTH HOTEL ANNEX.  THIS HOTEL IS LOCATED ON STATE HIGHWAY 1A, JUST E OF PORTSMOUTH AND S OF NEWCASTLE.  IT IS A LARGE SUMMER RESORT HOTEL AND IS OPEN ONLY DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1943)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1943 (FLG) FLAGPOLE RECOVERED ON THE E (OF 6) CUPOLA, ON THE WENTWORTH HOTEL, A LARGE SUMMER RESORT ABOUT 1.5 MILES SE OF PORTSMOUTH. HOTEL IS A LARGE 4-STORY BUILDING WITH 6 CUPOLAS.  THIS IS THE ONLY FLAGPOLE ON THE BUILDING AT THE PRESENT TIME.                            STATION RECOVERY (1953)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1953 (PT) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE AND CORRECT WITH THE FOLLOWING EXCEPTION--THE STATION IS ABOUT 1.3 MI. E OF HIGHWAY 1A, AND IS ON THE N SIDE OF HIGHWAY 1B. BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1872 (CHS) STATION IS IN THE VICINITY OF WATERVILLE, ON LAND BELONGING TO THE STATE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE, MOSTLY LEDGE ON TOP OF IT. SIGNAL IS ON HIGHEST POINT.  STATION IS MARKED BY A TRIANGLE.  TO REACH THE STATION GO FROM SANDWICH CENTER TO HOUSE OF MR. WM. MC CRELLIS, THENCE 4 MILES N TO TOP.  MR. MC CRELLIS HAS CHARGE OF SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1873)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST SURVEY (CGS) 1873 (ETQ) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1958 (WER) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WERE ESTABLISHED BY THIS PARTY.  FOLLOWING IS A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION.  THE STATION IS APPROXIMATELY 9 MILES NORTHWEST OF TAMWORTH, 6-1/2 MILES NORTH OF NORTH SANDWICH AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCK LEDGE WHICH FORMS THE SOUTHEAST PART OF THE SUMMIT OF MT. WHITEFACE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 113 AND 113A IN TAMWORTH, GO NORTHWESTERLY ON STATE HIGHWAY 113A FOR 6.4 MILES TO A T-ROAD AT THE SETTLEMENT OF WONALANCET AND SMALL SIGN AHEAD FERNCROFT, TURN RIGHT AND GO 0.75 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT SIGN WHITE MOUNTAIN NATIONAL FOREST-BLUEBERRY LEDGE TRAIL (WODC), TURN LEFT, CROSS BRIDGE AND KEEP RIGHT FOR 0.05 MILE TO FORKS, KEEP RIGHT FORK AND GO 0.15 MILE TO SIGN ON LEFT BLUEBERRY LEDGE TRAIL AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. FROM THE SIGN FOLLOW THE BLUEBERRY LEDGE TRAIL MARKED WITH BLUE PAINT AND SIGNS TO THE SUMMIT OF THE MOUNTAIN AND THE STATION.  (ABOUT 50 YARDS NORTHEAST OF THE STATION THERE IS A SPRING AND ABOUT 75 YARDS NORTHEAST OF STATION, THERE IS A SHELTER.) THE LAST PART OF THE TRAIL IS QUITE STEEP AND THERE ARE SEVEN SMALL LADDERS TO MAKE CLIMBING EASIER ON THE TRAIL.  (ABOUT A 3 HOUR PACK.)  STATION MARK IS AN IRON ROD CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ROCK LEDGE.  IT IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE AND INSIDE A CHISLED TRIANGLE TRENCH.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED WHITEFACE NO 1 1876, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BOULDER OUTCROP.  IT IS APPROXIMATELY 4 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED WHITEFACE NO 2 1876, IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BOULDER OUTCROP.  IT IS APPROXIMATELY 2 FEET LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US FOREST SERVICE 1959 (FSB) RECOVERED STATION AS DESCRIBED.  IN THE ROUTE TO STATION FOR, ON STATE HIGHWAY 113A FOR 6.4 MILES, IT SHOULD READ, ON STATE HIGHWAY 113A FOR 6.8 MILES.  STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 ARE IN GOOD CONDITION.  POINT IS ALSO WITNESSED BY THREE IRON BOLTS THAT WERE USED TO GUY THE ORIGINAL SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (2019)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2019 (MT) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

TURN LEFT AND PROCEED 1.05 KM (0.65 MI) ALONG AIRPORT ROAD TO E JOE ASTLE LANE ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND PROCEED NORTH 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) ON E JOE ASTLE LANE TO THE AIRPORT OFFICE AND A GATE. THE STATION IS LOCATED 79.25 M (260.01 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF NORTH 12 DEGREES EAST FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF RUNWAY 10-28, 36.88 M (121.00 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF SOUTH 14 DEGREES WEST FROM THE SOUTH RAIL OF THE BOSTON AND MAIN RAILROAD, AND 3.05 M (10.01 FT) ON A MAGNETIC COMPASS BEARING OF NORTH 75 DEGREES WEST FROM THE WINDSOCK. THIS STATION IS DESIGNATED AS THE PRIMARY AIRPORT CONTROL STATION.

BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HRL) STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6.0 MILES NORTHEAST OF STEWARTSTOWN, 2-1/2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PITTSBURG, AND ON PROPERTY OF MR. COLEMAN C. KEEZER.  IT IS 81.38 FEET SOUTH OF PITTSBURGS, UNITED STATES BORDER PATROL MAST, 80.5 FEET SOUTH OF A SMALL BUILDING AND 76 FEET SOUTHWEST OF POWERLINE POLE.  THE MARK IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND THE DISK IS STAMPED YOUNG 1959.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN PITTSBURG, GO SOUTH ON STATE HIGHWAY NO. 3 FOR 2.8 MILES TO TOP OF HILL, AND WOODEN GATE ON THE RIGHT OR WEST SIDE OF ROAD.  (CONTINUE SOUTH FOR 0.5 MILE TO AZIMUTH MARK ON THE RIGHT OR WEST SIDE OF ROAD.) TURN RIGHT PASSING THROUGH GATE AND GO NORTHWEST ON FIELD ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO STATION AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS 6.7 FEET NORTH OF UNITED STATES BORDER PATROL RADIO MAST, AND 11.8 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A SMALL BUILDING.  THE DISK IS A STANDARD TRIANGULATION REFERENCE MARK DISK, SET IN DRILLHOLE OF OUTCROPPING ROCK AND THE DISK IS STAMPED YOUNG NO 1 1959.  THIS REFERENCE MARK WAS SET IN THE PLACE OF YOUNG USGS 1925 THAT WAS MARKED BY A SMALL DRILLHOLE INSIDE OF A CHISELED TRIANGLE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS 26 FEET SOUTH OF SMALL KNOLL, AND 69 FEET SOUTHWEST OF DEADMAN FOR MAST CABLES.  THE MARK IS SET IN DRILLHOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK AND THE DISK IS STAMPED YOUNG NO 2 1959.  AZIMUTH MARK IS 16 FEET EAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF STATE HIGHWAY NO. 3, 71 FEET NORTHWEST OF TELEPHONE POLE NO. 33, AND 104 FEET SOUTH OF A 10 INCH BIRCH TREE.  IT IS SET IN DRILLHOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK, AND THE DISK IS STAMPED YOUNG 1959.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 18.50 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1964)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1964 (RAT) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1959 DESCRIPTION.  THE TWO REFERENCE MARKS AND THE STATION MARK WERE FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1994 (JDR) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 18.0 M (59.1 FT) SOUTH OF MANCHESTER, 12.0 MI (19.3 KM) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF LOWELL, MASS, 6.O MI EAST OF HOLLIS AT THE FAA ARTCC FACILITY CENTER IN NASHUA.  FOR ACCESS CONTACT MR KEN ACKER, FAA 35 NORTHEASTERN BLVD AND HARRIS ROAD, NASHUA, NH 30602.  PHONE (603) 886-7651.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM EXIT 4 U.S. HIGHWAY 3 (EAST DUNSTABLE ROAD) GO SOUTHERLY ON EAST DUNSTABLE ROAD FOR 0.1 MI (0.2 KM) TO A TRAFFIC LIGHT AND A ROAD ON THE RIGHT (NORTHEASTERN BLVD) .  TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY THEN NORTHERLY ON NORTHEASTERN BLVD FOR 0.6 MI (1.0 KM) TO THE ENTRANCE OF THE FAA ARTCC FACILITY ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEASTERLY ON ENTRANCE ROAD FOR 0.05 MI (0.08 KM) TO A GUARD HOUSE AND A GATE, PASS THROUGH GATE AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY ON ENTRANCE ROAD FOR 0.15 MI (0.24 KM) TO THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF A PARKING LOT AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. THE STATION IS LOCATED 52.0 FT (15.8 M) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF THE INTERSECTION OF A EAST-WEST AND A NORTH-SOUTH FENCELINE, 49.7 FT (15.1 M) EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE EASTERLY OF TWO 4X4 POST CEMENTED INTO THE GROUND AND USE TO HOLD A VOLLEYBALL NET, 46.8 FT (14.3 M) SOUTHWEST OF A NORTH-SOUTH FENCELINE, 22.5 FT (6.9 M) NORTHWEST OF A EAST-WEST FENCELINE AND 21.6 FT (6.6 M) NORTHWEST OF A CARSONITE WITNESS POST. NOTE--ACCESS TO THE DATUM POINT IS THROUGH A 5-INCH LOGO CAP.  THE SLEEVE DEPTH DOES NOT MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS FOR A CLASS A MARK.  THE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION, 35 NORTHEASTERN BOULEVARD AND HARRIS ROAD, NASHUA, NH 03062, TELEPHONE NUMBER (603) 886-7840.                            STATION RECOVERY (1998)  RECOVERY NOTE BY WOOLPERT CONSULTANTS 1998 (BBS) DESCRIBED BY WOOLPERT LLP 1998 (ARL) .  THE STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 29.0 KM (18.00 MI) SOUTH OF MANCHESTER, 19.3 KM (12.00 MI) NORTH NORTHWEST OF LOWELL MASSACHUSETTS, 9.7 KM (6.00 MI) EAST OF HOLLIS AT THE FAA ARTCC FACILITY IN NASHUA. OWNERSHIP--FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION, 35 NORTHEASTERN BOULEVARD AND HARRIS ROAD, NASHUA NH 03062, PHONE NUMBER 603-886-7840.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THEW JUNCTION OF US HIGHWAY 3 AND EAST DUNSTABLE ROAD (EXIT 4) IN NASHUA, PROCEED SOUTHERLY 0.2 KM (0.10 MI) TO HARRIS ROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED 0.4 KM (0.25 MI) WEST ALONG HARRIS ROAD TO NORTHEASTERN BOULEVARD.  TURN RIGHT AND PROCEED 0.5 KM (0.30 MI) NORTHWEST ALONG NORTHEASTERN BOULEVARD TO A SECURITY GATE. CONTIMUE THROUGH THE GATE AND PROCEED 0.3 KM (0.20 MI) NORTHEAST ACROSS THE PARKING LOT TO THE EAST CORNER OF THE FAA PROPERTY AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A STAINLESS STEEL ROD IN A SLEEVE FILLED WITH NON-TOXIC GREASE DRIVEN INTO THE GROUND, ENCASED IN A PVC PIPE. THE STATION IS RECESSED 0.05 M (0.16 FT) BELOW A LOGO CAP STAMPED--ZBW A 1994--, SURROUNDED IN CONCRETE 0.1 M (0.3 FT) IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 15.8 M (51.8 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE FENCE CORNER, 14.3 M (46.9 FT) SOUTHWEST OF THE SOUTHWEST PERIMETER FENCE, AND 6.9 M (22.6 FT) NORTHWEST OF A WITNESS POST. OWNERSHIP--FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION.  CONTACT MR. TIM NOYES, PHONE 603-879-6682 OR MR. JOHN NESBITT, PHONE 879-6415 ONE DAY IN ADVANCE BEFORE OCCUPYING THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF US HIGHWAY 3 (EXIT 4) AND EAST DUNSTABLE ROAD IN NASHUA, FROM THE SOUTHWEST END OF THE EAST DUNSTABLE OVERPASS BRIDGE OVER US HIGHWAY 3 GO SOUTHWEST ON EAST DUNSTABLE ROAD FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF HARRIS ROAD ON THE RIGHT (AT A TRAFFIC LIGHT), TURN RIGHT, NORTHERLY ON HARRIS ROAD FOR 0.40 KM (0.25 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF NORTHEASTERN BOULEVARD STRAIGHT AHEAD ON HARRIS ROAD TURNING WESTERLY ON THE LEFT (AT A TRAFFIC LIGHT) CONTINUE AHEAD, NORTHERLY ON NORTHEASTERN BOULEVARD FOR 0.48 KM (0.30 MI) TO THE ENTRANCE DRIVE FOR THE FAA FACILITY ON THE RIGHT AND BISHOP LANE ON THE LEFT, TURN RIGHT, NORTHEASTERLY ON THE ENTRANCE DRIVE FOR ABOUT 45.72 M (150.00 FT) TO THE SECURITY HOUSE ON THE LEFT, CHECK IN WITH SECURITY FOR A VISITORS PASS (CONTACT PERSON IN THE FACILITY IS MR.
